Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Avery v. Schneider as Next Friend of Schneider
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Allegations supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil to find officer for corporate entity hired to oversee safety, maintenance, and supervision of pool liable in action by parents and next friend of minor child, who nearly died from drowning and sustained brain injury, for negligence and fraud, despite claim that entity owed no duty or damages; officer and entity held entity out as qualified pool management company with properly trained and qualified lifeguards to protect members of community, lifeguard failed to employ proper post-drowning lifesaving techniques after she became aware of incident because she was improperly trained and supervised by entity, and since incident, and child had regular seizures requiring constant medication, migraine headaches, processing difficulties, poor memory, social difficulties, and other neurological and academic issues. (Per Hodges, J., with one judge concurring in the result.)
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations supported finding that officer for corporate entity that supervised pool breached duty to child who nearly drowned by inadequately training lifeguard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: ETC Texas Pipeline, Ltd. v. Addison Exploration & Development, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary pipeline companies and parent energy company shared officers did not establish agency liability on part of parent company for subsidiaries' actions with respect to alleged fraud and breach of contract with oil and gas lease development company absent evidence subsidiaries were acting on behalf of parent, as opposed to on their own behalf.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Energy company and subsidiary pipeline companies did not owe duty to development company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Landress v. Tier One Solar LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, investor sufficiently pled plausible claim for piercing corporate veil to hold parent company and its principals liable for subsidiary's purported fraud by alleging that subsidiary was undercapitalized, that parent and subsidiary disregarded corporate formalities by holding themselves out as joint entity when they obtained additional investment funds from another investor and commingling funds, that subsidiary and parent blurred lines of their corporate forms by agreeing that parent would provide additional inducements to investor in exchange for his investment in subsidiary, and that money was funneled from subsidiary to parent and served as conduit for principals to unjustly enrich themselves and render subsidiary insolvent.
Document Preview: TORTS  Parties. Company's former CFO was indispensable party in investor's action against company, its parent, and other executives.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Integration of physician advisor company into parent company's corporate structure was not sufficient basis to pierce corporate veil to hold parent company and subsidiaries liable for advisor company's allegedly fraudulent scheme in violation of False Claims Act; although parent placed trusted employees in management positions at advisor company, promoted company's products on corporate website, and promised to investigate allegations of abuse at company, advisor company was not facade for parent or any of its subsidiaries because company's alleged fraudulent scheme began years before its acquisition, and advisor was not insolvent and otherwise was able to satisfy judgment. 31 U.S.C.A. § 3729.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator alleged nationwide scope of scheme with sufficient particularity in FCA action against physician advisor company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Janvey v. Libyan Investment Authority
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, Libyan Foreign Investment Company (LFICO) was not Libyan Investment Authority's (LIA) alter ego, and thus LIA was not liable to receiver for assets related to Ponzi scheme for proceeds of LFICO's investments in scheme, even though LIA held LFICO's shares, where LFICO and LIA had separate boards of directors, there were no interlocks in boards of directors of LIA and LFICO, LIA was not responsible for controlling or managing specific activities or transactions at subsidiary level, and LIA did not play any role in connection with LFICO's investment in Ponzi scheme.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW  Foreign Sovereigns. District court had subject matter jurisdiction over receiver's action against Libyan Foreign Investment Company to recover Ponzi scheme...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Matthys v. Narconon Fresh Start
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Allegations of patient at substance abuse treatment facility operated by corporation stated a claim under Colorado law for piercing the corporate veil of two other corporations under alter ego theory, in action for breach of contract and fraud, alleging that treatment facility was not non-religious as promised, and that it did not offer treatment by qualified professionals and instead attempted to recruit patient into a church; patient alleged that corporate operator was subsidiary of second corporation which, in turn, was subsidiary of third corporation, and that third corporation oversaw church's drug rehabilitation activities and governed and controlled nearly every aspect of corporate operator's and second corporation's business activities.
Document Preview: TORTS  Emotional Distress. Alleged conduct of operator of substance abuse treatment facility was outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: William L. Thorp Revocable Trust v. Ameritas Inv. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: There was no evidence that either a grandparent or a parent corporation exercised actual control over subsidiary brokerage firms with regard to transactions allegedly constituting securities fraud or that the subsidiary brokerage firms were mere instrumentalities of the grandparent or parent corporations, precluding securities fraud claims against the grandparent or parent corporations.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investor failed to establish independent sales agent acted with scienter required for state and federal securities fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, there was a lack of corporate separateness between subsidiary propane company, its parent, which was not-for-profit limited liability company (LLC), and its grandparent, which was electric cooperative, as required to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract and fraud action of buyer of propane company, although propane company paid its own salaries and other expenses, propane company purchased its own assets and did business with third parties separate from cooperative, propane company was never referred to as a division of cooperative or LLC, cooperative did not use propane company's assets in its business, and formal legal requirements of propane company were observed, where cooperative was sole owner of LLC, which in turn was sole owner of propane company, entities had at least one common officer, cooperative guaranteed loans and donated capital to propane company, proceeds from sale of propane company to buyer went directly into cooperative's financial account, cooperative permitted propane company to use its real estate, and cooperative's board of directors served as LLC's ownership group, which governed propane company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, continued recognition of subsidiary propane company would sanction fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract and fraud action of buyer of propane company against parent and grandparent companies, where proceeds from buyer's purchase of propane company were transferred to grandparent company for nothing in return, such that if buyer was successful in its claims, it could not recover anything from propane company.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: FutureSelect Portfolio Management, Inc. v. Tremont Group Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Investor's complaint adequately stated a claim against investment firm's parent and grandparent based upon agency, where investor alleged that firm came under their control, which included the manner by which firm offered investments, including the funds that were alleged to be feeder funds for Ponzi scheme, alleged that parent and grandparent learned of firm's enormous exposure with perpetrator of Ponzi scheme and firm's representations to the feeder funds' investors regarding its oversight and monitoring of perpetrator of scheme were false or, at a minimum, highly suspect, and investor's complaint and hypothetical facts supported the claim that parent and grandparent controlled investment firm and retained the right to direct the manner in which firm's work was performed.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Pleading. Investor's complaint adequately stated a claim against investment firm's parent and grandparent based upon agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: FutureSelect Portfolio Management, Inc. v. Tremont Group Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Investor's contentions in complaint that investment firm's parent and grandparent marketed firm as a member of grandparent's family of companies and listed firm in its annual reports as one of its general agencies and other offices, which led investor to believe that firm had the authority to offer and sell funds, which were allegedly feeder funds for Ponzi scheme, were sufficient to state a claim on the basis of apparent agency.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Pleading. Investor's complaint adequately stated a claim against investment firm's parent and grandparent based upon agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: TechTarget, Inc. v. Spark Design, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a corporate veil may be pierced when the parent exercises some form of pervasive control of the activities of the subsidiary and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Advertising firm could not pierce the corporate veil of client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Vanderbilt Mortg. and Finance, Inc. v. Flores
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Corpus Christi Division.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, pursuant to Texas law, parent company can be found liable if: (1) parent exercised complete control over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such control was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Manufactured home purchasers had standing to sue under Texas fraudulent lien statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Kriegel v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Banking corporation could not be held directly liable for alleged fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, negligent misrepresentation, and violations of Washington's Consumer Protection Act (WCPA) that purportedly arose from automatic renewal of certificate of deposit (CD) by corporation's subsidiary. While corporation and subsidiary clearly had similar names, the deposit agreement governing the CD specifically defined the name of the bank as referring to the subsidiary. Customer's relationship was solely with the subsidiary. West's RCWA 19.86.020.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Banking corporation could not be held directly liable regarding automatic renewal of certificate of deposit by subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Campagnolo S.R.L. v. Full Speed Ahead, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Parent company did not exercise total domination over subsidiary sufficient to be vicariously liable in a false advertising action. While parent company was able to exercise some control over subsidiary and is nearly the sole-supplier to subsidiary, parent company did not exercise any control of the day-to-day operations of subsidiary. There was no overlap between parent and subsidiary employees, and no subsidiary employees reported to any employees of the parent company. Further, no evidence existed that parent company had any oversight over the content of subsidiary company's advertising.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company did not exercise total domination over subsidiary sufficient to be vicariously liable in a false advertising action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Colorado Coffee Bean, LLC v. Peaberry Coffee Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. IV.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish, in trial of fraudulent nondisclosure action that franchisees brought against franchisor and franchisor's parent company for failing to disclose that parent company suffered significant losses every year, that parent company was not the alter ego of the franchisor; there was no evidence that franchisor was formed for fraudulent purposes, there was evidence that corporate formalities were not disregarded, and there was no expert testimony concerning the appropriate level of capital for franchisor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Franchises and Dealerships. Exculpatory clauses did not preclude franchisees from reasonably relying on the nondisclosure of parent company's losses.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: GEM Advisors, Inc. v. Corporacion Sidenor, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Consulting firm adequately pled that Spanish parent corporation exercised its dominance over subsidiary to commit fraud or wrong that injured firm as required to pierce subsidiary's corporate veil under New York law for purpose of parent's liability on claims alleging that subsidiary breached letter agreement with firm by selling Mexican steel mills without paying required fees for New York firm's services in finding buyer and that subsidiary fraudulently misrepresented mills' ownership structure; defendants allegedly fraudulently and repeatedly represented that parent had no direct ownership in mills, thus causing firm to enter into and perform under the letter agreements without requiring parent to bind itself to a separate agreement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary acted as corporation's agent for purposes of personal jurisdiction over corporation in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Formosa Plastics Corp., USA v. Kajima Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: A showing that corporate project owner used its wholly-owned subsidiary to perpetuate an actual fraud on contractor was not required to find that project owner and subsidiary constituted a single business enterprise that could be held liable to contractor for fraud arising from contracts, where project owner, and not subsidiary, signed contracts, and jury found project owner guilty of its own fraud. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(2).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Experts. Expert was not disqualified in fraud action on basis of colleague's prior consultation with opposing party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Formosa Plastics Corp., USA v. Kajima Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporate project owner and its wholly-owned subsidiary constituted a "single business enterprise" that could be held liable to contractor for fraud, where companies had common employees during relevant time period, companies shared common offices, companies had a centralized or coordinated accounting system to the extent they related to approval of construction change orders with regard to project, companies shared a common business name, and employees of one company rendered services on behalf of the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Experts. Expert was not disqualified in fraud action on basis of colleague's prior consultation with opposing party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Tamko Roofing Products, Inc. v. Smith Engineering Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, an inequitable result would not occur based on failure to hold parent corporation liable for judgment obtained against wholly owned subsidiary, in action for fraudulent misrepresentation, breach of contract, and breach of warranty, and thus, alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation; there was no showing that parent corporation was involved with any fraud against judgment creditor, or that parent corporation knew what representations that subsidiary made to judgment creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Alter ego doctrine would not be invoked against parent corporation for conduct of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Upperman v. Grange Indemn. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Common Pleas of Ohio, Franklin County.
Headnote: Insureds stated claim to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent corporation liable for automobile insurers' alleged fraud and violation of statutory requirement to file rate increase with Department of Insurance; vice president's letter showing awareness of decision not to refund the illegally charged premiums was unclear as to his position with regard to parent or subsidiaries. R.C. § 3937.03(A, H).
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Premiums. Insureds had implied private right of action against automobile insurers for charging unfiled rates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Valley Regional Medical Center v. Wright
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Brownsville Division.
Headnote: Company that had acquired hospital had not used it for fraudulent purposes, as required by Texas statute holding parent liable for contractual obligations of subsidiary, when representatives of hospital allegedly fraudulently represented that he would be considered for appointed director of cardiovascular surgery; there was no showing that representatives did not intend to select some physician as director, before decision was made to terminate search and make other arrangements. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Acquiring company did not assume contractual obligation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Greater Hammond Community Services, Inc. v. Mutka
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Distinct corporations, even parent and subsidiary corporations, are presumed separate; to overcome this presumption, plaintiff must show that one corporation dominated another to the extent that the subordinate was the mere instrumentality of the dominant corporation, that the dominant corporation employed the subordinate to perpetrate a fraud, or that the capital placed in the subordinate was illusory or trifling compared to the business to be done and the risks of loss, and also must demonstrate that the defalcation of the corporations, for example, fraud, was the proximate cause of the injury sustained.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Regional community services organization was not protected by Tort Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Yoder v. Honeywell Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, corporation was not alter ego of former subsidiary, and so was not liable for acts of former subsidiary; although corporation was responsible for incorporation of former subsidiary, and board of directors consisted wholly of members of board of corporation for period, and then two of three members of board of former subsidiary were members of board of corporation for subsequent period, former subsidiary maintained separate corporate existence, was fully capitalized from inception, was not used to defeat public convenience or to justify or protect wrong, fraud, or crime, and had legitimate business purpose.
Document Preview: Worker brought products liability action against corporation, and corporation's former subsidiary that manufactured computer keyboard, for injuries suffered from use of allegedly defective...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Boughton v. Cotter Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, mere fact that corporate subsidiary became undercapitalized solely due to recharacterization of its assets when it ceased operations did not prove that corporation was set up to be undercapitalized, or that it was used to defeat public convenience, or to justify or protect wrong, fraud or crime, so as to support piercing of corporate veil to hold parent liable for conduct of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Residents filed action against owner of uranium mill and its parent corporation, asserting various state and federal claims arising from alleged exposure to emissions from mill.  The...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Bollwerk v. Susquehanna Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be found liable, under South Dakota law, for alleged acts of wholly owned subsidiary in fraudulently concealing medical information from employee during time he was employed at uranium processing mill, where subsidiary was a fully operational corporation that kept separate financial records and observed corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Former employee of subsidiary brought suit against parent and subsidiaries, alleging that one or more defendants fraudulently concealed medical information from him during time he was...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Trak Microcomputer Corp. v. Wearne Bros.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation would be liable for any fraudulent acts of subsidiary and would be subjected to Illinois jurisdiction when it was alter ego of subsidiary for fraudulent acts as well as acts in Illinois which gave rise to jurisdiction.
Document Preview: Action was brought alleging pattern of racketeering activity in violation of RICO in addition to other theories of liability stemming from alleged fraud and misrepresentation made in the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Agristor Leasing v. Guggisberg
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Minnesota law did not allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation of manufacturer of animal feed storage system liable on farmers' claims against the manufacturer on claims of strict liability, negligence, breach of warranty, and misrepresentation, absent showing that the manufacturer had been operated in unjust manner or that it was alter ego of the parent corporation.
Document Preview: Farmers against whom action was brought for breach of lease and wrongful detention of property filed third-party complaint against manufacturer, marketer, and seller of animal feed storage...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Cawley v. Bloch
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation formed after parent had committed alleged wrongdoing could not be held responsible for the alleged wrongful acts where plaintiffs did not allege any facts that suggested relationship between the two corporations was anything other than a legitimate parent-subsidiary relationship and where the corporate relationship could not have been designed to defraud anyone.
Document Preview: Operators of legal clinic brought action in contract and quantum meruit and for fraudulent and negligent misrepresentation and concealment against foreign parent and subsidiary...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1074 Fraud >
Title: Muttontown Pictures, Inc. v. Levine
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Alleged fact that one defendant was parent of corporation with which plaintiff had contracted was insufficient to foist liability on said parent in fraud action, in absence of any factual allegations asserting wrongdoing by the said parent.
Document Preview: Producer of motion picture brought breach of contract and fraud action against distributor and its parent corporation. The Supreme Court, New York County, Harold Baer, J., entered judgment,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: In re Flint Water Cases
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, there was no evidence that parent corporation exercised control over subsidiary in manner amounting to fraud, wrong, or misuse of corporate form, and thus, corporate veil could not be pierced to impose alter ego liability against parent for alleged professional negligence of subsidiary engineering services contractor for city's water treatment plant, based on parent-subsidiary relationship, in Bellwether cases regarding city's contaminated water supply, since subsidiary was not formed for any improper purpose and did not engage in unlawful activity through performance of professional engineering services.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego liability could not be imposed against parent by piercing corporate veil based on parent-subsidiary relationship in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Neill v. Cinema de Lux
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation of movie theater operator did not owe duty of care to patron who allegedly fell on wet condition in restroom at leased premises, in absence of any evidence that corporation exercised complete domination and control over the wholly owned subsidiary, to which it had assigned its rights and obligations under the lease.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Parent corporation owed no duty of care to patron who fell on premises operated by wholly-owned subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: McElroy v. FirstEnergy Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, security guard employed by security company, who fell on a set of stairs and injured his ankle while working at power plant, together with his wife could not pierce the corporate veil to assert claims for negligence and loss of consortium against plant operator's parent company, since these were straightforward torts, that were not based on allegations of extreme shareholder misconduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Security guard injured in fall at jobsite could not pierce corporate veil to assert tort claims against parent of jobsite operator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Layne Christensen Company v. City of Franklin, Tennessee
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: City, who alleged subsidiary of water resource company performed defective work prior to company's acquisition of subsidiary, was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of water resource company or its parent company in action brought by company against city for declaratory judgment to determine whether company was financially liable for alleged defective work; city did not assert that company or subsidiary used the corporate entity to avoid obligations, and at the time subsidiary performed the alleged defective work company and its parent company were not in control of subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Fact issue existed whether company's acquisition of subsidiary resulted in mere continuance of subsidiary on issue of company's liability...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Avery v. Schneider as Next Friend of Schneider
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Allegations supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil to find officer for corporate entity hired to oversee safety, maintenance, and supervision of pool liable in action by parents and next friend of minor child, who nearly died from drowning and sustained brain injury, for negligence and fraud, despite claim that entity owed no duty or damages; officer and entity held entity out as qualified pool management company with properly trained and qualified lifeguards to protect members of community, lifeguard failed to employ proper post-drowning lifesaving techniques after she became aware of incident because she was improperly trained and supervised by entity, and since incident, and child had regular seizures requiring constant medication, migraine headaches, processing difficulties, poor memory, social difficulties, and other neurological and academic issues. (Per Hodges, J., with one judge concurring in the result.)
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations supported finding that officer for corporate entity that supervised pool breached duty to child who nearly drowned by inadequately training lifeguard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Cases
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Agency or alter ego theory did not apply to render initial manufacturer of talcum powder, which passed production to wholly owned subsidiary, liable for negligent failure to warn of risks of ovarian cancer after manufacturer had ceased production, despite contention that manufacturer was "directing" subsidiary's actions; even though there was legal relationship between manufacturer and subsidiary, which had similar company names, and some coordination between manufacturer and subsidiary on issues related to talc, manufacturer did not control subsidiary or treat subsidiary as merely conduit or instrumentality of itself.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Warnings. Initial manufacturer of talcum powder did not have duty to warn of ovarian cancer risk at time it was manufacturing or after it ceased production.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Doe v. Bank of America Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Bank's parent corporation could not be held liable for negligence or breach of contract based on bank's alleged actions in abruptly closing, without explanation, accounts held by an international political figure and his daughter, where plaintiffs pled no facts under either a direct or derivative theory of liability and advanced no alternative theories under which parent could be found liable, as bank agreement governing the accounts made clear that relevant banking relationship was with bank, not its parent, which was accepted by plaintiffs when they signed personal signature cards that indicated that banking agreement governed their accounts.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Accounts. There was no claim for breach of implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing where bank had no contractual duty to not close bank accounts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Gourdine v. Karl Storz Endoscopy–America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under California law, German medical device manufacturer's subsidiary, which was a California company that marketed and distributed the devices within the United States, was manufacturer's agent under representative services theory, as required for subsidiary's actions to be imputed to manufacturer in patient's products liability action; manufacturer and subsidiary shared the same market branding, manufacturer drafted all marketing, training, and sales materials used by the subsidiary and directed the subsidiary to market its products in all states, manufacturer had similar subsidiaries in other markets around the world and managed those subsidiaries collectively, and services of those subsidiaries were essential to manufacturer's unitary enterprise.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over German medical device manufacturer in products liability action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Federico v. Lincoln Military Housing, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, parent company of property acquisition and management company that managed and operated military housing communities could not be held liable in action, brought by family that resided in military housing community, against company and independent contractor, alleging violations of Virginia Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (VRLTA), breach of lease, negligence, and negligence per se, based on allegations that property company and contractor failed to disclose known and concealed defects concerning water intrusion and mold, failed to maintain portions of home outside the exclusive possession and control of tenant, and negligently performed repairs, where parent company did not use organizational structure to perpetrate fraud or gain unfair advantage, and separateness of companies did not work injustice. West's V.C.A. § 36–97 et seq.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Family's claim against company that managed military housing community was not barred by derivative immunity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Muniz v. Walgreen Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, corporate parent of drug store operator did not exercise sufficient control over operator to warrant piercing corporate veil in customers' negligence action alleging that their child was given wrong prescription, although operator and parent shared close branding relationship, where parent did not disregard corporate formalities, parent did not exercise control over operator's day-to-day operations, parent and operator did not have overlapping directors or personnel, operator was not undercapitalized, operator filed independent annual reports, operator had own headquarters, operator independently obtained all necessary licensing and permits required by Puerto Rico, operator maintained separate accounting books, and operator paid salary of its employees.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Puerto Rico contacts of drug store operator's corporate parent were not proximate cause of child receiving wrong prescription.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Glenn v. TPI Petroleum, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil of parent company was not warranted in order to establish liability for alleged wrongful acts of subsidiaries related to negligence action, where parent company was a holding company without employees or direct involvement in provision of goods or services, there was no evidence of comingling of funds between parent and subsidiaries or that parent controlled decisions and acts of subsidiaries, the only tangible indication of a relationship between parent and subsidiaries was location of offices at a shared address, and there was no allegation that parent engaged in any wrongdoing.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked limited personal jurisdiction over non-resident petroleum company in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: North Cypress Medical Center Operating Co. Ltd v. Fedex Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Delivery service provider's parent company could not be held liable for provider's alleged negligence in failing to notify medical center operator that a box containing confidential patient information had been dropped and documents had been lost during shipment merely because of their corporate relationship.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Airline Deregulation Act preempted medical center operator's tort claims against delivery service provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Yanmar Co., Ltd. v. Slater
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: American subsidiary of Japanese tractor manufacturer owed no duty to purchaser, who was using tractor to mow grass on slope near a pond on his property when it rolled over, thereby killing him, for purposes of negligence action brought by purchaser's estate; subsidiary was not even in existence at the time that the tractor was manufactured, subsidiary had nothing to do with the design, manufacture, or distribution of the tractor, subsidiary never sold purchaser a part for his tractor, and appellate court would not impute any duty of manufacturer to its subsidiary because there was no indication that subsidiary was engaged in a joint venture with manufacturer or acted as an agent for manufacturer.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have general jurisdiction over Japanese tractor manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ramcke v. Georgia Power Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for any negligence on part of subsidiary that owned property and subsidiary that engineered and designed property's construction project on property regarding alleged failure to keep premises safe during project; there was insufficient evidence to pierce corporate veil, and there was no indication that parent corporation participated in a joint venture with its subsidiaries or acted as their agent or alter ego. West's Ga.Code Ann. § 51–3–1.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Property owner and its agent had no duty to keep work premises safe for construction company's invitees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Kriegel v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Banking corporation could not be held directly liable for alleged fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, negligent misrepresentation, and violations of Washington's Consumer Protection Act (WCPA) that purportedly arose from automatic renewal of certificate of deposit (CD) by corporation's subsidiary. While corporation and subsidiary clearly had similar names, the deposit agreement governing the CD specifically defined the name of the bank as referring to the subsidiary. Customer's relationship was solely with the subsidiary. West's RCWA 19.86.020.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Banking corporation could not be held directly liable regarding automatic renewal of certificate of deposit by subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Huff v. First Energy Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Trumbull County.
Headnote: Holding company that developed specifications controlling manner in which subsidiary companies would manage vegetation surrounding electrical lines owed no duty of care to pedestrian who was struck by decaying maple tree in inspection zone created by those specifications, where holding company did not create subsidiary power company that had easement to control surrounding vegetation, there was no indication that holding company obtained its controlling interest to defraud or engage in malfeasance, and there was no indication that holding company supervised power company's implementation of specifications or had any say over which contractor was hired to manage vegetation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Issue as to whether pedestrian struck by tree was intended beneficiary of vegetation management contract barred summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ward v. Cross County Multiplex Cinemas, Inc
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff, who was injured at a theater, failed to allege the type of domination required to pierce the corporate veil, so as to hold parent corporation of theater's owner liable for the purported negligence of the theater owner.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Merged corporation was not liable for purported negligence of surviving corporate occurring more than two years after merger.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Shaw v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: A parent corporation could not be held liable for the alleged negligent actions of its indirect subsidiary in Brazil where the parent corporation was a separate and distinct legal entity that was not responsible for the Brazil subsidiary. The parent corporation asserted that the subsidiary had separate corporate leadership and separate finances. Despite being given the explicit opportunity to do so, an injured consumer did not provide any evidence to the contrary nor did the consumer allege that the parent corporation's improper corporate conduct caused the consumer inability to obtain an adequate remedy from the subsidiary. Therefore, the parent corporation's motion to dismiss was granted.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dismissal. A parent corporation could not be held liable for the alleged negligent actions of its indirect subsidiary in Brazil where the parent corporation was a separate and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Nassau County v. Richard Dattner Architect, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for alleged breach of contract and negligence of contractor acquired by its subsidiary was not warranted, absent showing that parent dominated and controlled the activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold parent liable for subsidiary's breach of contract

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Figueiredo v. New Palace Painters Supply Co. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: General contractor could not seek indemnification or contribution from property owner on negligence and scaffolding law claims asserted against general contractor on behalf of laborer who died on renovation project when he fell through an open hole, though general contractor and property owner shared common owners and officers, as general contractor and property owner were separate entities and not parent/subsidiary, property owner had hired general contractor to run the renovation project, and property owner did not supervise, direct, or control the contractors or work, and it did not enter into contracts with subcontractors, or provide tools or materials. McKinney's Labor Law § 240(1).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. Violation of scaffolding law was the proximate cause of death of laborer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Moyle v. Elliott Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Charter flight subsidiary of parent aviation company did not perform repairs or maintenance work on decedent's single-engine aircraft, precluding decedent's estate from recovering on negligence claim against subsidiary following decedent's fatal plane crash, even though parent company printed subsidiary's name on an invoice for the relevant repairs; charter flight subsidiary appeared on invoice in clerical error, parent company's other subsidiary, a repair facility, admitted that it performed the allegedly negligent repairs, and payment collected by invoice was credited to the repair subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Aviation repair subsidiary was a viable corporation, precluding estate from piercing the corporate veil in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Moyle v. Elliott Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Subsidiary of parent aviation company that admitted to performing repairs to decedent's single-engine aircraft, which repairs allegedly caused decedent's fatal air crash, was a viable corporation, precluding decedent's estate from piercing the corporate veil in order to hold parent company liable for subsidiary's alleged negligence; even though subsidiary did not maintain a separate bank account from parent, subsidiary was a licensed aircraft repair business and carried its own liability insurance policy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Aviation repair subsidiary was a viable corporation, precluding estate from piercing the corporate veil in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Moyle v. Elliott Aviation, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Repair subsidiary of parent aviation company was not a mere instrumentality of its parent, precluding decedent's estate from recovering on negligence claim against the parent company for repairs performed by subsidiary that allegedly caused decedent's fatal single-engine plane crash; subsidiary did not intend to avoid a legal obligation, as it conceded that it performed the allegedly negligent repairs, it did not move for summary judgment, and its financial resources included a large liability insurance policy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Aviation repair subsidiary was a viable corporation, precluding estate from piercing the corporate veil in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Beck v. Consolidated Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, pedestrian's conclusory statements were insufficient to support piercing of parent corporation's corporate veil based on its subsidiary's alleged negligence in maintaining property, in pedestrian's negligence action to recover damages for injury she sustained when concrete curb broke under her foot, causing her to fall forward into street, absent evidence that parent corporation managed subsidiary, or that any control parent corporation exercised over subsidiary was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured pedestrian.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Former owner of property owed no direct duty to pedestrian injured when curb broke under her foot.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Forsythe v. Clark USA, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Estates of deceased employees who alleged that employer's sole corporate shareholder, by mandating that employer was to operate oil refinery at 25% cost reduction, interposed guiding hand in employer's management of refinery, leaving employer no choice but to obey, invoked "direct participation" exception to the general rule that corporate veil will not be pierced in absence of large-scale disregard of separate existence of subsidiary corporation, given that estates' theory of negligence did not rest upon corporate shareholder's legal status in relation to employer, but, instead, on shareholder's own conduct.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employees' estates invoked direct participation exception to rule that corporate veil will not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Potash v. Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Slip and fall victim failed to prove that premises lessee's parent corporation so dominated the lessee's operation as to warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold the parent liable for the lessee's negligence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Premises lessee's parent corporation was not liable to slip and fall victim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: McConkey v. McGhan Medical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Former parent company had no duty to customers of former subsidiary that had separate legal identity, and therefore claim of negligence under Tennessee law against former parent company by customers of former subsidiary failed.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Breast implant recipient failed to make showing that former parent company controlled former subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Manchester Equipment Co., Inc. v. American Way
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, subsidiary did not have apparent authority to act on parent's behalf, and thus parent could not be held liable to seller for any negligence of subsidiary in failing to implement appropriate security measures before allowing unknown persons to take computers from subsidiary's warehouse, even though buyer may have believed he was dealing with parent, absent evidence that seller believed he was dealing with parent when he contracted with subsidiary
Document Preview: Seller of computer equipment brought state court action against parent of storage company for negligently delivering goods to unknown persons. Following removal, parent moved for summary...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Parent corporation's relationship with subsidiary hospital perpetuated a separate and individual corporate existence which could not be disregarded for purposes of imposing liability on parent corporation for alleged negligent acts with respect to care and treatment provided to patient while undergoing surgery at hospital, absent showing that parent corporation entered into a relationship with hospital to perpetuate fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Corporate forms of hospital and its parent corporation could not be disregarded to impose liability on parent corporation for alleged negligent acts with respect to care and treatment provided to patient while undergoing surgery at hospital, though parent corporation had control over some of hospital's affairs and participated in many of hospital's activities, absent showing that parent corporation had control or right to control over medical care of patients at hospital.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Affiliation agreement entered into between hospital and its parent corporation and hospital documents bearing the parent corporation's emblem merely suggested that hospital was an affiliate in the parent corporation's health care delivery system, not that parent corporation consented or knowingly permitted hospital to perform patient's surgery so as to impose liability on parent corporation under apparent authority principles for alleged negligent acts with respect to care and treatment provided to patient while undergoing surgery at hospital.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Abdel-Fattah v. Pepsico, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Parent corporation's 100% ownership of stock of subsidiary corporation did not make it liable for alleged negligence of its subsidiary.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer Torts. Parent's 100% ownership of subsidiary's stock corporation did not make it liable for subsidiary's alleged negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Humana, Inc. v. Kissun
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Corporate veil separating parent corporation owning number of hospitals from subsidiary operating one hospital would not be pierced, in malpractice suit brought against subsidiary, even though subsidiary used logo of parent on its letterhead, sign and advertising, parent hired attorneys to handle suits for or against subsidiary, and subsidiary's chief executive officer was hired and supervised by a regional vice president of parent; there was no showing of abuse of corporate form or that adherence to separate corporate identity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil of subsidiary could not be pierced in malpractice case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Humana, Inc. v. Kissun
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for alleged malpractice on part of physicians who were employees of subsidiary corporation operating hospital, under theories of apparent agency or joint venture, even though hospital displayed logo of parent.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil of subsidiary could not be pierced in malpractice case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Porter v. LSB Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: No basis existed for imposing liability in products liability and negligence action on holder of trademark for lathe in its capacity as shareholder of subsidiary which distributed lathe by "piercing the corporate veil," where subsidiary was not undercapitalized, shareholder observed corporate formalities, and subsidiary was not misused either to perpetuate a fraud or to inflict injury, nor was subsidiary formed for the purpose of carrying out parent's business while insulating parent from liability.
Document Preview: Trademark. Holder of trademark on lathe could not be held liable either in negligence or in strict products liability for injury suffered by lathe operator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: National Bank of Commerce (of El Dorado) v. HCA Health Services of Midwest, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: There was no evidence to support piercing of corporate veil of hospital to hold hospital's parent liable for hospital's negligence.
Document Preview: In action for injuries sustained by newborn infant, the Circuit Court, Saline County, John W. Cole, J., rendered judgment for defendant nurses and for plaintiffs against hospital. ...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Lener v. Club Med, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not liable for negligence or breach of contract in connection with injuries sustained by passenger when he slipped and fell on excursion boat owned by parent corporation's partially-owned subsidiary, even though parent corporation provided some personnel and administrative technical services to subsidiary; passenger failed to show that parent exercised such complete domination and control over subsidiary that parent could be held liable for torts of subsidiary.

Title: Montgomery Health Care Facility, Inc. v. Ballard
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Parent corporation of nursing home owner could be held liable for nursing home's negligence, resulting in patient's death, where parent controlled, or retained right to control day-to-day operations of home.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Meshel v. Resorts Intern. of New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation, which operated tour business which provided customers to hotel indirectly owned by parent corporation and which did not share employees, assets, or business of parent corporation, could not be held liable for alleged negligence of hotel's agents or employees in responding to an emergency with defective oxygen equipment and spent or inadequate oxygen cylinders.

Title: Helzer v. F. Joseph Lamb Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Public policy did not require that corporate veil of Canadian corporation be pierced in negligence action by Michigan resident injured in accident in Canada involving employee of that corporation, to reach United States parent of Canadian corporation.

Title: Eastridge Development Co. v. Halpert Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate parent of engineering firm acted as firm's alter ego and was therefore liable for firm's negligent performance of soil studies, where parent used its subsidiaries in manner calculated to insulate assets from professional liability, and after acquiring engineering firm, allowed professional liability insurance to lapse, assumed control of its operations and management and moved it in with another subsidiary.

Title: Eastridge Development Co. v. Halpert Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Punitive damages were not recoverable against corporate parent of engineering firm with respect to parent's liability as alter-ego of engineering firm, since liability of parent could not exceed that which arose from engineering firm's professional negligence.

Title: Spearing v. Bayfield County
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil" did not prohibit state court from stacking negligence of subsidiary with negligence of parent corporation where tort liability resulting from accident involved neither fraud nor claim in equity.

Title: Boafo v. Hospital Corp. of America
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Even though two corporations shared some officers and had jointly purchased hospital property from bankruptcy receivership, subsidiary was not a shell for parent corporation in operating hospital, but did fully and, for the most part, autonomously operate and manage hospital, and thus, patient, who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital, was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation, where subsidiary was fully capitalized entity which was insured and which owned hospital property, subsidiary managed and operated hospital on a day-to-day basis, and subsidiary maintained its own payroll and employed its own employees.

Title: Boafo v. Hospital Corp. of America
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Assuming the means of sustaining independent identity of subsidiary corporation from parent were absent, no basis existed for disregarding parent's separate identity and holding it liable to patient, who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital operated by subsidiary, unless parent's ulterior motive or purpose was to promote fraud and injustice or defeat a public convenience, and thus, corporate veil of parent would not be pierced, since no such evidence was presented.

Title: Agristor Leasing v. Guggisberg
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Minnesota law did not allow piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation of manufacturer of animal feed storage system liable on farmers' claims against the manufacturer on claims of strict liability, negligence, breach of warranty, and misrepresentation, absent showing that the manufacturer had been operated in unjust manner or that it was alter ego of the parent corporation.
