Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Luckett v. Bethlehem Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Although parent corporation indirectly owned 70% of stock of foreign subsidiary and furnished ten of the managing officers of the latter, many of whom held managerial posts in parent, and had contracted to furnish subsidiary with technical services and manufacturing equipment as well as locating the business for it and although parent's employee, who while with subsidiary, negotiated contract with plaintiff's employer, it could not be said that subsidiary was a mere alter ego instrumentality of the parent so as to hold parent liable for any negligence of subsidiary employee, especially absent any showing of fraud or inequitable conduct resulting from use of separate corporate structures.
Document Preview: Action was brought against United States corporation and its subsidiary, a Singapore corporation, to recover for injuries which plaintiff sustained when crane cable snapped on board a...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Pushnik v. Winky's Drive-In Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although wholly owned subsidiary was separate legal entity from its owner, where owner leased land for subsidiary and then subleased land to subsidiary, where owner hired and paid architect and contractors responsible for building subsidiary, which was fast food restaurant, where subsequent to time of accident wherein automobile crashed through glass enclosure into restaurant pinning patron to steel counters, decision was made to alter structure of subsidiary to provide seating space for customers in restaurant, which decision was made and alterations paid for by owner, where owner employed supervisors who made periodic inspections of fast food restaurant, where supervisors were responsible for hiring, training, and firing management of restaurant, it could be found that owner was in control of premises on date of accident and thus owner could be held liable in patron's negligence suit against it, subsidiary, and others.(Per Price, J., with one Judge concurring and with three Judges joining in concurring opinion and two Judges concurring in result.)
Document Preview: Fast food restaurant patron brought negligence action against restaurant owner, restaurant, i.e., wholly owned subsidiary of owner, lessor, et al., for injuries arising out of accident...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co. v. Arkla Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Where workman sustained injuries when he inhaled and came in contact with hydrochloric acid while unloading the acid from tank truck which was owned by chemical company but leased by gas company, the chemical company which was wholly-owned subsidiary of gas company was, under Arkansas law, legally responsible for negligent acts of employees of the gas company in connection with handling of the acid.
Document Preview: Action was brought by insurer, injured workman, and his wife against chemical company for injuries sustained when the workman inhaled hydrochloric acid while unloading the acid from tank...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Where corporate parent of subsidiary, which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs, exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized "dummy" and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Noto v. Cia Secula di Armanento
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate members of Iranian Oil Consortium were not liable for deaths and injuries resulting from explosion of Italian oil tanker in Iranian port because of alleged negligence of Dutch corporation which owned and operated terminal where explosion occurred on theory that corporate identity should be disregarded because corporation was the "alter ego" and agent of its parent corporations, where the Dutch corporation was a solvent and substantial corporation and functioned as a separate corporate unit as it was set up to function under the agreement.
Document Preview: Five actions brought on behalf of next of kin of 28 deceased crew members and by 7 injured survivors of a tanker which exploded in an Iranian port. The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J.,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1075 Negligence >
Title: Garden City Co. v. Burden
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: In action by a farmer against an irrigation company and its corporate parent, where irrigation company had no assets, owned no property other than easement in irrigation ditch and parent company owned, controlled and directed all operations of irrigation company, it would be inequitable to permit parent to escape liability because of negligent operation of ditch by irrigation company under pretext of separate identity of two corporations.
Document Preview: Action by J. L. Burden agasinst the Garden City Company, a corporation, and another for damages to plaintiff's land caused by the negligence of defendants in the operatinon of an irrigation...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Boston Scientific Corp. v. Cook Group Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil of parent company of patent holders' competitor was not justified, as would support holding parent directly liable for competitor's infringement of patent directed to reversibly closeable endoscopic hemostatic clips for treating gastrointestinal bleeding; parent did not make, use, sell, offer to sell, or import competitor's products, and there was no indication competitor was an "alter ego" of parent or that treating competitor as a separate corporate entity would promote fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Medical Devices and Procedures. Products literally infringed patent claim disclosing a medical device comprising a separate link to release a control wire from a clip.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: British Telecommunications PLC v. IAC/InteractiveCorp
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Patent infringement plaintiff plausibly pleaded agency relationship between parent company and subsidiary software companies, as required to state claim against parent company under agency theory of vicarious liability; as alleged, parent company represented to public that subsidiaries' software products fell under its proprietary brands, provided technology and network systems that allowed such software to operate in violation of patents, directly hired and fired officers of its subsidiaries, shared officers and directors and shuffled officers throughout its subsidiaries, and relied on system in which persons responsible for overseeing subsidiaries reported directly to parent company's chief executive officer, rather than reporting to their own companies' boards of directors.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Parent company could be liable for patent infringement by subsidiaries under agency theory of vicarious liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: British Telecommunications PLC v. IAC/InteractiveCorp
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Patent infringement plaintiff plausibly pleaded agency relationship between holding company and sub-subsidiary software companies, as required to state claim against holding company under agency theory of vicarious liability; as alleged, holding company used language "we" in annual reports when referring to software products, and promulgated software products which infringed patents.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Parent company could be liable for patent infringement by subsidiaries under agency theory of vicarious liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Adtile Technologies Inc. v. Perion Network Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations of developer of multi-sensor advertising technology and services for smartphones and tablets that corporate officer and another employee listed both Israeli parent corporation and its subsidiary as their place of employment on social media website were insufficient to support an agency or alter ego theory, and were thus insufficient for district court to pierce corporate veil and attribute subsidiary's alleged actions to parent corporation, on developer's breach of contract and trademark infringement action against parent corporation and subsidiary; parent corporation and its subsidiaries maintained separate books, records, and accounts.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal or general jurisdiction over Israeli corporation that did not advertise in forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Astornet Technologies Inc. v. BAE Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: District court's focus on facts that would justify piercing corporate veil of corporate subsidiary was too narrow to support dismissal of patent infringement action brought by licensee of patent for airport gate entry system against parent corporation for allegedly inducing infringement by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) by virtue of TSA's use of airport equipment supplied by the subsidiary; although focus on veil-piercing facts was appropriate for considering parent corporation's indirect liability for infringement committed by subsidiary, veil-piercing standards did not govern issues of direct liability, and district court's analysis should have included examination of whether parent corporation affirmatively encouraged TSA to enter into contract with subsidiary to engage in infringement. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(b).
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - United States. Patent licensee's exclusive remedy for alleged infringement by government contractors was suit against United States in Court of Federal Claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Baby Phat Holding Co., LLC v. Kellwood Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Purchaser of certain trademarks, copyrights, and contractual rights stated a breach of contract claim against seller's parent company, based upon an alter-ego theory, where purchaser alleged that parent company dominated and controlled negotiations on behalf of seller and actually provided erroneous information which persuaded purchaser to enter into the agreement, that purchaser paid full purchase price directly to parent company and not seller, and that parent company perpetrated a wrong or injustice against purchaser, thus warranting intervention by a court of equity, through its domination of seller, misrepresentation of value of assets sold, and causing seller to become judgment proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Purchaser stated a breach of contract claim against seller's parent company, based upon an alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Radiancy, Inc. v. Viatek Consumer Products Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Claims that a skincare products manufacturer was completely controlled by its parent company, that both entities shared the same chief executive officer (CEO), and that parent company was the real owner of patents asserted by manufacturer as infringed, failed to allege that parent company was the alter ego of manufacturer, as required to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent company liable for any harms committed by manufacturer under Delaware law.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Declaratory Judgment. District Court lacked authority to issue declaratory judgment on validity or infringement of a patent, in absence of a patent controversy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Las Vegas Sands Corp. v. Ace Gaming, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, parent company did not exhibit corporate dominance over its subsidiary, a licensee of trademark for hotel, and thus, piercing of licensee's corporate veil to hold parent company liable for licensee's purported breach of licensing agreement was not appropriate; there was no evidence that subsidiary was undercapitalized when it was formed, or evidence as to level of capitalization required to operate casino and hotel such as one in Atlantic City, New Jersey, such that court could come to any conclusion as to adequacy or inadequacy of subsidiary's capitalization, there was not requisite day-to-day involvement of parent company's directors or officers in subsidiary's operations, and funds of parent company and subsidiary were not commingled.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Licensor had authority to terminate licensing agreement when licensee shut down hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Las Vegas Sands Corp. v. Ace Gaming, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, parent company did not abuse privilege of incorporation by using its subsidiary, a licensee of trademark for hotel, to perpetuate fraud or injustice, and thus, piercing of licensee's corporate veil to hold parent company liable for licensee's purported breach of licensing agreement was not appropriate; even if subsidiary lacked sufficient funds to pay any judgment, there was no evidence that subsidiary's financial state resulted from abuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Licensor had authority to terminate licensing agreement when licensee shut down hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Las Vegas Sands Corp. v. Ace Gaming, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, subsidiary, a licensee of trademark for hotel, was not acting as its parent company's agent when it signed licensing agreement with licensor, absent evidence that parent company agreed to have subsidiary act on its behalf when subsidiary entered into agreement.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Marks and Logos. Licensor had authority to terminate licensing agreement when licensee shut down hotel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: TIP Systems, LLC v. SBC Operations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil of holding company so as to hold it liable for allegedly infringing acts committed by its subsidiary was not warranted, absent showing that finances, record-keeping, and daily operations of the two corporations were not kept separate, that subsidiary's business came only from holding company, that subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital, that holding company used subsidiary's property as its own, or that holding company totally dominated and controlled subsidiary so that it was operated as holding company's business conduit or agent. 35 U.S.C.A. § 271(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of parent so as to hold it liable for allegedly infringing acts of subsidiary was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Smith v. NBC Universal
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil had to be pierced in order to hold corporate parent liable under California law for activities of its partly owned subsidiary, where subsidiary admitted that it was responsible for copyright violation and parent did not have direct relationship with violator.
Document Preview: TORTS - Publicity. Commercial value of publication containing orca attack on victim was not enhanced by victim's likeness or identity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Iridex Corp. v. Synergetics USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be pierced, under Missouri law, to allow for patent infringement action against parent of subsidiary allegedly violating patent for fiber optic connector system used with medical lasers; parent was not even formed until one month before suit, when it was created as part of reverse triangular merger, parent had legitimate business purpose of running acquired company, and subsidiary had not been drained of resources to pay any damages that might result from infringement suit.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Big East Entertainment, Inc. v. Zomba Enterprises, Inc
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Record distribution corporation, as parent company, could not pierce the corporate veil to advance copyright infringements claims of its subsidiaries, under New York law, based on shareholder's personal ownership of parent and subsidiaries.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Limitations. Record distribution corporation's copyright ownership and infringement claims were time-barred.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1076 Patent, copyright, and trademark ownership and infringement >
Title: Jacobs Vehicle Systems, Inc. v. Pacific Diesel Brake Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, engine brake manufacturer's parent company did not so dominate manufacturer as to warrant piercing corporate veil in connection with patent infringement claim against manufacturer, even though manufacturer's president regularly reported to parent's board of directors, where parent did not control manufacturer's day-to-day operations, manufacturer was adequately capitalized, and there was no evidence that parent was hiding behind manufacturer in order to perpetuate fraud or other wrong.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Transportation. Parent did not so dominate manufacturer as to warrant piercing corporate veil in connection with patent infringement claim.

Title: Mobil Oil Corp. v. Linear Films, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporation, all of stock of which was held by its parent, certain debts of which were guaranteed by the parent, which shared common offices and directors with parent, for which no separate minutes were kept nor agendas prepared for board of directors' meetings, and which continued to use parent's name on its advertising and stationery even after its name was changed to distinguish it from the parent, was not "alter ego" of the parent for purposes of holding parent liable for subsidiary's alleged patent infringement in absence of any showing of fraud or injustice.

Headnote: Even if parent received indirect, unjust profit from its ownership of subsidiary, that was not enough to meet requirement so as to pierce corporate veil and render parent liable for alleged patent infringement of subsidiary that parent used separate corporate existence of subsidiary to perpetrate frauds.

Title: D.L. Auld Co. v. Park Electrochemical Corp.

Headnote: Fact that one corporation owned all of the shares of subsidiary, had directors and officers in common with it, financed operations of subsidiary, and paid salary of its president was not sufficient to warrant disregarding corporate entity of subsidiary in patent action as there is no showing that subsidiary had gross inadequate capital, that it had no business except with the parent, or that formal legal requirements of subsidiary were not observed.

Title: Franks v. Markson
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Where three corporate plaintiffs sought to enjoin violation of contract made by plaintiffs and defendants with respect to use of plaintiffs' trade-name "Jim Clinton", even assuming one of defendants, which was a Maine corporation, owned and controlled a number of "Bill Benton" corporations which name allegedly was similar to trade name of "Jim Clinton", fact of ownership would not, standing alone, empower court to enter a decree against the Maine corporation which would bind the subsidiaries, since such ownership and control did not merge the corporations into one or make either the agent of the other.

Title: Culbertson v. Kem Playing Cards
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In action to recover royalties under contract relating to manufacture and sale of playing cards, partial defense that defendant corporation had granted sole and exclusive license to manufacture such cards to another corporation would be insufficient if it was found that such other corporation was either a subsidiary or assignee, but would be good if it was determined that such other corporation was a true licensee whose corporate entity could not be pierced.

Headnote: In patent infringement suit by assignee against assignor's subsidiary corporation, defendant's separate corporate status would be disregarded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1077 Wills and decedents' estates >
Title: Garza v. Citigroup Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Global holding company's implementation and generally overseeing compliance and risk management policies in its subsidiaries to prevent money laundering did not establish fiduciary relationship under New York law between holding company and bank account-holder of its Mexican subsidiary, as required to pierce corporate veil for accounting claim by executor of estate of account-holder, since general supervision did not provide holding company with direct control over deposits of subsidiary's account-holders. 12 U.S.C.A. § 4001 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fiduciary relationship did not exist between parent corporation and its subsidiary bank's account-holder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Philip Morris USA, Inc. v. Rintoul
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Tobacco company, its parent company, and e-cigarette company were distinct corporate entities, and, thus, evidence of e-cigarette company's marketing statements and parent company's purchase of minority interest in e-cigarette manufacturer was inadmissible as irrelevant to whether tobacco company engaged in continued misconduct, as basis for imposing punitive damages in wrongful death action that smoker's estate asserted against tobacco company, absent evidence that could support piercing corporate veils between tobacco company and other entities, particularly given that tobacco company's corporate parent, a nonparty, was not also e-cigarette company's corporate parent.
Document Preview: GLBT  Torts. Husband could not recover loss-of-consortium damages for premarital injury to smoker, notwithstanding unconstitutionality of same-sex marriage ban.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary bank was not financially dependent on its parent, weighing in favor of finding that subsidiary was not a mere department of its parent, as would render service of a subpoena on the subsidiary effective against parent; subsidiary paid its own business expenses, including the salaries of all of its personnel, without assistance from parent, it did not borrow money from parent, and it did not receive funds for its own account from parent. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 45, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Service of subpoena on American subsidiary of Israeli bank was not effective against parent bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary bank typically appointed its executive level personnel without consulting its parent, weighing in favor of finding that subsidiary was not a mere department of parent, as would render service of a subpoena on the subsidiary effective against parent, even though parent recommended a candidate for subsidiary's Chief Executive Officer (CEO) who was ultimately selected for the position and even though three of subsidiary's twelve-member board were directors or officers of parent; board members from parent were not also executives of employees of subsidiary. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 45, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Service of subpoena on American subsidiary of Israeli bank was not effective against parent bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary observed corporate formalities, weighing in favor of finding that it was not a mere department of its parent, as would render service of a subpoena on the subsidiary effective against parent; subsidiary had its own board of directors, which held regular meetings, it held annual shareholder meetings, and it maintained separate books and records from its parent and prepared its own financial statements. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 45, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Service of subpoena on American subsidiary of Israeli bank was not effective against parent bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Israeli bank did not exert control over its American subsidiary's marketing and operational policies, weighing in favor of finding that subsidiary was not a mere department of its parent, as would render service of a subpoena on the subsidiary effective against parent; subsidiary ran its own day-to-day operations, determined marketing and operational policies without interference by parent, and hired, trained, and paid its own employees, and the two entities had separate computer and phone systems and maintained separate customer records and accounts. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 45, 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Service of subpoena on American subsidiary of Israeli bank was not effective against parent bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Cessna Aircraft Co. v. Avior Technologies, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Owner of aircraft and its subsidiary were both bound by terms of service contract, to which the subsidiary was party and which the subsidiary signed as agent of the owner, such that owner, as well as the subsidiary, was bound by the limitation of damages provision in the service contract; the subsidiary, as agent, lost separate standing to sue on its own behalf when the owner brought an action in its own name, and subsidiary alleged in its pleadings that it had assigned all of its right to the aircraft's owner. West's F.S.A. § 672.719.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic loss rule barred tort claims for damages for matters arising from service contract for aircraft repair.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(1) In general >
Title: Hall v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2, Department A.
Headnote: Application of judicial privilege to letter written by former employee to employer's parent company during course of wrongful termination suit in which she accused executive director of diverting corporate funds for personal use did not constitute improper piercing of parent company's corporate veil, in context of executive director's counter-claim for defamation; parent company's liability, or that of its shareholders, was not at issue.
Document Preview: TORTS - Privileges. Employee's letter to parent company during course of wrongful termination suit containing defamatory statements was entitled to judicial privilege.

Title: Niver v. Travelers Indem. Co. of IL
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, insured made prima facie showing that piercing corporate veil was appropriate in his bad faith action against insurer, and thus insured was entitled to discover and to present to jury financial information about insurer's parent for purposes of jury's determination of punitive damages, in light of allegation that parent had eighty-seven subsidiaries, money flowed freely between corporations, with dividends paid by subsidiaries to their parent corporation, and pooling of capital and surpluses of various subsidiaries, subsidiaries all had same home office address and same officers, directors, and actuary, each subsidiary was wholly-owned by parent, used same claims manual, and used same incentive program, only parent provided benefit retirement plans, and only parent filed federal income tax return, which included all subsidiaries. I.C.A. § 668A.1(3).
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Insured seeking punitive damages could discover and present to jury financial information about insurer's parent.

Title: Norex Petroleum Ltd. v. Chubb Ins. Co. of Canada
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Statute governing court discovery assistance in aid of foreign proceedings did not authorize order compelling United States nonparty subsidiary to produce documents held by European parent corporation, for use in Canadian litigation; there was no showing that Canadian courts needed or wanted American court assistance, and there was no basis for piercing of corporate veil to secure possession of documents held by parent. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1782.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Statute did not authorize discovery order involving documents outside of country.

Title: Cahaly v. Benistar Property Exchange Trust Co., Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Business's client who applied for prejudgment remedy of attachment against business, business's parent corporation, and chairman of business and parent corporation was entitled to subject assets of parent corporation and chairman to prejudgment remedy of attachment, even though client had entered into contract with business, since there was probable cause to believe that client could pierce corporate veil of business. C.G.S.A. § 52-278a et seq.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Plaintiff could pursue prejudgment attachment while awaiting final judgment in another state.

Title: Strom v. American Honda Motor Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Barnstable.
Headnote: Motorcycle distributor had sufficient control over documents possessed by its parent corporation, sister research and development corporation, and subsidiary corporation which was manufacturer of motorcycle and could be compelled to produce documents in connection with products liability action brought by injured rider of motorcycle; doctrine of corporate disregard did not preclude discovery, as that doctrine relates to quite distinct issue of whether liability of one corporate entity should be visited upon related entity. Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 34, 43A M.G.L.A.
Document Preview: Discovery. Motorcycle distributor had control over and could be compelled to produce documents held by parent, sister, and subsidiary corporations.

Title: Strom v. American Honda Motor Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Barnstable.
Headnote: Doctrine of corporate disregard relates not to whether documents in possession of parent or subsidiary of litigating corporation may be discovered from corporation, but to distinct issue of whether effects of liability on one corporate entity should be visited on related entity.
Document Preview: Discovery. Motorcycle distributor had control over and could be compelled to produce documents held by parent, sister, and subsidiary corporations.

Title: In re Uranium Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Test for determining whether an American court can order an American parent corporation to produce the documents of its foreign subsidiary is this: if a corporation has power, either directly or indirectly, through another corporation or a series of corporations, to elect a majority of the directors of another corporation, such corporation may be deemed a parent corporation and in control of the corporation whose directors it has the power to elect to office.

Title: In re Uranium Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In antitrust suit alleging the existence of an international marketing arrangement among uranium producers, United States corporation, which has or once had control over its directors, officers and employees who managed the uranium-related activities of that corporation alone or of both it and its Canadian parent, had to produce all responsive documents held by those employees or former employees, even if those documents had found their way into the Canadian parent's files; the formality separating the two corporations could not be used as a screen to disguise the coordinated nature of their uranium enterprise.

Title: U.S. v. Reserve Min. Co.

Title: Caston v. F. Hoffmann-La Roche, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Generally, sister-sister or parent-subsidiary relationships are insufficient to establish personal jurisdiction based on imputing one entity's minimum contacts with a forum to the other entity under an alter ego theory.

Title: PSFS 3 Corporation v. Michael P. Seidman, D.D.S., P.C.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: Assignment of finance agreements with doctors and dentists from finance company, whose principal place of business was in Iowa, to its wholly owned subsidiary which allowed subsidiary to invoke floating forum-selection clause in finance agreements, in which the parties agreed that the local courts where headquarters of assignee were located would have jurisdiction over disputes, was not a sham for purposes of subsidiary's action against doctors and dentists to enforce finance agreements related to purchase from third-party vendor of multimedia systems for their waiting rooms; the assignment was a transparent transaction with the limited purpose of creating optimal enforcement mechanism with respect to the finance agreements, and the pierce the corporate veil doctrine was not well designed for this context because question was not one of remedy where the corporate structure had been abused, but one of compliance with express contractual term that established personal jurisdiction in the courts of the state where the corporate headquarters of assignee was located.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignment of finance agreements from company to its subsidiary which allowed subsidiary to invoke forum-selection clause was not a sham.

Title: Miami Products & Chemical Co. v. Olin Corporation

Headnote: In considering whether subsidiary is parent corporation's alter-ego for jurisdictional purposes, court considers failure to observe corporate formality, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of personal and corporate funds, sharing of common office space, address and telephone numbers of alleged dominating entity and subject corporation, overlap of ownership, directors, officers or personnel, use of corporation as means to perpetrate wrongful act against plaintiff, and any other evidence tending to show that company is being used as mere shell.

Headnote: To determine if an alter ego relationship between corporations is established, permitting exercise of personal jurisdiction over the parent corporation, the court must consider whether: (1) distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are incorporated and maintained; (2) daily operations of the two corporations are separate; (3) formal barriers between management of the two entities are erected, with each functioning in its own best interests; and (4) those with whom the corporations come in contact are apprised of their separate identity.

Title: TMX Finance Holdings, Inc. v. Wellshire Financial Services, LLC

Title: TMX Finance Holdings, Inc. v. Wellshire Financial Services, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Plaintiff asserting that a parent corporation is an alter ego of its subsidiary must show a plus factor beyond the subsidiary's mere presence within the bosom of the corporate family; it is this plus factor that converts, for jurisdictional purposes, the typical parent-subsidiary relationship-which involves common ownership, monitoring, reporting, and articulating of general policies-into an alter-ego relationship.

Headnote: Reports from a subsidiary to a parent that allow a parent to monitor its operations are insufficient to treat two separate entities as one entity for jurisdictional purposes.

Title: Griffith v. SSC Pueblo Belmont Operating Company LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado.
Headnote: To exercise personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent company based on the activities of its resident subsidiary, a trial court shall determine whether it may pierce the corporate veil and impute the resident subsidiary's contacts to the nonresident parent company, and if the resident subsidiary's contacts may be imputed to the nonresident parent company, the court shall analyze all of the nonresident company's contacts with Colorado, including the resident subsidiary's contacts, to determine whether exercising either general or specific personal jurisdiction over the company comports with due process, but if the trial court concludes that it may not pierce the corporate veil, it shall treat each entity separately and analyze only the contacts that each parent company has with the state when performing the personal jurisdiction analysis. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Residential Facilities. Trial court's analysis of personal jurisdiction over nursing home operators was inadequate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: In re Lyondell Chemical Company
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts will pierce the corporate veil in reverse and exercise personal jurisdiction over a subsidiary based on its jurisdiction over the parent company when the subsidiary is an alter ego or mere department of the parent company.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Jurisdiction. Creditors' trust in Chapter 11 case failed to establish that subsidiary was subject to personal jurisdiction as alter ego of parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Clockwork IP, LLC v. Clearview Plumbing & Heating Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Canadian plumbing company's related entity, an intellectual property holding company incorporated in Canada, was not subject to personal jurisdiction in Missouri in Missouri-based residential plumbing provider's action alleging trademark infringement and other violations of the Lanham Act against Canadian plumbing company; even if related entity was plumbing company's alter ego such that acts of plumbing company could be attributable to its related entity, the lack of personal jurisdiction over plumbing company as related entity's alleged parent precluded exercise of personal jurisdiction over related entity. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Lanham Act, §§ 32, 43(a), 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 1114, 1125(a); V.A.M.S. § 506.500(1)(1–3).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Exercise of personal jurisdiction over Canadian plumbing company would have offended traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.

Title: Warad West, LLC v. Sorin CRM USA Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Where a subsidiary may be said to be doing the business of the parent company in a particular state, the parent company may be subject to personal jurisdiction in that state.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Sales representative failed to state prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over Italian parent companies under an alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Warad West, LLC v. Sorin CRM USA Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: On a motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the truly relevant inquiry into whether a plaintiff has made a prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction under an alter ego theory is into facts concerning the amount of control exercised by the corporate parent over its subsidiary. Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Sales representative failed to state prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over Italian parent companies under an alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Warad West, LLC v. Sorin CRM USA Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Claims that Italian parent companies directly or indirectly owned subsidiaries in the United States, that Italian parent companies shared common directors with subsidiaries, that several of Italian parent companies' subsidiaries were headquartered in the same location, and that subsidiaries were grossly undercapitalized, failed to state a prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over the Italian companies under an alter ego theory, where former employee of one subsidiary stated in an affidavit that Italian parent companies disregarded and neglected, rather than controlled and micromanaged subsidiaries. Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Sales representative failed to state prima facie case of personal jurisdiction over Italian parent companies under an alter ego theory.

Title: Cornerstone Healthcare Group Holding, Inc. v. Reliant Splitter, L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: To join a parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiff must prove that the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Owners of parent company that owned Texas business did not purposefully avail themselves of privilege of conducting activities in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Cornerstone Healthcare Group Holding, Inc. v. Reliant Splitter, L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: To join a parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the degree of control exercised by the parent must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Owners of parent company that owned Texas business did not purposefully avail themselves of privilege of conducting activities in Texas.

Title: Cornerstone Healthcare Group Holding, Inc. v. Reliant Splitter, L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: To join a parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, plaintiff must present evidence showing that the two entities are not separate and the corporate veil, therefore, should be pierced to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Owners of parent company that owned Texas business did not purposefully avail themselves of privilege of conducting activities in Texas.

Title: S.E.C. v. Life Partners Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Although Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) suit named only parent company, and not subsidiary which allegedly violated securities laws in its sale of viatical life settlements, court had jurisdiction to hear case, since there was no meaningful difference between the companies.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Viatical life settlements are investment contracts constituting securities subject to federal regulation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: KM Enterprises, Inc. v. Global Traffic Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under theory of waiver, Southern District of Illinois was not proper venue for Clayton Antitrust Act suit initiated against competitor and its subsidiary by manufacturer of devices to permit emergency vehicles to preempt ordinary traffic lights; although competitor's subsidiary conceded that it was subject to personal jurisdiction in State of Illinois, it strongly contested venue in Southern District of Illinois, arguing that its contacts with that district were too minimal to support venue, and, even if subsidiary had waived venue in that district, nothing about relationship between subsidiary and competitor suggested abnormal level of involvement or control so as to warrant piercing corporation veil to exercise jurisdiction over competitor based on subsidiary's activities. Clayton Act, § 12, 15 U.S.C.A. § 22; 28 U.S.C.A. § 1391(d).
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Venue. Two clauses of Clayton Act's venue provision had to be read together, rather than independently from each other.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: KM Enterprises, Inc. v. Global Traffic Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Activities of a subsidiary may suffice to assert jurisdiction over the parent if there is some basis for piercing the corporate veil, such as the parent's unusual degree of control over the subsidiary, but this does not apply in the case of an ordinary parent-subsidiary relationship that observes corporate formalities.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Venue. Two clauses of Clayton Act's venue provision had to be read together, rather than independently from each other.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: In re BPZ Resources, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Peruvian corporation which owned oil production platform would be treated as a separate legal entity despite allegations that Texas parent corporations were owner's alter ego, on motion to dismiss based on forum non conveniens made by parent corporations in negligence action brought by crewmembers and families of crewmembers who were injured or killed in explosion of oil tanker, absent evidence that would justify piercing Peruvian owner's corporate veil or treating it as the alter ego of the Texas parent corporations.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Removal. Peru rather than Texas was a more convenient forum to litigate action arising out of explosion at Peruvian oil platform.

Title: In re Cyclobenzaprine Hydrochloride Extended-Release Capsule Patent Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, parent's contacts with state were attributable to subsidiary, for purposes of determining whether subsidiary was subject to personal jurisdiction in state in patent infringement action, where both entities shared same address and some of same employees. 10 West's Del.C. § 3104.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Drugs. Generic manufacturer's parent was not liable for patent infringement based on its subsidiary's submission of ANDA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Spir Star AG v. Kimich
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: To fuse two corporations for jurisdictional purposes, a parent must control the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary to an extent beyond its role as an investor.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. German manufacturer of high-pressure hoses sold through Texas distributor was subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Helm v. Alderwoods Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: A parent company can be held liable for its subsidiary, and the local subsidiary's contacts with the forum may be imputed to the parent corporation, if the parent and subsidiary are not really separate entities, or one acts as the general agent of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Court had personal jurisdiction over non-resident parent company based on actions of local subsidiaries.

Title: Freres v. SPI Pharma, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Delaware law to reach a parent corporation under the alter ego theory, the party asserting jurisdiction must establish some fraud, injustice, or inequity in the use of the corporate form.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Jurisdiction. Tolling manufacturing agreement did not subject British manufacturers to personal jurisdiction in Delaware.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Cephalon, Inc. v. Watson Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware long-arm statute's agency theory of personal jurisdiction, the court may attribute the actions of a subsidiary company to its parent where the subsidiary acts on the parent's behalf or at the parent's direction; this theory does not treat the parent and subsidiary as one entity, but rather attributes specific acts to the parent because of the parent's authorization of those acts. 10 West's Del.C. § 3104(c).
Document Preview: PATENTS - Drugs. Patentee stated claim against drug manufacturer and subsidiary that prepared ANDA for generic drug.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Cephalon, Inc. v. Watson Pharmaceuticals, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware long-arm statute, the agency theory of personal jurisdiction may be applied not only to parents and subsidiaries, but also to companies that are two arms of the same business group, operate in concert with each other, and enter into agreements with each other that are nearer than arm's length. 10 West's Del.C. § 3104(c).
Document Preview: PATENTS - Drugs. Patentee stated claim against drug manufacturer and subsidiary that prepared ANDA for generic drug.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The applicability of alter ego jurisdiction depends upon whether (1) the parent owns all or a significant majority of the subsidiary's stock, (2) commonality of officers or directors exists between the two corporations, (3) the corporate family possesses a unified marketing image, including common branding of products, (4) corporate insignias, trademarks, and logos are uniform across corporate boundaries, (5) corporate family members share employees, (6) the parent has integrated its sales and distribution systems with those of its subsidiaries, (7) the corporations exchange or share managerial or supervisory personnel, (8) the subsidiary performs business functions that would ordinarily be handled by a parent corporation, (9) the parent uses the subsidiary as a marketing division or as an exclusive distributor, and (10) the parent exercises control or provides instruction to the subsidiary's officers and directors.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Jurisdiction. Plaintiffs failed to establish prima facie showing of purposeful availment jurisdiction over foreign chocolate manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: In re Western States Wholesale Natural Gas Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Parent corporation of energy companies could not be haled to court on the ground that its subsidiaries were its alter ego. The parent corporation had never been qualified to conduct business in the state. The parent indirectly wholly owned both subsidiaries. The companies did not share offices and had only one overlapping officer or director. The parent did not make financial guarantees on the subsidiaries behalf. The companies maintained separate books and records. The subsidiaries contracted for use of the service marks and corporate services. Any daily reporting of information to the parent was only in accord with its investor oversight role.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Parent corporation of energy companies could not be haled to court on the ground that its subsidiaries were its alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: In re American Intern. Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: There are situations when the separate legal existence of persons can be disregarded for personal jurisdiction purposes, such as when a subsidiary's veil is pierced because the subsidiary effectively has no substantial claim to call itself a person different from its parent, but veil piercing and other similar theories depend on the notion that the legal person present in Delaware is not in fact separate from the person over whom jurisdiction is asserted, and they are deemed one in the same usually on the notion that the subsidiary in Delaware is in fact the parent itself improperly cloaked in a different name.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Derivative Actions. Stockholders stated derivative claims against executives of large insurance company for fraudulent financial conduct.

Title: Tese-Milner v. De Beers Centenary A.G.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For New York courts to have jurisdiction over a parent corporation because of the activities of its subsidiary, pursuant to New York's general jurisdiction statute, the subsidiary must be either an agent or a department of the parent. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Plaintiff who made substantial start toward showing court had personal jurisdiction was entitled to jurisdictional discovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Tese-Milner v. De Beers Centenary A.G.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish that a subsidiary is an agent of its parent corporation, for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over the parent corporation under New York law, a plaintiff must show that the subsidiary does all the business which the parent corporation could do were it here by its own officials. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Plaintiff who made substantial start toward showing court had personal jurisdiction was entitled to jurisdictional discovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Tese-Milner v. De Beers Centenary A.G.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether one business entity is a department of another, for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction under New York general jurisdiction statute, a court must consider the following four factors: (1) common ownership; (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent corporation; (3) the degree to which the parent corporation interferes in the selection and assignment of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formalities; and (4) the degree of control the parent exercises over the marketing and operational policies of the subsidiary. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Plaintiff who made substantial start toward showing court had personal jurisdiction was entitled to jurisdictional discovery.

Title: Capital Technology Information Services, Inc. v. Arias & Arias Consultores
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: While a parent corporation's control of day-to-day operations of its subsidiary may be a fact that supports a finding of jurisdiction based on alter ego, the applicable legal analysis to determine jurisdiction based on alter ego theory is whether the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary to the extent the two companies become "fused" and cease to be separate for jurisdictional purposes; overruling Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P., 141 S.W.3d 870. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Personal jurisdiction could be exercised over wholly-owned subsidiary fused with its parent corporation.

Title: In re Genetically Modified Rice Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Where a subsidiary's affairs are so conducted that it is in fact a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation, jurisdiction over the parent may be proper.

Title: PHC-Minden, L.P. v. Kimberly-Clark Corp.

Headnote: Appropriate parental involvement by a parent company over its subsidiary, for the purposes of exercising jurisdiction over the subsidiary, includes monitoring the subsidiary's performance, supervision of the subsidiary's finance and capital budget decisions, and articulation of general policies.

Title: First Horizon Merchant Services, Inc. v. Wellspring Capital Management, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. II.
Headnote: For purposes of personal jurisdiction, agency and alter ego, while different legal concepts, often depend on the same facts when parent and subsidiary corporations are involved.

Title: First Horizon Merchant Services, Inc. v. Wellspring Capital Management, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. II.
Headnote: Facts concerning the amount of control exercised by the corporate parent over its subsidiary are relevant for both the theory of agency and the theory of alter ego, when determining whether a court has personal jurisdiction over the parent.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Letters, telephone call and presentation were sufficient contacts to subject bankrupt's CEO to personal jurisdiction.

Title: First Horizon Merchant Services, Inc. v. Wellspring Capital Management, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. II.
Headnote: The control of a corporate parent over a subsidiary could be evidence that the subsidiary is the parent's alter ego, when determining whether a court has personal jurisdiction over the parent, because the subsidiary has no real separate corporate existence.

Title: U.S. Gypsum Co. v. LaFarge North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Personal jurisdiction may be exercised over a corporate parent under Illinois law in situations where the corporate veil can be pierced.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Trade Secrets. Use of ice to clean slurry mixers was not trade secret under Illinois Trade Secrets Act (ITSA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Cai v. DaimlerChrysler AG
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Nonresident parent's interaction with subsidiary does not result in subsidiary's forum having general jurisdiction over parent unless those interactions are sufficient to meet alter ego or general agency tests for jurisdiction.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. German employer was not subject to specific personal jurisdiction in Oregon in former employee's breach of contract suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Gadea v. Star Cruises, Ltd.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Only where a parent corporation exerts such extensive operational control over a subsidiary that the subsidiary is no more than an agent existing to serve only the parent's needs does jurisdiction over the parent based on the activity of the subsidiary exist; sharing some officers and directors, having a unified or global strategy and goals, cross-selling in promotional materials, and performing services for one another is not sufficient to satisfy this test. West's F.S.A. § 48.193(2).
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Business activity by cruise ship owner's subsidiary did not subject owner to general jurisdiction.

Title: Cappuccitti v. Gulf Indus. Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To join the parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiff must prove that the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary.

Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To join the parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the degree of control exercised by the parent must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship.

Title: Cappuccitti v. Gulf Indus. Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To join the parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiff must present evidence showing that the two entities are not separate and the corporate veil, therefore, should be pierced to prevent fraud or injustice.

Title: LinkAmerica Corp. v. Cox
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Common corporate infrastructure such as information technology and accounting services do not place the parent in the subsidiary's shoes whenever the subsidiary conducts business for purposes of asserting personal jurisdiction over parent; supplying necessary financing to the subsidiary is in the same category.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Analysis of personal jurisdiction turned on whether exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with constitution.

Title: Ruiz v. Bally Total Fitness Holding Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Court's assertion of personal jurisdiction over wholly owned subsidiary does not automatically establish jurisdiction over that subsidiary's parent.

Title: HomeBingo Network, Inc. v. Chayevsky
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Venue may properly be laid with regard to individual stockholders who are alter egos of the corporation by virtue of the corporation's acts where venue would be proper as to a corporate parent or affiliate.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Venue. Venue over individual defendants was not proper on basis on infringing devices in district.

Title: Commonwealth General Corp. v. York
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: In order to fuse the parent company and its subsidiary for purposes of personal jurisdiction, it must be proved that the parent is the alter ego of the subsidiary; the parent must be shown to control the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary to the extent that the two entities effectively cease to be separate.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Jurisdiction. Exercising specific personal jurisdiction over buyer of life insurer's stock did not comply with due process.

Title: Amstell Holding, Inc. v. SIG Combibloc, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Jurisdiction existed over a parent company as the suing corporation demonstrated that but for the parent company's approval the corporation would not have been harmed. The corporation demonstrated that the parent company's executives were directly involved in the transaction that lead to its harm. Further, the parent company was subject to an agency relationship with its subsidiary as the corporation demonstrated that it engaged in a relationship similar to a principal/agent relationship. M.G.L.A. c. 223A, § 3.
