Title: I & JC Corp. v. Helen of Troy L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: To "fuse" parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, plaintiffs must prove the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary; however, the degree of control the parent exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship, and the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Defendant companies were alter egos of the other, thereby imputing tortious conduct to the other for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: In re Lernout & Hauspie Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: For purposes of determining alter ego status for personal jurisdictional purposes, factors that demonstrate whether corporate formalities have been observed include whether the parent corporation and its subsidiary were separately incorporated, had separate boards of directors, maintained separate financial records, and had separate facilities and operating personnel.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Fund's subsidiary was the agent of fund for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: When a claimant seeks to fuse parent and subsidiary companies for jurisdictional purposes, the degree of control the parent exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud and injustice. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Reers v. Deutsche Bahn AG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors to aid in determining whether one entity is the mere department of another for jurisdictional purposes are: (1) common ownership; (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent; (3) the degree to which the parent interferes in the selection of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formalities; and (4) the extent of the parent's control over the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Dismissal. Suit arising from train accident in France would be dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Reers v. Deutsche Bahn AG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A parent cannot assume the jurisdictional status of its subsidiary unless factors beyond common ownership suggest that their separate corporate identities are a mere facade.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Dismissal. Suit arising from train accident in France would be dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Reers v. Deutsche Bahn AG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of establishing that parent corporation assumed jurisdictional status of subsidiary based on theory that subsidiary is a "mere department" of parent, parent corporation's control over personnel decisions requires more than the parent's appointment of a few of the subsidiary's officers or directors.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Dismissal. Suit arising from train accident in France would be dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Zamarron v. Shinko Wire Company, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: An alter ego relationship between parent and subsidiary corporations is not established merely by showing one hundred percent stock ownership, commonality of officers and directors, and an exercise of control derived from stock ownership; rather, proof of control by the parent over the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary must be shown to fuse the two corporations for jurisdictional purposes.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked general or specific jurisdiction over Japanese corporation in tort action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Hitachi Shin Din Cable, Ltd. v. Cain
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: To fuse a parent company and its subsidiary for personal jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiffs must prove the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary, but the degree of control the parent exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendant's web site did not support court's exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: General jurisdiction over a parent corporation may exist in an action against a subsidiary when evidence establishes the parent and the subsidiary are alter egos; the party asserting alter ego liability must establish such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist and an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc. v. C & C Helicopter Sales, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory of jurisdiction, as followed in Delaware, corporate entities as between parent and subsidiary may be disregarded and the ultimate party in interest, the parent, be regarded in law and fact as the sole party in a particular transaction, in the interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, public wrong are involved, or where equitable consideration among members of the corporation require it.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court would defer to Canadian trademark infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: BMC Software Belgium, N.V. v. Marchand
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: To "fuse" the parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiffs must prove the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary, and the degree of control the parent exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary of Houston based corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: In determining whether parent and subsidiary corporations should be treated separately or joined for jurisdictional purposes, factors to consider are: (1) whether distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are incorporated and maintained, (2) whether daily operations of the corporations are separate, (3) whether formal barriers between the management of the entities are erected, with each functioning in its own best interest, (4) whether the corporations filed consolidated tax returns, (5) whether operating capital of the subsidiary is financed by the parent or borrowed from other sources, (6) whether the subsidiary's stock is owned by the parent, (7) whether the corporations share common officers and directors, (8) the extent to which separate books and accounts are kept, (9) whether the corporations have common departments of businesses, (10) whether the corporations have separate meetings of shareholders and directors, (11) whether an officer or director of one corporation is permitted to determine the policies of the other, (12) whether those who come in contact with the corporations are apprized of their separate identities, and (13) the extent to which contracts between the parent and subsidiary favor one over the other; it is not necessary that all factors be present or considered.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(2) Jurisdiction and venue in general >
Title: Sun Trust Bank v. Sun International Hotels, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Estate of minor child could not pierce corporate veil of Florida subsidiaries of foreign owners of hotel in Bahamas where minor was killed while snorkeling in lagoon to establish personal jurisdiction over owners in Florida in action arising out of minor's death; owners and subsidiaries carefully structured their corporate relationships and maintained their separate corporate existence.

Title: Baldwin v. Household Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Fusing a parent corporation and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes requires that a party prove that the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary.

Title: Dorsey v. J. Ray McDermott, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: When reviewing relevant the facts to determine foreign corporations primary place of business, so as to determine proper venue, courts must not impute the principal place of business of a parent corporation to its subsidiary, or impute the principal place of business of a subsidiary to a parent; only time that this rule does not apply is if the subsidiary is the alter ego of the parent, or vice versa.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Venue. Parish in which foreign corporation conducted majority of its activities was corporation's de facto primary place of business.

Title: C.R. Bard, Inc. v. Guidant Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under "alter ego" theory, for establishing specific personal jurisdiction under Delaware long arm statute, court may attribute actions of subsidiary to its parent and ignore corporate boundaries if court finds that subsidiary is mere alter ego of parent. 10 Del.C. § 3104(c)(1).

Title: C.R. Bard, Inc. v. Guidant Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to establish specific personal jurisdiction over parent corporation, under alter ego theory contained in Delaware long arm statute, party asserting jurisdiction must establish some fraud, injustice, or inequity in use of corporate form. 10 Del.C. § 3104(c)(1).

Title: C.R. Bard, Inc. v. Guidant Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under "agency theory," for establishing specific personal jurisdiction over parent corporation under Delaware long arm statute due to transaction of business in state, in person or through agent, court may attribute actions of corporate subsidiary to parent when subsidiary acts on parent's behalf or at parent's direction. 10 Del.C. § 3104(c)(1).

Title: Conner v. ContiCarriers and Terminals, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In determining whether to "fuse" parent company and its subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, court considers whether distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are incorporated and maintained; whether daily operations of the two corporations are separate; whether formal barriers between management of two entities are erected, with each functioning in its own best interest; whether those with whom corporation come into contact are apprised of their separate identity; whether subsidiary files income tax return separate from consolidated return filed by parent; common stock ownership; method and degree of financing of subsidiary by parent; common directors and officers; separate books and accounts; common business departments; extent to which contracts between parent and subsidiary favor one over the other; and connection of parent's employee, officer or director to subsidiary's tort or contract giving rise to suit. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: CIVIL PROCEDURE - Jurisdiction. Barge operator did not have continuous and systematic contacts necessary to maintain general personal jurisdiction.

Title: Conner v. ContiCarriers and Terminals, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Barge operator's parent corporation did not disregard corporate formalities or exercise such control and dominance over subsidiary as to make alter-ego jurisdiction proper in action brought by injured crew member; although subsidiary received its initial capital from parent, corporations shared office headquarters and had common directors, and approximately 50% of subsidiary's revenue came from providing shipping services to parent, companies maintained their own books, and debits or credits to their shared account were charged separately to each company through "intercompany" accounting system, subsidiary separately owned or leased equipment and property, subsidiary entered into separate contracts, maintained separate bank accounts, and separately held title to property, and both companies filed separate tax returns. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: CIVIL PROCEDURE - Jurisdiction. Barge operator did not have continuous and systematic contacts necessary to maintain general personal jurisdiction.

Title: Jemez Agency, Inc. v. CIGNA Corp.

Headnote: Generally, judicial jurisdiction over subsidiary corporation does not of itself give state judicial jurisdiction over parent corporation, even if parent owns all of the subsidiary's stock. Restatement (Second) of Conflicts of Law § 52 comment.

Title: Jemez Agency, Inc. v. CIGNA Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, subsidiary insurance companies were not alter egos of their ultimate parent company, as would allow exercise of jurisdiction over parent on theory that ultimate parent transacted business and committed torts through subsidiaries in terminating marketing program; even though subsidiaries conducted business as one entity and ultimate parent provided extensive financing to the group and prepared consolidated financial statements and annual reports, and even though employees of parent and ultimate parent shared common payroll system, and subsidiaries were entities separate and distinct from ultimate parent and there was no evidence of improper or fraudulent purpose for incorporation. Title: Stambaugh v. International Harvester Co.

Title: Amarillo Oil Co. v. Mapco, Inc.

Title: Bellomo v. Pennsylvania Life Co.

Title: Cox v. CoinMarketCap OPCO, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Imputation of a subsidiary's minimum contacts with a forum to a parent company, for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over the parent company, requires satisfaction of the "alter ego" test, which obligates a party to make out a prima facie case (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two entities no longer exist and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.

Title: Franks v. Coopersurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Parent company of distributor of surgical clips was not "alter ego" of distributor, and, thus, district court could not exercise specific personal jurisdiction over parent company, in patient's action for consumer protection and products liability arising from injury that patient allegedly sustained from migration of clips, although parent company and distributor shared several employees in leadership roles, and there was evidence of collaboration between entities; there was no indicia of fraud, wrongdoing, domination, misuse, or subversion of corporate familiarities for court to pierce corporate veil, and shared directors, officers, and employees, shared press releases, and collective regulator filings did not warrant piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's products liability claim on theory of design defect was preempted by Medical Device Amendments of Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

Title: Ryan v. Greif, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under the common-law presumption that a separately incorporated subsidiary is institutionally independent of its parent, personal jurisdiction cannot therefore be asserted over a corporate parent based solely on the conduct of the subsidiary.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, United States-based subsidiary of foreign parent company was not parent's alter ego, as would allow piercing of corporate veil to attribute subsidiary's contacts in forum state to parent for determination of whether specific personal jurisdiction existed over parent, in action by judgment creditor of subsidiary, seeking to recover from parent an unpaid judgment against subsidiary arising from breach of contract for sale of livestock feed; parent did not control and dominate affairs of subsidiary.

Title: HDT Bio Corp. v. Emcure Pharmaceuticals, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: For an agency relationship to exist between a parent company and a subsidiary for purposes of personal jurisdiction, the parent must have moved beyond the establishment of general policy and direction for the subsidiary and must have, in effect, taken over performances of the subsidiary's day-to-day operations in carrying out that policy.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction did not exist over Indian pharmaceutical company in trade-secret-misappropriation suit over technology for COVID-19 vaccine.

Title: Arnold v. CooperSurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Patient failed to show that medical company's nonresident parent corporation was alter ego of company so as to subject parent corporation to personal jurisdiction in Ohio, in patient's products liability action seeking damages for injuries sustained from migration of device implanted during her tubal ligation, though patient alleged that company and parent corporation had overlap in officers that held leadership roles with each company at the same time, that parent's officers and employees had involvement in company's activities, and that parent issued multiple press releases regarding acquisitions beneficial to company; patient failed to allege that parent corporation had disregarded corporate formalities or that company was financially independent on parent corporation. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's design defect claim under Ohio law against medical device companies was impliedly preempted by Medical Device Amendments (MDA) to FDCA.

Title: Arnold v. CooperSurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In the parent-subsidiary context, the alter-ego doctrine holds that a non-resident parent corporation is amenable to suit in the forum state if the parent company exerts so much control over the subsidiary that the two do not exist as separate entities but are one and the same for purposes of jurisdiction; alter-ego theory is akin to piercing the corporate veil of a parent corporation, and such veil piercing occurs only in extraordinary cases.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's design defect claim under Ohio law against medical device companies was impliedly preempted by Medical Device Amendments (MDA) to FDCA.

Title: Arnold v. CooperSurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary is an alter ego of the parent corporation, for purposes of determining personal jurisdiction, Ohio courts consider factors such as whether (1) corporate formalities are observed, (2) corporate records are kept, and (3) the corporation is financially independent.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's design defect claim under Ohio law against medical device companies was impliedly preempted by Medical Device Amendments (MDA) to FDCA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Arnold v. CooperSurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary is an alter ego of the parent corporation, for purposes of determining personal jurisdiction, Ohio courts consider additional factors such as: (1) sharing the same employees and corporate officers; (2) engaging in the same business enterprise; (3) having the same address and phone lines; (4) using the same assets; (5) completing the same jobs; (6) not maintaining separate books, tax returns and financial statements; and (7) exerting control over the daily affairs of another corporation.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's design defect claim under Ohio law against medical device companies was impliedly preempted by Medical Device Amendments (MDA) to FDCA.

Title: American Express National Bank v. Pino Napoli Tile & Granite, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: The alter-ego/department test, under which jurisdiction over an out-of-state parent corporation may be based on the activities of an in-state subsidiary corporation only if the parent's degree of control over the subsidiary's activities is so complete that the subsidiary is merely a department of the parent, is the appropriate standard for applying the exemption, in the statute restricting actions brought in New York by a foreign corporation against another foreign corporation or nonresident, for a foreign corporation that was formed under the laws of the United States and that maintains an office in New York. Title: Straight v. LG Chem, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: E-cigarette device user's factual assertions were insufficient to show that American subsidiary of South Korean manufacturer of lithium-ion batteries was alter ego of manufacturer under Ohio law, thus precluding personal jurisdiction over manufacturer under an alter-ego theory, in user's action against manufacturer alleging that one of manufacturer's battery cells exploded while used in device; while user alleged that subsidiary lacked its own website and that manufacturer and subsidiary shared a channel on a popular video-sharing website, subsidiary observed corporate formalities, kept its own financial accounts and business records, had its own employees and corporate officers, paid employees out of its own funds, and had its own corporate headquarters.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. South Korean manufacturer of batteries was not subject to personal jurisdiction in action brought by user injured by e-cigarette device's battery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Knepfle v. J-Tech Corporation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, plaintiff may establish personal jurisdiction of an upstream, nonresident parent of a resident subsidiary corporation in three ways: first, the plaintiff may show that the non-Florida parent company independently satisfies the test for jurisdiction under Florida's long-arm statutes; second, the plaintiff may establish facts that justify piercing the corporate veil; and third, the plaintiff may show that the parent exercises sufficient control over the subsidiary to render the subsidiary an agent or alter ego of the parent, however the amount of control exercised by the parent must be high and very significant. Fla. Stat. Ann. § 48.193(1).

Title: National Fair Housing Alliance v. Brookdale Santa Fe

Headnote: For purposes of alter ego/agency analysis, general rule under New Mexico law is that mere relationship of parent corporation and subsidiary corporation is not in itself sufficient basis for subjecting both to jurisdiction of forum state, where one is nonresident and is not otherwise present or doing business in forum state.

Title: National Fair Housing Alliance v. Brookdale Santa Fe
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: For purposes of the alter ego/agency analysis, fact that subsidiary is wholly owned is insufficient for personal jurisdiction over parent under New Mexico law, as court will not subject passive investors to its jurisdiction solely on basis of their investment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: National Fair Housing Alliance v. Brookdale Santa Fe
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Where circumstances justify disregard of the corporate entity, and in such cases, the contacts of the subsidiary may be imputed to the parent for purposes of establishing general jurisdiction over the parent; the relevant factual inquiry is whether the parent actually controlled its subsidiary, i.e., exercised domination of the day-to-day business decisions of the subsidiary and a disregard of the corporate entity of the subsidiary, thereby giving rise to personal jurisdiction over the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Allegations of non-profit organization failed to make prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction under alter ego/agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: National Fair Housing Alliance v. Brookdale Santa Fe
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: In evaluating the extent of a parent's control over a subsidiary under New Mexico law for jurisdictional purposes, court considers whether the directors or executives of the subsidiary do not act independently in the interest of the subsidiary but take direction from the parent corporation, whether the parent and the subsidiary have directors or officers in common, whether the parent corporation pays the salaries or expenses or losses of the subsidiary, whether the parent finances the subsidiary, and whether the two corporations have separate auditors, books and records, offices, officers and staffs, bank accounts, tax returns, payrolls, and purchasing.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Allegations of non-profit organization failed to make prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction under alter ego/agency theory.

Title: National Fair Housing Alliance v. Brookdale Santa Fe

Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Allegations of non-profit organization failed to make prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction under alter ego/agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: National Fair Housing Alliance v. Brookdale Santa Fe
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, liability through alter ego theory and personal jurisdiction are different inquiries that focus on different principles and frequently on differing bodies of law; accordingly, while the relationship between a parent and its subsidiary may be crucial in evaluating jurisdiction itself, the ultimate question must be focused on minimum contacts and the satisfaction of due process. U.S. Const. Amend. 5.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Allegations of non-profit organization failed to make prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction under alter ego/agency theory.

Title: Rodríguez-Rivera v. Allscripts Healthcare Solutions, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Relatedness prong for exercising specific personal jurisdiction under the Due Process Clause and Puerto Rico's long-arm statute was not satisfied with respect to holding company that was an indirect parent of subsidiary, an electronic medical records provider, and thus district court lacked jurisdiction over holding company in action by physician alleging claims including negligence in connection with destruction of medical records; holding company did not itself manufacture, market, or sell any goods or services or have any contacts with Puerto Rico, and did not control or direct subsidiary's activities. U.S. Const. Amend. 14; Puerto Rico Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 4.7(a)(1), 32 L.P.R.A.App. III.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. Relatedness prong for exercising specific personal jurisdiction was satisfied with respect to electronic medical records provider.

Title: Chubchai v. AbbVie, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: First prong of alter ego test for personal jurisdiction over parent corporation, i.e., unity of interest and ownership, requires showing that parent controls subsidiary to such degree as to render latter mere instrumentality of former; it requires such pervasive control that it can only be met where parent corporation dictates every facet of subsidiary's business, from broad policy decisions to routine matters of day-to-day operation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Chubchai v. AbbVie, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: In assessing whether the first prong of alter ego test for personal jurisdiction over parent corporation, i.e., unity of interest and ownership, courts consider nine factors: (1) the commingling of funds and other assets of the entities, (2) the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, (3) identical equitable ownership of the entities, (4) use of the same offices and employees, (5) use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) disregard of corporate formalities, (8) lack of segregation of corporate records, and (9) identical directors and officers.

Title: Glowacki-Bishop v. Western & Southern Financial Group Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: To overcome presumption of corporate separateness between parent and subsidiary, for the purpose of establishing personal jurisdiction over the parent corporation, there must be a plus factor beyond the subsidiary's mere presence within the bosom of the corporate family, such as an agency relationship between the two entities, a significant degree of control by the parent that is more than common ownership and directorship, or clear and convincing evidence that the subsidiary is a corporate shell, rather than a stand-alone entity.

Title: In re Tenaris S.A. Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Shareholders of company plausibly alleged company was alter ego of company's parent corporations for personal jurisdiction purposes, as required for court to exercise jurisdiction over corporations in putative securities fraud class action alleging unlawful bribery scheme involving company subsidiary rendered company's public statements and omissions materially misleading under Securities Exchange Act, where shareholders alleged that dividends from company and corporations were maintained in central account of corporations, that bribery payments related to single subsidiary were taken out of central account, that corporations and company shared common personnel and office space, and that corporations' executives delivered bribery payments for official action regarding company's subsidiary. U.S. Const. Amend. 5; Securities Exchange Act of 1934 § 27, 15 U.S.C.A. § 78aa; Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Industry Regulation. Shareholders plausibly alleged executive was acting within scope of authority when he made inaccurate public statements as to bribery scheme.

Title: Reynolds v. Binance Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: When considering entities' unity of interest, for purposes of alter ego test used to extend personal jurisdiction to foreign parent or subsidiary on basis of in-forum entity's contacts, relevant factors include the commingling of funds and other assets of the entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical ownership of the entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Jurisdiction. Nonresident operator of online digital currency exchange platform was not subject to general personal jurisdiction as subsidiary's alter ego.

Title: Reynolds v. Binance Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Nonresident operator of online digital currency exchange platform was not subject to general personal jurisdiction as subsidiary's alter ego, in cryptocurrency investor's action for conversion, unjust enrichment, and negligence, although two of subsidiary's three board directorships were held by operator's executives; fact that subsidiary's reported address was same as company in which operator invested was insufficient to demonstrate entities' requisite unity of interest, and investor did not establish that inequitable result would follow from failure to disregard separate entities between operator and subsidiary.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Jurisdiction. Nonresident operator of online digital currency exchange platform was not subject to general personal jurisdiction as subsidiary's alter ego.

Title: Reynolds v. Binance Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: As total ownership and shared management personnel are alone insufficient to establish the requisite level of control, placement of a parent's directors on the subsidiary's board does not singularly create an alter-ego relationship for purposes of personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Jurisdiction. Nonresident operator of online digital currency exchange platform was not subject to general personal jurisdiction as subsidiary's alter ego.

Title: Fulano v. Fanjul Corporation
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Subsidiary of India corporation, which was based in forum state, was not alter-ego of corporation so as to impute general personal jurisdiction over subsidiary to corporation in foreign agricultural workers' action alleging workers suffered adverse health effects through exposure to corporation's pesticides, even if corporation monitored and gathered information about subsidiary's performance and subsidiary was free to use corporation's trademark symbol without compensation; activities did not rise to level of control required for alter-ego relationship, subsidiary owned none of corporation's stock, and entities had no common officers or directors, no common use of employees, and no interchange of managerial personnel.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Subsidiary of foreign corporation which was based in forum state was not corporation's alter-ego so as to impute personal jurisdiction to corporation.

Title: J.R. v. Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Customers, whose personally identifiable information (PII) was allegedly transferred into database by pharmacy operator, which marketed access to that database to healthcare providers that primarily served low-income patients to permit providers to secure federal reimbursement, failed to demonstrate that operator's parent corporation exercised such control over operator that it was an alter ego of operator under South Carolina law, and thus District Court did not have personal jurisdiction over operator, with respect to customers' claims of misuse of their PII; while operator was a subsidiary of corporation, this did not demonstrate control, nor did corporation's role in guaranteeing operator's debt, and there was no indication of failure to observe corporate formalities. Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2).
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Records. Customers failed to allege claim of unjust enrichment, based on pharmacy operator's transfer of personally identifiable information (PII) to database.

Title: J.R. v. Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: For courts to have personal jurisdiction over a corporation under the alter ego theory, under South Carolina law, the plaintiff must show that the subsidiary functions as the agent or mere department of the parent, that is, that the subsidiary does all the business which the parent corporation could do on its own.

Title: Miami Products & Chemical Co. v. Olin Corporation
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Buyers of caustic soda failed to show that Taiwanese parent corporation of seller of soda acted through its subsidiary based in New Jersey to participate in conspiracy with other sellers of soda comprising 90% of domestic market to artificially limit quantities and raise prices, as required to demonstrate minimum contacts necessary for due process with respect to parent company on the basis of agency relationship necessary to establish personal jurisdiction under rule permitting exercise of such jurisdiction based upon service of summons on foreign defendant, in buyers' action alleging violation of Sherman Act's restraint of trade provision; while buyers alleged that seller treated subsidiary's office in New Jersey as its headquarters, there was no indication of an agency relationship specifically related to soda. U.S. Const. Amend. 14; Sherman Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1; Fed. R. Civ. P. 4(k)(2).
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Conspiracy. Buyers of caustic soda sufficiently alleged sellers engaged in parallel conduct, stating claim under Sherman Act's restraint of trade provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gardner v. Starkist Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: A parent's involvement in macro-management issues do not satisfy the unity of interest prong of the alter ego doctrine used to extend personal jurisdiction to a foreign parent or subsidiary, such as reviewing and approving major decisions, placing several of its directors on the subsidiary's board, and involving itself in the subsidiary's pricing decisions; instead, the plaintiff must show that the parent directs the subsidiary's day-to-day operations and that the entities failed to observe their separate corporate formalities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Purchaser of tuna fish products could not use alter ego doctrine to extend personal jurisdiction to seller's South Korean parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gardner v. Starkist Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Generic language on a defendant's website and in its press releases simply do not rise to the day-to-day control required to impute a subsidiary's contacts to the parent under the alter ego doctrine, which is used to extend personal jurisdiction to a foreign parent or subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Purchaser of tuna fish products could not use alter ego doctrine to extend personal jurisdiction to seller's South Korean parent company.

Title: In re Platinum-Beechwood Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Long-term care insurer implicated in hedge fund Ponzi scheme and insurer's affiliated administrative services provider failed to state New-York-law claim, for aiding and abetting either fraud or breach of fiduciary duty, against either parent company of reinsurer allegedly involved in scheme, or transferee of certain capital of reinsurer, where insurer and services provider alleged conduct only by subsidiaries of parent and transferee, yet did not offer explanation for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Receiver for hedge funds failed to state New-York-law aiding and abetting fraud claim against insurer allegedly involved in Ponzi scheme.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: To assert jurisdiction over a parent company based on the conduct of a subsidiary, the court must find circumstances warranting it to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Warnings. State of Maryland stated claim for strict product liability based on failure to warn against manufacturers, marketers, and distributors of gasoline.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under the agency test, used to decide whether to pierce the veil separating parent corporations from their subsidiaries for jurisdictional purposes, the court may attribute the actions of a subsidiary corporation to the parent corporation only if the parent exerts considerable control over the activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Warnings. State of Maryland stated claim for strict product liability based on failure to warn against manufacturers, marketers, and distributors of gasoline.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce the veil separating parent corporations from their subsidiaries for jurisdictional purposes, the central inquiry is whether significant decisions of the subsidiary must be approved by the parent.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Warnings. State of Maryland stated claim for strict product liability based on failure to warn against manufacturers, marketers, and distributors of gasoline.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Courts consider various factors in determining whether the requisite level of control exists, for purposes of piercing corporate veil for jurisdictional purposes, such as whether the parent and subsidiary maintain separate books and records, employ separate accounting procedures, and hold separate directors' meetings.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: In determining whether the requisite level of control exists between parent corporation and subsidiary, for purposes of piercing corporate veil for jurisdictional purposes, courts consider the level of interdependence between parent and subsidiary.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, in deciding whether to pierce the veil separating parent corporations from their subsidiaries for jurisdictional purposes, court must find that the parent knew, or should have known, that its conduct would have some impact in Maryland.

Title: State v. Exxon Mobil Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Nonresident holding company did not exert degree of control over indirect subsidiary greater than that of typical parent company and, thus, subsidiary's contacts with Maryland could not be imputed to holding company for jurisdictional purposes, in action by State of Maryland, in its capacity as trustee of State's natural resources, seeking to redress alleged contamination of State's waters with methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE), an oxygenate additive that was commonly blended into gasoline; holding company and subsidiary existed largely as separate entities, they maintained their own books and records, had their own boards of directors, and did not comingle their accounts, and holding company never exercised control over day-to-day operations of subsidiary.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Warnings. State of Maryland stated claim for strict product liability based on failure to warn against manufacturers, marketers, and distributors of gasoline.

Title: Mills v. Ethicon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, service on a wholly owned subsidiary confers jurisdiction over the foreign parent only if the subsidiary is an alter ego or agent of the parent.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Patient's complaint asserting negligence claims under Pennsylvania law failed to satisfy notice pleading requirements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Wapp Tech Limited Partnership v. Micro Focus International, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Courts consider a number of factors in assessing the relationship between a parent company and its alleged alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiary's contacts to parent for specific personal jurisdiction, such as: (1) the parent company's attempt to purposely direct or control the activities of the subsidiary; (2) evidence of common control or joint-venture agreements; (3) the amount of the subsidiary's stock owned by the parent company; (4) the existence of separate headquarters for each entity; (5) the sharing of common officers and directors; (6) the observance of corporate formalities; (7) the maintenance of separate accounting systems; (8) the subsidiary's exercise of complete authority over its daily operations; and (9) the degree of the parent company's control over the general policy and administration of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Wapp Tech Limited Partnership v. Micro Focus International, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: On its face, a parent company setting financial goals or requiring financial reporting from its subsidiaries does not present a prima facie case that the subsidiary is the parent company's alter ego, for purposes of imputing subsidiary's contacts to parent for specific personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Wapp Tech Limited Partnership v. Micro Focus International, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Patentee failed to make a prima facie showing that non-resident competitor exercised a degree of control over its subsidiaries in forum state sufficient to establish that subsidiaries were competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for specific personal jurisdiction, based on allegations that competitor instituted general financial policies and strategies for its subsidiaries, and set budget, revenue, and business goals of its subsidiaries, and that competitor shared a common director with its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for personal jurisdiction.

Title: Wapp Tech Limited Partnership v. Micro Focus International, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: One hundred percent stock ownership by a parent company of its subsidiaries cannot alone establish an alter ego theory, for purposes of imputing subsidiary's contacts to parent for specific personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Wapp Tech Limited Partnership v. Micro Focus International, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Patentee failed to make a prima facie showing that non-resident competitor and its subsidiaries in forum state did not respect corporate formalities, as may establish that subsidiaries were competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for specific personal jurisdiction, based only on allegations that the relationship between competitor's chief executive office (CEO) and the leading directors of subsidiaries was blurred and the boards of at least some of the subsidiaries were not active or used.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not competitor's alter egos, for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' contacts to competitor for personal jurisdiction.

Title: Watamar Holding S.A. v. SFM Holdings, S.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: When a party seeks to prove one corporation is an alter ego of another, elements required to pierce the corporate veil for liability purposes differ from those used for jurisdictional purposes, because certain elements necessary to pierce the corporate veil are irrelevant to assessing jurisdictional contacts; plaintiffs must prove parent controls internal business operations and affairs of subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendants and Swiss holding corporation.

Title: Watamar Holding S.A. v. SFM Holdings, S.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Court uses standard for jurisdictional veil-piercing of corporate veil between parent company and subsidiary to assess jurisdictional veil-piercing between individual and corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendants and Swiss holding corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Boon Global Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: A party seeking to establish personal jurisdiction over a person or entity can either: (1) show each defendant's sufficient, direct contacts with the forum state, or (2) use the alter ego theory to extend personal jurisdiction to a foreign parent or subsidiary when, in actuality, the foreign entity is not really separate from its domestic affiliate.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Writs. Mandamus relief was unwarranted to vacate order compelling third-party non-signatories to software development agreement to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Boon Global Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: The unity of interest and ownership prong for establishing jurisdiction on an alter ego theory requires a showing that the parent controls the subsidiary to such a degree as to render the latter the mere instrumentality of the former.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Writs. Mandamus relief was unwarranted to vacate order compelling third-party non-signatories to software development agreement to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lutz v. Rakuten, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A court exercises personal jurisdiction over a parent corporation through its personal jurisdiction over a subsidiary by way of the alter-ego theory; under the alter-ego theory, if a subsidiary is merely the agent of its parent corporation or the parent corporation controls the subsidiary, then personal jurisdiction exists over the parent whenever personal jurisdiction, whether general or specific, exists over the subsidiary.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. Specific personal jurisdiction existed over nonresident owner of Japanese professional baseball team, in action for negligent misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: A court may impute the contacts of a subsidiary corporation to a foreign parent corporation for the purpose of exercising specific personal jurisdiction if the subsidiary corporation is merely operating as the parent corporation's alter ego, such that the independence of the separate corporate entities may be disregarded.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Real estate developer's contentions did not demonstrate that limited liability company functioned as a dummy or shell corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Successor Agency to Former Emeryville Redevelopment Agency v. Swagelok Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, London-based corporation's acquisition conduct supported finding of unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and subsidiary that acquired company, as required for jurisdiction over London-based corporation under alter ego liability theory, in city's CERCLA action seeking to recover costs for contamination of property by the acquired company; London-based corporation incorporated 20 entities in anticipation of the takeover, corporation sent press release stating that it intended to commence a tender offer for any outstanding shares of the company and released several other press releases taking apparent credit for the takeover. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over London-based parent corporation in CERCLA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Successor Agency to Former Emeryville Redevelopment Agency v. Swagelok Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, litigation by London-based parent corporation concerning company that was acquired by one of the corporation's subsidiaries tended to support a unity of interest between corporation and with its subsidiary, as required for jurisdiction over London-based corporation under alter ego liability theory, in city's CERCLA action seeking to recover costs for contamination of property; corporation filed two lawsuits against the company for attempting to utilize New York Securities Takeover Disclosure Act to prevent the takeover. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over London-based parent corporation in CERCLA action.

Title: Successor Agency to Former Emeryville Redevelopment Agency v. Swagelok Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Undercapitalization of London-based parent corporation's subsidiary, which acquired, through hostile takeover, a company that was allegedly responsible for contaminating property, suggested that parent corporation was alter ego of its subsidiary as required, under California law, for jurisdiction over parent corporation under alter ego theory in city's CERCLA action seeking to recover costs for contamination of property; subsidiary did not have its assets or liabilities valued during the acquisition, even while the parent corporation had reason to know that subsidiary faced prospective liabilities. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over London-based parent corporation in CERCLA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Successor Agency to Former Emeryville Redevelopment Agency v. Swagelok Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, London-based parent corporation's sharing of same officers and directors with subsidiary that acquired company that was allegedly responsible for contaminating property was insufficient to establish unity of interest between parent corporation and subsidiary as required for jurisdiction over London-based corporation under alter ego liability theory, in city's CERCLA action seeking to recover costs for contamination of property by the acquired company; there were no directors of the parent company who were concurrently directors of the subsidiary at the time of the acquisition, and of all 26 directors, associate directs, and officers of the parent corporation and the subsidiary, there was only one in common between the two entities. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over London-based parent corporation in CERCLA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Successor Agency to Former Emeryville Redevelopment Agency v. Swagelok Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Injustice would result if corporate veil was not pierced as required, under California law, for personal jurisdiction over London-based parent corporation of subsidiary that acquired company that allegedly contaminated property, in city's CERCLA action seeking to recover costs for contamination of property by the acquired company; parent corporation intentionally targeted the company for a hostile takeover and liquidation and acquired a company that retained the alleged environmental liabilities while operating on the property. Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980, § 101 et seq., 42 U.S.C.A. § 9601 et seq.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over London-based parent corporation in CERCLA action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BASF Corporation v. Willowood, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: As all corporations must necessarily act through agents, a wholly owned subsidiary may be an agent under Colorado law, and when its activities as an agent are of such a character as to amount to doing business of the parent, the parent is subjected to the in personam jurisdiction of the state in which the subsidiary conducts the parent's business.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Alleged infringers were not agents or alter egos of each other as required for general jurisdiction over infringer that was as Hong Kong LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BASF Corporation v. Willowood, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Objective of either the agency or alter ego theory, in a dispute concerning personal jurisdiction over a parent corporation, is to establish that the parent corporation has the minimum contacts with the forum necessary to support a finding of jurisdiction.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. Alleged infringers were not agents or alter egos of each other as required for general jurisdiction over infringer that was as Hong Kong LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Resident corporation respected corporate formalities and operated as independent corporation, outside direct control of foreign companies in family, weighing against imputing contacts from resident corporation to nonresident corporate defendants, in due process personal jurisdiction analysis under Texas long-arm statute; although resident corporation cooperated with its parent, grandparent, and sister companies, it had separate office, kept its own corporate records, it separately hired and paid its employees, it separately owned property, leased office space, held director and shareholder meetings, had directors who were tasked with pursuing its interests, it was sufficiently capitalized, it had its own insurance coverage, and it independently contracted with employees from affiliated companies. U.S. Const. Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In Texas, a subsidiary corporation's contacts can be imputed to its parent corporation for the purpose of exercising personal jurisdiction over the parent when the subsidiary is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of the parent.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: To succeed in Texas under an alter ego theory of imputing a subsidiary corporation's contacts to its nonresident parent corporation, for the purpose of exercising personal jurisdiction over the parent, the plaintiff seeking to establish personal jurisdiction in a manner consistent with due process must show that the parent controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice, and a "plus" factor must be demonstrated, i.e., something beyond the subsidiary's mere presence within the bosom of the corporate family. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In Texas, when considering whether a subsidiary corporation's contacts can be imputed to its nonresident parent corporation for the purpose of exercising personal jurisdiction over the parent in a manner consistent with due process, all of the relevant facts and circumstances surrounding the operations of the two corporations must be examined to determine whether two separate and distinct corporate entities exist. U.S. Const. Amend. 14.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the contacts for personal jurisdiction can be imputed through a parent-subsidiary relationship.

Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Resident corporation's informal references to itself with same name as parent corporation did not support inference that corporate formalities were ignored, in personal jurisdiction analysis of whether contacts from resident corporation could be imputed to nonresident corporate defendants in manner consistent with due process under Texas long-arm statute, since in legally binding circumstances, like contracts, financial statements, insurance policies, invoices, certifications, board meeting minutes, and board resolutions, resident corporation used its formal and unique name. U.S. Const. Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Foreign corporate parent did not exercise control over resident corporation through credit-facility agreement that was secured through parent's assets, including its shares in resident corporation, weighing against imputing contacts from resident corporation to nonresident corporate defendants in due process personal jurisdiction analysis under Texas long-arm statute, where resident corporation received access to credit for agreeing to credit-facility agreement and resident corporation's board of directors met and approved pledge agreement and credit-facility agreement's terms. U.S. Const. Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.

Title: Garcia v. Peterson
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In determining if an alter ego relationship between corporations is established, permitting exercise of personal jurisdiction over the parent corporation, factors deemed important by Texas courts are: (1) common stock ownership; (2) the method and degree of financing of the subsidiary by the parent; (3) common directors or officers; (4) separate books and accounts; (5) common business departments; (6) extent to which contracts between parent and subsidiary favor one over the other; and (7) connection of parent's employee, officer or director to subsidiary's tort or contract giving rise to suit.

Title: Hernandez–Denizac v. Kia Motors Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Nonresident designer of automobile's airbag control unit and crash sensors did not control activities of its subsidiaries who were previously registered to do business in Puerto Rico, as required to exercise personal jurisdiction over designer in consumer's action alleging that he was seriously injured when his automobile's allegedly defective air bags failed to deploy during a collision, pursuant to theory of piercing corporate veil under Puerto Rico law, where designer proffered evidence that it had scrupulously maintained separate corporate existence from its subsidiaries, and consumer failed to proffer requisite strong and robust evidence that would warrant disregarding designer's corporate form.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. Nonresident airbag designer did not purposefully avail itself of privilege of conducting activities in Puerto Rico.

Title: Gourdine v. Karl Storz Endoscopy–America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: German medical device manufacturer's subsidiary, which was a California company that marketed and distributed the devices within the United States, and over which district court had personal jurisdiction, was alter ego of manufacturer, as required for district court to exercise personal jurisdiction over manufacturer in patient's products liability action; there was unity of interest and ownership between manufacturer and subsidiary in that there was considerable identification of the directors and officers of the two entities in the responsible supervision and management of both entities, subsidiary had been manufacturer's exclusive distributor in United States for 35 years and manufacturer's products comprised 93% of subsidiary's revenues, and it would at least appear inequitable to excuse from the action the party that designed and manufactured the product on the basis of legal separation between manufacturer and distributor.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over German medical device manufacturer in products liability action.

Title: Semperit Technische Produkte Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Hennessy
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: New Jersey subsidiary of Austrian manufacturer of high pressure hydraulic hose was not alter ego of manufacturer, and thus, actions of subsidiary would not be imputed to manufacturer, for purposes determining whether products liability suit arising out of death of Texas buyer's employee when hose failed, causing high pressure release that pushed employee into oil derrick, arose out of manufacturer's contacts with Texas, as alternative basis for Texas to exercise personal jurisdiction over manufacturer; fact that manufacturer required frequent detailed financial reporting and that boards of both had overlapping membership was of no consequence, fact that manufacturer approved subsidiary's budget did now show control over subsidiary beyond what parent would normally exercise, and fact that manufacturer had to approve subsidiary's hiring decisions was little different from approving budgets.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. Texas had personal jurisdiction over Austrian manufacturer of high pressure hydraulic hose.
