Title: Ranza v. Nike, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: The alter ego test, allowing a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil for personal jurisdictional purposes, is designed to determine whether the parent and subsidiary are not really separate entities, such that one entity's contacts with the forum state can be fairly attributed to the other; the alter ego relationship is typified by parental control of the subsidiary's internal affairs or daily operations.

Title: Ranza v. Nike, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Alter ego test may be used to extend personal jurisdiction to a foreign parent or subsidiary when, in actuality, the foreign entity is not really separate from its domestic affiliate.

Title: Ranza v. Nike, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: The unity of interest and ownership prong of the alter ego test used to extend personal jurisdiction to a foreign parent or subsidiary requires a showing that the parent controls the subsidiary to such a degree as to render the latter the mere instrumentality of the former; this test envisions pervasive control over the subsidiary, such as when a parent corporation dictates every facet of the subsidiary's business, from broad policy decisions to routine matters of day-to-day operation.

Title: Ranza v. Nike, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Total ownership and shared management personnel are alone insufficient to establish the requisite level of control by a parent over its subsidiary needed to extend personal jurisdiction to a foreign parent or subsidiary under the alter ego test.

Title: Ranza v. Nike, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Netherlands employer was not an alter ego of its Oregon parent corporation, and thus parent corporation's contacts could not be attributed to employer to establish personal jurisdiction over it in Oregon action brought by former employee for sex and age discrimination in the workplace based on conduct that occurred in the Netherlands; although parent corporation exercised control over employer's budget, established human resource policies, and had approval authority for large purchases, employer set its own prices for its products licensed through parent corporation, fulfilled orders using its own inventory, negotiated its own contract and licenses, and handled its own day-to-day operations. Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, § 4, 29 U.S.C.A. § 623; Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 703, 704, 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e–2, 2000e–3.

Title: Ranza v. Nike, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: A parent corporation may be directly involved in financing and macro-management of its subsidiaries without exposing itself to a charge that each subsidiary is merely its alter ego allowing personal jurisdiction to extend to foreign parent or subsidiary.

Title: Muniz v. Walgreen Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: A district court may not exercise personal jurisdiction over a parent corporation simply by virtue of its subsidiary's contacts with the forum; the court may, under certain circumstances, pierce the corporate veil to attribute the subsidiary's contacts to the parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Puerto Rico contacts of drug store operator's corporate parent were not proximate cause of child receiving wrong prescription.

Title: In re Miscavige
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: For jurisdictional purposes, in order to "fuse" the Texas contacts of a parent company with that of a subsidiary or agent, a plaintiff must prove that the parent controls the internal business operations of and affairs of the subsidiary, and the degree of control the parent exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Discovery. Apex deposition rule applies to executive named as a defendant based on his capacity as an executive.

Title: Viega GmbH v. Eighth Jud. Dist. Ct.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Corporate entities are presumed separate, and, thus, the mere existence of a relationship between a parent company and its subsidiaries is not sufficient to establish personal jurisdiction over the parent on the basis of the subsidiaries' minimum contacts with the forum. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not acting as agents of parents so as to establish personal jurisdiction over parents.

Title: Viega GmbH v. Eighth Jud. Dist. Ct.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: The alter ego theory allows plaintiffs to pierce the corporate veil to impute a subsidiary's contacts to the parent company for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over the foreign parent company by showing that the subsidiary and the parent are one and the same.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not acting as agents of parents so as to establish personal jurisdiction over parents.

Title: Viega GmbH v. Eighth Jud. Dist. Ct.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Corporate entities are presumed separate, and thus, indicia of mere ownership are not alone sufficient to subject a parent company to personal jurisdiction based on its subsidiary's contacts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not acting as agents of parents so as to establish personal jurisdiction over parents.

Title: In re Chinese-Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Chinese drywall manufacturer's subsidiary was acting as manufacturer's "agent," within meaning of Florida agency law, and thus subsidiary's contacts with Florida could be imputed to manufacturer, as required to determine whether district court in Florida had specific jurisdiction over manufacturer in products liability action; manufacturer created subsidiary solely to execute sales accompanied by value added tax invoices, manufacturer's employees sat on subsidiary's board of directors, manufacturer capitalized, staffed, and dealt with subsidiary, subsidiary held itself out to be the same entity as manufacturer, and manufacturer wound down subsidiary upon its discontinuation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Subsidiary was agent of parent company, and thus its contacts with Florida could be imputed to parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chinese-Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Chinese drywall manufacturer's subsidiary was alter ego of manufacturer under Louisiana law, and thus subsidiary's contacts with Louisiana could be imputed to manufacturer, as required to determine whether district court in Louisiana had specific jurisdiction over manufacturer in products liability action; manufacturer authorized subsidiary to use its trademark in producing drywall but did not charge subsidiary for this authorization, manufacturer and subsidiary did not accurately report their dealings with each other in their financial reports, and some of subsidiary's board members did not receive compensation from subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Subsidiary was agent of parent company, and thus its contacts with Florida could be imputed to parent company.

Title: Radian Guaranty Inc. v. Bolen
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory of jurisdiction, a court may exercise personal jurisdiction over the parent based on the subsidiary's connection to the forum if the plaintiff can show that the parent controls the day-to-day operations of the subsidiary such that the subsidiary can be said to be a mere department of the parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Non-signatories were bound by forum selection clause which provided express consent to personal jurisdiction.

Title: Bates v. Bankers Life and Cas. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: In general, existence of relationship between parent company and its subsidiaries is not sufficient to establish personal jurisdiction over parent on basis of subsidiaries' minimum contacts with forum; however, where parent and subsidiary are not really separate entities, or one acts as agent of the other, local subsidiary's contacts with forum may be imputed to foreign parent corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under Oregon law, breach of contract claim against insurer's parent survived motion to dismiss on theory of actual agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bates v. Bankers Life and Cas. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: In order to establish specific personal jurisdiction over defendant based on contacts of its subsidiary on alter ego theory, a plaintiff must make out prima facie case (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two entities no longer exist and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice; such unity of interest is present where parent corporation uses its subsidiary as marketing conduit and attempts to shield itself from liability based on its subsidiaries' activities, or where record indicates that parent dictates every facet of subsidiary's business-from broad policy decisions to routine matters of day-to-day operation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under Oregon law, breach of contract claim against insurer's parent survived motion to dismiss on theory of actual agency.

Title: RMS Titanic, Inc. v. Zaller
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: "Alter ego" theory of personal jurisdiction generally provides that nonresident parent corporation is amenable to suit in forum state if parent company exerts so much control over subsidiary that the two do not exist as separate entities but are one and the same for purposes of jurisdiction.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Trade Dress. Plaintiffs involved in staging of museum quality exhibition stated plausible trade dress infringement claim under Lanham Act.

Title: Black v. The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Pursuant to a theory of agency liability, a court may find the necessary contacts to support the exercise of personal jurisdiction over a foreign parent company by virtue of its relationship to a subsidiary that has continual operations in the forum.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Bermuda corporation that operated Dubai hotel where guest was injured in fall.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Black v. The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: The general agency test for exercising personal jurisdiction over a foreign parent company by virtue of its relationship to a subsidiary that has continual operations in the forum requires that the plaintiff show: (1) the subsidiary functions as the parent corporation's representative in that it performs services that are sufficiently important to the foreign corporation that if it did not have a representative to perform them, the corporation's own officials would undertake to perform substantially similar services; and (2) an element of control, albeit not as much control as is required to satisfy the alter ego test.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Bermuda corporation that operated Dubai hotel where guest was injured in fall.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Black v. The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: At an irreducible minimum, the general agency test for exercising personal jurisdiction over a foreign parent company by virtue of its relationship to a subsidiary that has continual operations in the forum requires that the agent perform some service or engage in some meaningful activity in the forum state on behalf of its principal such that its presence substitutes for presence of the principal.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Bermuda corporation that operated Dubai hotel where guest was injured in fall.

Title: Intellectual Ventures I LLC v. Nikon Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under agency theory for establishing specific personal jurisdiction under Delaware long-arm statute, court may attribute actions of a subsidiary company to its parent where subsidiary acts on parent's behalf or at parent's direction. 10 West's Del.C. § 3104(c)(1–4).
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Allegations were sufficient to state induced patent infringement claims against retailers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Intellectual Ventures I LLC v. Nikon Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Agency theory for establishing specific personal jurisdiction under Delaware long-arm statute may be applied not only to parent and subsidiary corporations, but also to companies that are "two arms of the same business group," operate in concert with each other, and enter into agreements with each other that are nearer than arm's length. 10 West's Del.C. § 3104(c)(1–4).
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Allegations were sufficient to state induced patent infringement claims against retailers.

Title: Intellectual Ventures I LLC v. Nikon Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: District Court lacked personal jurisdiction in patent infringement action over Japanese camera manufacturer under agency theory for establishing specific personal jurisdiction under Delaware long-arm statute, where manufacturer was not the principal in an agency relationship with any of the other defendants in patent infringement action, and its conduct was directed by its parent corporation and was limited to activities in Japan. 10 West's Del.C. § 3104(c)(1–4).
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Allegations were sufficient to state induced patent infringement claims against retailers.

Title: Burke v. Ability Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: If the resident subsidiary corporation is the alter ego of the nonresident parent corporation, the subsidiary's contacts are those of the parent corporation's, and due process is satisfied, for purpose of establishing personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporation. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations supported piercing corporate veil, as would establish personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Burke v. Ability Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: Nonresident parent corporations allegedly exercised sufficient control over subsidiary insurer which contracted with insured to provide long-term care insurance policy, to such a degree as to render the latter the mere instrumentality of former, sufficient to support piercing of the corporate veil and establish personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporations, under the due process clause, in action brought by estate of insured against insurer and parent corporations, alleging breach of contract, bad faith, and other claims; subsidiary insurer was allegedly owned by one or both of parent corporations, one individual allegedly exercised direct control over subsidiary and parent corporations, all of the entities allegedly shared administrative costs and facilities, and money allegedly moved from subsidiary to parent corporations. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations supported piercing corporate veil, as would establish personal jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Grand Aerie Fraternal Order of Eagles v. Haygood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: A trial court may have general personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent corporation if the relationship between corporation and its subsidiary that does business in the state is one that would allow the court to impute the subsidiary's doing business in state to the parent corporation; this is only permissible when the parent corporation exerts such domination and control over its subsidiary that they do not in reality constitute separate and distinct corporate entities but are one and the same corporation for purposes of jurisdiction.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Nonresident national organization's contact with state was not sufficiently related to dram shop action for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Grand Aerie Fraternal Order of Eagles v. Haygood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Jurisdictional veil-piercing is distinct from substantive veil-piercing; imputing a related entity's contacts for jurisdictional purposes requires a showing that the parent controls the subsidiary's internal operations and affairs.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Nonresident national organization's contact with state was not sufficiently related to dram shop action for personal jurisdiction.

Title: Grand Aerie Fraternal Order of Eagles v. Haygood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: To disregard parent-subsidiary corporate form as a corporate fiction for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over a nonresident corporation, there must be evidence that the two entities cease to be separate, including that the parent's degree of control is more than is typical with common ownership and directorship.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Nonresident national organization's contact with state was not sufficiently related to dram shop action for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Grand Aerie Fraternal Order of Eagles v. Haygood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: To determine whether a nonresident parent corporation is the alter ego of subsidiary for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over the parent corporation, the Court of Appeals reviews the record for atypical control over subsidiary's operations or typical parental involvement that is consistent with their legal form; appropriate parental involvement includes monitoring the subsidiary's performance, supervision of the subsidiary's finance and capital budget decisions, and articulation of general policies.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Nonresident national organization's contact with state was not sufficiently related to dram shop action for personal jurisdiction.

Title: Grand Aerie Fraternal Order of Eagles v. Haygood
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Inappropriate control of a nonresident parent corporation over subsidiary sufficient to establish general personal jurisdiction over the parent corporation based on the subsidiary's contact with forum is evidenced by something beyond the subsidiary's mere presence within the bosom of the corporate family.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Nonresident national organization's contact with state was not sufficiently related to dram shop action for personal jurisdiction.

Title: Genzyme Corp. v. Shire Human Genetic Therapies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Actions of a drug manufacturer's competitor would not be imputed to the competitor's parent corporation, so as to treat the corporation as the competitor's alter ego for personal jurisdictional purposes in the manufacturer's Lanham Act false advertising suit; the corporation's inclusion of the competitor in its Securities and Exchange Commission filings and publicity materials amounted to nothing more than evidence of common ownership and directorship, and there was no evidence that implicated the corporation in the composition and dissemination of the press release at issue. Lanham Act, § 43 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1125 et seq.; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 12(b)(2), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Advertising. Drug manufacturer stated a Lanham Act false advertising claim against a competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Genzyme Corp. v. Shire Human Genetic Therapies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: To overcome the presumption of separate corporate identity and assert personal jurisdiction over a parent corporation based on its subsidiary's forum contacts, there must be a "plus" factor beyond the subsidiary's mere presence within the bosom of the corporate family; these "plus factors" include an agency relationship between the two corporations, a degree of control by the parent that is more than common ownership and directorship, or clear and convincing evidence that the subsidiary is not a functioning entity, but simply an empty shell. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 12(b)(2), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Advertising. Drug manufacturer stated a Lanham Act false advertising claim against a competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Marnavi S.p.A. v. Keehan
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Italian agent's allegations on behalf of Panamanian vessel owner, that Delaware corporation and directors formed wholly-owned subsidiary to avoid liability to agent for foreign arbitration award against corporation for warranty and tort obligations from contract to seal coat vessel, and that corporation was merged into subsidiary for inadequate consideration as strategy of corporate "shape shifting" to avoid paying agent, were not sufficient to infer that directors or corporations were alter egos of each other, as basis for exercise of personal jurisdiction over directors, under Delaware law, since transactions by corporation and directors did not amount to fraudulent use of corporate forms.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Directors were not subject to personal jurisdiction for derivative liability claims for arbitration award against corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Singh v. Daimler, AG
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: The "alter-ego theory" provides for personal jurisdiction if the parent company exerts so much control over the subsidiary that the two do not exist as separate entities but are one and the same for purposes of jurisdiction and the following additional factors are considered: (1) sharing the same employees and corporate officers; (2) engaging in the same business enterprise; (3) having the same address and phone lines; (4) using the same assets; (5) completing the same jobs; (6) not maintaining separate books, tax returns and financial statements; and (7) exerting control over the daily affairs of another corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Employee's International Assignment Letter did not constitute waiver by German companies to jurisdiction in United States.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a plaintiff may establish personal jurisdiction in the forum over a nonresident parent corporation by virtue of its subsidiary's activities in the forum when, the parent exercises sufficient control over the subsidiary to render the subsidiary an agent or alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Florida law, ownership of a resident subsidiary corporation by an out-of-state parent corporation, without more, will not sustain the assertion of personal jurisdiction over the foreign parent; generally, proof of control by the parent over the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary is required to fuse the two for jurisdictional purposes, and the degree of control exercised by the parent must be greater than that normally associated with ownership and directorship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Florida law, if a subsidiary is a mere instrumentality of a parent corporation, the parent corporation will be subject to personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Wholly-owned subsidiary of Chinese drywall manufacturer operated as manufacturer's alter ego or agent in conducting its Florida-related business, as required to impute subsidiary's contacts to manufacturer for purposes of personal jurisdiction in action brought against manufacturer by home and property owners for claims arising after defective drywall was installed in homes and properties; although subsidiary was created with separate articles of incorporation, registered with Chinese business licensing department, and submitted financial reports separate from manufacturer, manufacturer created subsidiary specifically to manufacture its products, particularly drywall, and sell drywall to manufacturer's existing customers, manufacturer and subsidiary held themselves out to customers and potential customers as a single entity, and manufacturer's employees "volunteered" to work for subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Louisiana law recognizes the possibility of imputing contacts of a subsidiary to a parent for purposes of personal jurisdiction when the subsidiary is actually an alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Wholly-owned subsidiary of Chinese drywall manufacturer operated as manufacturer's alter ego or agent in conducting its Louisiana-related business, as required to impute subsidiary's contacts to manufacturer for purposes of personal jurisdiction in action brought against manufacturer by home and property owners for claims arising after defective drywall was installed in homes and properties; subsidiary was formed to sell manufacturer's products to portion of its existing customer base, entities' employees and board members overlapped, subsidiary held itself out as manufacturer in dealing with customers and potential customers, manufacturer authorized subsidiary to use its registered trademarks, entities interchanged in conducting business and settling debts with customers, and after subsidiary stopped production, manufacturer continued to pay the salaries of subsidiary's remaining employees and handled its business affairs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Title: Repwest Ins. Co. v. Praetorian Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Without some showing that subsidiaries are the alter egos or agents of the parent, a simple corporate affiliation does not confer personal jurisdiction on a parent company.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Arbitration and Appraisal. Claims alleging breach of contract and breach of duty of good faith and fair dealing were subject to arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lego A/S v. Best-Lock Const. Toys, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, before a long-arm statute can be utilized as a basis for the exercise of jurisdiction over the nonresident foreign corporation, the corporate veil must be pierced so that acts of the domestic subsidiary can be imputed to the absent parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Toy manufacturer was not the alter ego of its chief executive officer (CEO) for purposes of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: U.S. v. Pangang Group Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Foreign corporation's domestic subsidiary was corporation's general agent, for purposes of determining whether service of process on subsidiary complied with delivery requirement in prosecution for economic espionage conspiracy, where subsidiary merged offices with another subsidiary on corporation's request, and subsidiary's representatives served as clerks to run certain documents through, and subsidiary was responsible for marketing for corporation in United States.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Indictment and Information. Evidence did not establish unity of interest for alter-ego relationship, as required for personal jurisdiction over foreign corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: U.S. v. Pangang Group Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Level of control required by foreign corporation to obtain a work visa for domestic subsidiary's executive was not commensurate with the level of control required to establish an alter-ego relationship between corporation and subsidiary for personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Indictment and Information. Evidence did not establish unity of interest for alter-ego relationship, as required for personal jurisdiction over foreign corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: U.S. v. Pangang Group Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Evidence that domestic subsidiary was the general agent for foreign parent companies, and that subsidiary's board of directors included representatives from parent companies was not sufficient to establish the requisite unity of interest to establish an alter-ego relationship, as required to establish personal jurisdiction over parent companies in prosecution for economic espionage conspiracy, where government had served process only on subsidiary.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Indictment and Information. Evidence did not establish unity of interest for alter-ego relationship, as required for personal jurisdiction over foreign corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: U.S. v. Pangang Group Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Failure to disregard separate identities of foreign parent companies and domestic subsidiary, in prosecution for economic espionage conspiracy, would not result in fraud or injustice, as required to establish personal jurisdiction over companies based on alter ego status, absent showing that companies structured subsidiary in such a way that it was designed as to avoid subjecting it to liability within the United States.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Indictment and Information. Evidence did not establish unity of interest for alter-ego relationship, as required for personal jurisdiction over foreign corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Hilani v. Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Tennessee, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, actions of one corporation may serve as basis for personal jurisdiction over related corporate entity (1) when one corporation is acting as agent for the other or (2) when the two corporations are essentially alter egos of each other; in either event, both relationships must be characterized by parent corporation's control of subsidiary corporation's internal affairs or daily operations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court lacked personal jurisdiction over Greek resident's breach of contract suit against U.S. religious organization.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Mazza v. Verizon Washington DC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Courts will impute personal jurisdiction under an alter ego theory in cases where the parent company so dominated the subsidiary corporation as to negate its separate personality.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Allegations were sufficient to state a claim of a pattern of abusive collection strategies in violation of FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Knight Corp. v. Knight
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Jurisdictional veil-piercing and substantive veil-piercing involve different elements of proof, and for this reason, fraud-which is vital to piercing the corporate veil-has no place in assessing contacts by a nonresident parent company with a forum state through the acts of the subsidiary to determine whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction over the parent is permissible. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Jurisdiction. Pennsylvania corporation for which husband was president did not have minimum contacts with Texas to permit exercise of jurisdiction over corporation in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Khatib v. Alliance Bankshares Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Merging parent and subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes requires an inquiry comparable to the corporate law question of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Parent-subsidiary relationship was insufficient to impute subsidiary's contacts with forum to parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Khatib v. Alliance Bankshares Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Parent-subsidiary relationship was insufficient to impute contacts of lender to its parent corporation, and, thus, exercise of personal jurisdiction over parent corporation on basis of lender's contacts in the District of Columbia was not warranted, in borrower's putative class action asserting claims arising out of lender's sub-prime lending practices, where parent corporation operated as a bank holding company, and lender did not perform a function that parent corporation would otherwise have to perform itself.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Parent-subsidiary relationship was insufficient to impute subsidiary's contacts with forum to parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gines v. D.R. Horton, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: In determining whether to maintain corporate separateness of contacts between a parent corporation and a subsidiary, for personal jurisdiction purposes, the court must look to several non-exhaustive factors: (1) the amount of stock owned by the parent of the subsidiary (2) whether the entities have separate headquarters, directors, and officers, (3) whether corporate formalities are observed, (4) whether the entities maintain separate accounting systems, and (5) whether the parent exercises complete control over the subsidiary's general policies or daily activities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District Court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over non-resident parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: City of Greenville, Ill. v. Syngenta Crop Protection, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Where corporate formalities are not observed such that piercing corporate veil is warranted, where parent dominates subsidiary, or where subsidiary is acting solely as parent's agent, and parent is simply doing business through its subsidiary to shield itself from liability, court may have personal jurisdiction over parent based on subsidiary's contacts.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Swiss parent of American herbicide manufacturer was subject to personal jurisdiction in United States.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: City of Greenville, Ill. v. Syngenta Crop Protection, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Where plaintiff claims parent company is subject to court's jurisdiction by virtue of its subsidiary's contacts because it exercised extraordinary control over subsidiary, court considers factors including: (1) whether officers or directors are same; (2) how much control is exerted by parent over daily affairs of its subsidiary; (3) whether parent arranges financing for and capitalization of subsidiary; (4) whether separate books, tax returns, and financial statements are kept; (5) whether parent holds its subsidiary out as agent; and (6) method of payment made to parent by subsidiary.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Swiss parent of American herbicide manufacturer was subject to personal jurisdiction in United States.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: City of Greenville, Ill. v. Syngenta Crop Protection, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: United States herbicide manufacturer was sufficiently controlled by its Swiss parent corporation to permit exercise of general personal jurisdiction over parent in action by drinking water providers to recover costs they incurred in testing and monitoring herbicide's levels and in removing it from their raw water, where subsidiary's board rarely met in person and decided almost everything by unanimous consent of recommendation provided by higher functional reporting level outside its legal boundaries, parent centralized uniform marketing in which it represented that its mark was single-integrated globally managed entity, personnel technically employed by one entity within corporate family actually functioned as if they were employed by parent for use of entire group of companies, global managers exercised high degree of control over herbicide's production, and parent maintained general oversight of compensation packages and settlement of legal proceedings.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Swiss parent of American herbicide manufacturer was subject to personal jurisdiction in United States.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Hydroxycut Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Weight loss supplement seller's subsidiary was its "agent," for purposes of imputing subsidiary's minimum contacts with state to seller so as to allow court to exercise personal jurisdiction over seller in consolidated multi-state consumer protection lawsuits, even though seller claimed it was merely a holding company, where seller was in the business of developing and selling diet and nutritional supplements, its subsidiary played essential role in carrying out this business, but for subsidiary, seller itself would have had to perform functions such as development, marketing, and distribution of the products, and seller, through its sole director and officer exerted day-to-day operational control over subsidiary by providing working capital, and by reviewing new products, formulas, product packaging, advertising, daily sales, and product promotions to extent that subsidiary could be deemed an incorporated division of seller.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary was an agent of its parent company, for purposes of imputing its minimum contacts with state to parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Hydroxycut Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under either Delaware or California law, weight loss supplement seller's subsidiary was its "alter ego," for purposes of imputing subsidiary's minimum contacts with states to seller, as parent, so as to allow court to exercise personal jurisdiction over it in consolidated consumer protection lawsuits; even though parent and subsidiary did not disregard corporate formalities by commingling records or funds, and although subsidiary was not under capitalized, parent company dominated and controlled subsidiary to extent that subsidiary was a mere conduit for parent's sales operations through its financing of subsidiary, control of its day-to-day operations, and control of its profits, and parent had acted in bad faith by changing its name to that of a holding company, in order to hide behind its corporate form, on same day that Food and Drug Administration (FDA) concluded that supplement products presented a severe potentially life-threatening hazard to some users.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary was an agent of its parent company, for purposes of imputing its minimum contacts with state to parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Verizon Trademark Services, LLC v. Producers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, personal jurisdiction over Florida parent corporation will not equate to personal jurisdiction over subsidiary, unless subsidiary is merely alter ego or mere instrumentality of parent corporation, over which court does have personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Jurisdiction. Internet domain name registration service provider was not subject to specific personal jurisdiction in Florida.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Rasmussen v. General Motors Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Japanese automobile manufacturing company did not have control over its United States subsidiary sufficient to allow the court to disregard the separate corporate identities of the nonresident parent and the subsidiary and impute the acts of the subsidiary to the parent for purposes of asserting general personal jurisdiction over Japanese parent company; parent did not have complete control or domination of subsidiary, requisite corporate formalities were observed, there was no showing that subsidiary did not exercise independent decision-making, there was no showing that corporate legal requirements were not followed, and there was no showing of fraud or undercapitalization. W.S.A. 801.05.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Circuit court lacked personal jurisdiction over Japanese automobile manufacturing company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Haley Paint Co. v. E.I. Dupont De Nemours and Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Because it is generally the case that the contacts of a subsidiary cannot impute jurisdiction to its parent entity, the test for determining whether a subsidiary is an agent of the parent corporation revolves around determining whether the corporate veil between the two entities should be pierced.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Personal jurisdiction over parent corporation was not warranted under Maryland's agency test.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Haley Paint Co. v. E.I. Dupont De Nemours and Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, the agency test allows a court to attribute the actions or contacts of a subsidiary corporation to the foreign parent corporation for purposes of personal jurisdiction only if the parent exerts considerable control over the activities of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Personal jurisdiction over parent corporation was not warranted under Maryland's agency test.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Comprehensive general liability insurer had sufficient control over subsidiary to impute subsidiary's contacts to insurer for purposes of general personal jurisdiction over insurer in multidistrict litigation (MDL) arising out of alleged damage caused by Chinese drywall; insurer owned 100% of subsidiary, insurer and subsidiary shared administrative office, subsidiary and insurer shared officers and most trustees, insurer and subsidiary shared common office, contact information, website, statutory statement contact, storage, and employees, insurer and subsidiary shared accounting system, filed consolidated tax return, used same accounting and actuary consulting firms, and investment advisor, insurer's financial strength ratings factored into subsidiary's rating, insurer's wholly owned subsidiary provided staff and general management services for insurer and subsidiary, insurer reinsured 100% of subsidiary's claims and losses, subsidiary ceded 100% of its premium to insurer, and subsidiary's insurance policies were transferred to insurer.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Jurisdiction. Exercise of general personal jurisdiction over insurer in multidistrict litigation (MDL) was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: WH Smith, PLC v. Benages & Associates, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Subsidiaries were not mere instrumentalities or alter egos of foreign parent company, which was public limited company (PLC) organized under the laws of England and Wales, and thus judgment creditor of subsidiaries could not pierce the corporate veil, for purposes of establishing long-arm jurisdiction under alter-ego theory, though parent company made all significant decisions for subsidiaries, and though subsidiaries and parent company shared one director at various times; subsidiaries leased their own offices, maintained their own bank accounts, had hundreds of retail units and thousands of employees, and had separate management, board of directors, and officers.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not alter egos of foreign parent company, for purposes of establishing long-arm jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: WH Smith, PLC v. Benages & Associates, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Alleged conduct of parent company, which was public limited company (PLC) organized under the laws of England and Wales, in instructing subsidiaries to breach agreement with consulting company, without more, did not constitute type of "improper conduct" necessary to pierce the corporate veil, for purposes of establishing long-arm jurisdiction under the alter ego theory.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not alter egos of foreign parent company, for purposes of establishing long-arm jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Curtis v. Altria Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Parent company was not subject to vicarious personal jurisdiction due to actions of wholly-owned subsidiary tobacco company for purposes of class action alleging false advertising; there was no evidence that parent company was or ever had been involved in day-to-day control over production of distribution of subsidiary's products.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Plaintiffs satisfied public-benefit requirement of private attorney general statute in class action against tobacco company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Curtis v. Altria Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Ordinary supervision of a subsidiary by a parent corporation is not sufficient to extend personal jurisdiction over the subsidiary to the parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Plaintiffs satisfied public-benefit requirement of private attorney general statute in class action against tobacco company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: IMark Marketing Services, LLC v. Geoplast S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, Italian parent demonstrated active and substantial control over its American subsidiary, such that entities had unity of interest and control, and thus subsidiary's contacts with District were attributable to parent for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over it, where subsidiary was wholly-owned by parent, parent represented to potential clients that subsidiary was its United States branch, companies used identical logos and trademarks, companies shared website content, parent's managing director was subsidiary's president and sole director, subsidiary did not maintain separate bank account, and parent paid subsidiary's expenses.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary's contacts were attributable to parent for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over it.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Moncrief Oil Intern., Inc. v. OAO Gazprom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: For a parent company and its subsidiary to be fused for jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiffs must prove the parent company controls the internal business operations and affairs of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have jurisdiction over Russian natural gas company, in trade secret and tortious interference action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Moncrief Oil Intern., Inc. v. OAO Gazprom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: In order for a parent company and a subsidiary to be fused for jurisdictional purposes, the degree of control the parent company exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have jurisdiction over Russian natural gas company, in trade secret and tortious interference action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Moncrief Oil Intern., Inc. v. OAO Gazprom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: United Kingdom marketing subsidiary of Russian oil and natural gas company was not the alter ego of, and thus could not for jurisdictional purposes be fused with, resident company that operated liquefied natural gas (LNG) regasification facility, in misappropriation of trade secrets and tortious interference action that Texas oil and natural gas company brought against Russian company, marketing subsidiary and resident company, absent evidence of the corporate formalities existing between the marketing subsidiary and the resident company. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have jurisdiction over Russian natural gas company, in trade secret and tortious interference action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Moncrief Oil Intern., Inc. v. OAO Gazprom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: So long as a parent corporation and a subsidiary maintain a degree of corporate separation that is more than superficial and the policy-making authority held and exercised by the parent is no more than that appropriate for a sole shareholder of a corporation, this exercise of control is not enough to warrant jurisdiction over the nonresident corporation through the resident corporation. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Courts did not have jurisdiction over Russian natural gas company, in trade secret and tortious interference action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: General jurisdiction over a local subsidiary extends to the foreign parent under an alter ego theory, general principles of agency, or under the representative services doctrine, a narrow species of agency. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: In the context of general jurisdiction over a nonresident parent company based on an agency relationship with a local subsidiary, an agency is proved by evidence that the entity for whom the work was performed had the right to control the activities of the alleged agent. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Agency supports the imputation of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent company only when the control exercised over the local subsidiary is so pervasive and continual that the subsidiary is just a means through which the parent acts, or nothing more than an incorporated department of the parent. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: For agency to support the imputation of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent company, the parent's general executive control is not enough, and the parent must in effect take over performance of the subsidiary's day-to-day operations in carrying out the parent's policy. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: The representative services doctrine does not depend on whether the parent enjoys pervasive and continuous control over the subsidiary as to establish a general agency relationship, to support the imputation of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent company. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Under the representative services doctrine, general jurisdiction may be exercised over a foreign parent corporation when the local agent essentially exists only to further the business of the parent, and but for the local agent's existence, the parent would be performing those functions in the forum itself. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: The representative services doctrine supports the exercise of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent company when the local subsidiary performs a function that is compatible with, and assists the parent in the pursuit of, the parent's own business, but the doctrine does not support jurisdiction where the parent is merely a holding company whose only business pursuit is the investment in the subsidiary. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Evidence of English parent company's branding on subsidiary's signage, uniforms, and stationery was not substantial evidence supporting trial court's finding that parent company was not a holding company, in finding that it was subject to personal jurisdiction under the representative services doctrine. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: While the representative services doctrine is applied separately from general jurisdiction based on agency, the doctrine still requires a showing of a high level of control such that the subsidiary is just an instrumentality of the parent's own business. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Even assuming employer's English parent company was not a holding company, employee failed to prove that employer did not pursue its own business and only operated for the benefit of parent company, as required for the representative services doctrine to support general jurisdiction over the parent company, where employer's president stated that employer was the sole owner of its licenses and products, and employee produced no evidence to the contrary. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Under a general agency theory of jurisdiction, the nature of the control exercised by the parent over the subsidiary necessary to put the subsidiary in an agency relationship with the parent must be over and above that to be expected as an incident of the parent's ownership of the subsidiary and must reflect the parent's purposeful disregard of the subsidiary's independent corporate existence. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BBA Aviation PLC v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Former employee failed to demonstrate that employer's English parent company exercised pervasive and continuous control over employer's day-to-day operations that went beyond the normal parent-subsidiary relationship, as required for a general agency theory of jurisdiction to apply, even though the two companies had officers and directors in common, parent company's logo appeared on employer's documents, and parent company provided benefit plan to employer's employees, where statements by employer's president demonstrated that employer had its own corporate officers, human resources staff, and financial personnel, employer's president stated that his title as president of parent company's "component, repair, and overhaul group" did not establish any formal legal position within parent company, and employer's president stated that parent company's chief executive officer (CEO) visited employer only twice in several years. West's Ann.Cal.C.C.P. § 410.10.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Representative services doctrine did not support general jurisdiction over employer's parent company.

Title: JL Schwieters Const., Inc. v. Goldridge Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Non-resident corporation may be subject to jurisdiction in a state by virtue of its subsidiary's activities in that state if the companies are organized and operated so that the subsidiary is an instrumentality or alter ego of the parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Non-resident developer was subject to personal jurisdiction in mechanic's lien foreclosure action.

Title: Southern New England Telephone Co. v. Global NAPs Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under either Connecticut law or federal common law of veil piercing, plaintiff's allegations that corporate defendant's affiliates were operated as a single economic unit and that the same parent corporation dominated and controlled those entities were sufficient to bring the parent corporation and the affiliates within district court's personal jurisdiction in action seeking payment for services rendered pursuant to a federal tariff.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. District court had jurisdiction over ILEC's action seeking payment for services rendered pursuant to federal tariff.

Title: Southern New England Telephone Co. v. Global NAPs Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, plaintiff's allegations that corporate defendant's parent company structured its subsidiaries such that those companies that incurred liabilities were also those without assets to satisfy them was sufficient to show improper use of the corporate form necessary to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over the subsidiaries under veil piercing theory.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. District court had jurisdiction over ILEC's action seeking payment for services rendered pursuant to federal tariff.

Title: In re Enterprise Rent-A-Car Wage & Hour Employment Practices Litigation
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania operating subsidiary of Missouri parent company was not its alter ego, thereby precluding court's exercise of in personam jurisdiction over parent; sharing by corporations of directors and ownership by parent of 100% of subsidiary's stock did not implicate that parent controlled subsidiary to extent necessary to be alter ego, common marketing image and joint use of trademarked logos did not render subsidiary and parent as alter egos, use of integrated sales system and use of services from parent's information technology and human resources departments were not sufficient, and parent did not exercise any control over internal workings or day-to-day operations of its subsidiary.

Title: MMI, Inc. v. Baja, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, a plaintiff may pierce the corporate veil and overcome the legal distinction between a parent holding company and its subsidiary or licensee for purposes of personal jurisdiction (1) if the parent company is merely an alter ego of the subsidiary created to shield the subsidiary from litigation in an unfavorable forum or (2) if the subsidiary is the general agent of the parent in the forum.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Motion Practice. License agreement fell within definition of trade secret, thus favoring finding good cause to seal that document.
