Title: MMI, Inc. v. Baja, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Holding company that merely licensed its trade name and service mark to licensee subsidiary was not alter ego of subsidiary under Arizona law, for purposes of personal jurisdiction in patent infringement action, although they had common address and ownership.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Motion Practice. License agreement fell within definition of trade secret, thus favoring finding good cause to seal that document.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Drake v. Ocwen Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Borrower failed to argue that the corporate lender and its subsidiary commingled their funds or assets since the subsidiary was fully capitalized, and thus, the court lacked personal jurisdiction over the corporation. The borrower sued the subsidiary, which had modified the borrower loan, and the corporation, which wholly owned the subsidiary, for alleged disclosure violations. The borrower alleged that Illinois had personal jurisdiction over the corporation, which was a Florida corporation that maintained offices in Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, and New York, since it was the alter ego of the subsidiary. He alleged that the subsidiary and the corporation shared the same business address. However, the borrower failed to argue that the corporation treated the assets of the subsidiary as its own or that both the corporation and subsidiary failed to maintain adequate corporate records or failed to comply with corporate formalities. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2-209(b) (4), (a)(1).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Borrower failed to allege that corporation and its subsidiary commingled their funds or assets.

Title: Gallelli v. Crown Imports, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: While common ownership between a parent corporation and its alleged department is essential to a finding that the subsidiary is a mere department of its parent, in the analysis for personal jurisdiction over the parent under New York law, the remaining factors must thereafter be considered to determine the outcome of the inquiry. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Holding company did not exercise pervasive control over subsidiary corporations

Title: Gallelli v. Crown Imports, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Jurisdiction under New York law based upon an agency theory requires a plaintiff to show that a subsidiary does all the business which a parent corporation could do were it here by its own officials; the agent's activities in New York must be important enough to the foreign parent corporation that in the absence of an agent, the named defendant would undertake to perform substantially similar services. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Holding company did not exercise pervasive control over subsidiary corporations

Title: Gallelli v. Crown Imports, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: When considering issue of agency for personal jurisdiction under New York law, a court considers whether a subsidiary is carrying out its own business, or the business of a parent. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Holding company did not exercise pervasive control over subsidiary corporations

Title: Gallelli v. Crown Imports, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: A subsidiary of a holding company carries on its business as an investment of the holding company, and not as an agent of the holding company, for personal jurisdiction purposes under New York law. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Holding company did not exercise pervasive control over subsidiary corporations

Title: Gallelli v. Crown Imports, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Holding company did not exercise pervasive control over subsidiary corporations that brewed and distributed beer, as required for personal jurisdiction over company under New York law in action by parents of child injured by exploding beer bottle, even though company's major asset was stock of corporations responsible for bottling and distribution, where there was no common ownership between company and subsidiaries, subsidiaries were not financially dependent on holding company, and holding company adhered to corporate formalities in dealings with subsidiaries. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.

Title: Gallelli v. Crown Imports, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary corporations were not agents of holding company, as required for personal jurisdiction over holding company under New York law in action by parents of child injured by exploding beer bottle allegedly brewed, bottled and imported by company's subsidiaries, where business of subsidiaries was beer brewing and distribution, and business of holding company was investment. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.

Title: Patterson v. Home Depot, USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: When a defendant has a wholly-owned subsidiary that possesses minimum contacts, the subsidiary's contacts may be imputed to the defendant if the plaintiff demonstrates that the subsidiary acted as an alter-ego or general agent of the defendant.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Purposeful availment requirement for specific jurisdiction was met, based on stream of commerce theory.

Title: Gordon v. Greenview Hosp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: Status of non-resident corporation, that owned and operated hospital in Kentucky, as a subsidiary of two Tennessee corporations, was insufficient to justify exercise of personal jurisdiction over corporation in medical malpractice action, absent showing that either parent corporation had complete control of subsidiary, such that subsidiary was nothing more than an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of the parent corporation. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; West's T.C.A. Const. Art. 1, § 8; West's T.C.A. § 20–2–214(a); Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 12.02(2).
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Presence of hospital's director's offices in Tennessee was insufficient to justify exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Title: Gordon v. Greenview Hosp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: A parent corporation's general involvement with subsidiary corporation's performance, finance and budget decisions, and general policies and procedures does not provide a basis for attributing one corporation's contacts with the forum to the other for the purposes of personal jurisdiction.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Presence of hospital's director's offices in Tennessee was insufficient to justify exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Title: Gordon v. Greenview Hosp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: As an alternative to asserting jurisdiction over a subsidiary corporation on the alter ego theory, jurisdiction may exist over a subsidiary corporation based on the actions of the parent corporation when there is an agency relationship between the two.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Presence of hospital's director's offices in Tennessee was insufficient to justify exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Global manufacturer and producer of chocolate confectionary products did not have sufficient control over its Canadian indirectly owned operating subsidiary required for District Court to exercise general personal jurisdiction over subsidiary, via "alter ego" theory, in plaintiffs' antitrust class actions claiming that candy producers conspired to fix prices in domestic market in violation of Sherman Act and various state antitrust and consumer protection statutes; although global manufacturer controlled subsidiary's stock, subsidiary was business unit of global manufacturer, manufacturer profited from dividends and capital repatriations from subsidiary, established group-wide accounting protocols, approved executive compensation and large capital expenditures, and acquisitions of raw materials, those facts typified standard parent-subsidiary interactions but did not reflect daily, operational control required for alter ego relationship, as subsidiary retained its own senior officers who did not supervise employees of manufacturer's other entities, subsidiary produced and distributed several products that were not widely available in United States, developed promotional materials and implemented marketing campaigns without input from other affiliated entities, and set prices at which it sold prices to Canadian distributors and managed its production facilities without global manufacturer's oversight. Sherman Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Monopolies. District Court could exercise general personal jurisdiction, under alter ego theory, over British based chocolate company.

Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: United States subsidiary was not so controlled by its parent, a Switzerland-based global manufacturer and producer of chocolate confectionary products, such that District Court could exercise general personal jurisdiction over Swiss-based global manufacturer via "alter ego" theory, in plaintiffs' antitrust class actions claiming that candy producers conspired to fix prices in domestic market in violation of Sherman Act and various state antitrust and consumer protection statutes; although plaintiff sought to aggregate activities of various entities of group of companies related to global manufacturer and producer, global manufacturer did not domineer daily affairs of United States subsidiary through its purported corporate conduits, and subsidiary exercised significant degree of autonomy over its daily affairs. Sherman Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Monopolies. District Court could exercise general personal jurisdiction, under alter ego theory, over British based chocolate company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: United States subsidiary was sufficiently controlled by its parent corporations, United Kingdom-based global manufacturers and producers of chocolate confectionary products, such that District Court could exercise general personal jurisdiction over British corporations, via "alter ego" theory, in plaintiffs' antitrust class actions claiming that candy producers conspired to fix prices in domestic market in violation of Sherman Act and various state antitrust and consumer protection statutes; parent corporations vertically managed entire group through business units aligned with product groups rather than corporate boundaries, chief executive officer's committee (CEC) met regularly to assess corporate affairs, implement global strategy for all subsidiaries, and control daily functions of operating entities to exclusion of their boards of directors. Sherman Act, § 1, 15 U.S.C.A. § 1.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Monopolies. District Court could exercise general personal jurisdiction, under alter ego theory, over British based chocolate company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Canadian corporation named as defendant in Sherman Act action arising out of alleged attempts to fix prices for chocolate confectionary products was not alter ego of its United States corporate parent, and district court could not exercise general personal jurisdiction over it on alter ego theory, though corporate parent was entitled to ordain Canadian subsidiary's officers and directors, influence executive compensation, approve budgets, gather information regarding corporate performance, and receive distributions of subsidiary profits, and though it issued group-wide accounting, finance, and sales protocols through its finance and recurring reports manuals; manuals encouraged subsidiaries to vary manner in which corporate principles were applied in practice, and subsidiary had significant control, for example, as to how it paid dividends and repatriated capital. Sherman Act, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise personal jurisdiction over foreign corporate parents on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Swiss corporation named as defendant in Sherman Act action arising out of alleged attempts to fix prices for chocolate confectionary products was not alter ego of American subsidiary, as required for district court to exercise general personal jurisdiction over it on alter ego theory, though Swiss corporation, acting through other downstream corporate entities, formulated guidelines and best practices to govern subsidiary's operations, collected financial data from subsidiary through management letters and through integrated computer information system, and exercised control over officers of subsidiary; subsidiary exercised significant autonomy by maintaining its own production facilities, purchasing raw materials through contracts to which Swiss parent was not a party, formulating its own budget, and establishing its own administrative policies. Sherman Act, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 1 et seq.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise personal jurisdiction over foreign corporate parents on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: D'Jamoos ex rel. Estate of Weingeroff v. Pilatus Aircraft Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: As all corporations must necessarily act through agents, a wholly owned subsidiary may be an agent, and when its activities as an agent are of such a character as to amount to doing business of the parent, the parent is subjected to the in personam jurisdiction of the state in which the activities occurred.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Jurisdiction. Swiss aircraft manufacturer lacked minimum contacts with Pennsylvania for exercise of specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts will, in certain circumstances, exercise general personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent corporation based upon its relationship with a local subsidiary; such an exercise of jurisdiction is proper where a subsidiary corporation is acting as the parent corporation's Illinois agent in the sense of conducting the parent's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Because parents of wholly owned subsidiary corporations necessarily control and direct the activities of the subsidiaries to some extent, Illinois courts will not permit the exercise of personal jurisdiction over a subsidiary's nonresident parent simply because it is the parent; the critical question is whether the Illinois subsidiary exists for no purpose other than conducting the business of its parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The existence of common officers of both a nonresident parent corporation and its resident subsidiary, without more, is not sufficient to permit an exercise of personal jurisdiction of a parent corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Canadian parent corporation of entity that guaranteed American subsidiary's commercial lease for men's clothing store did not so dominate and control subsidiary and guarantor that subsidiary and guarantor were "agents" of parent, as would allow Illinois court to exercise specific personal jurisdiction over parent in lessor's action to enforce guaranty, even though parent procured initial funding for all of its American subsidiaries and had same officers and directors; parent and subsidiaries were engaged in separate, distinct business ventures, as parent sold variety of styles and brands of menswear and subsidiaries sold only one brand, licensing agreement rather than parent controlled subsidiaries' marketing and sales, and parent had refused to guaranty lease payments.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The determinative question for specific jurisdiction over nonresident parent corporation based on agency theory is whether the parent corporation is simply attempting to shield itself from lawsuits by conducting its own business through the legal fiction of "separate" subsidiaries and distribution networks.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Canadian parent corporation of entity that guaranteed American subsidiary's commercial lease for men's clothing store was not "alter ego" of guaranty or subsidiary, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil and allow Illinois court to exercise specific personal jurisdiction over parent in lessor's action to enforce guaranty; guarantor and subsidiary observed corporate formalities, held their own substantial inventory and assets, and conducted their own business separate from Canadian parent, subsidiaries remained solvent and continued to pay their bills, including rent under the lease, until parent decided to sell them and get out of American market, and parent had refused to guarantee lease.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: No single factor is dispositive when determining applicability of alter ego doctrine for jurisdictional purposes, and the court may consider all relevant evidence to determine whether the parent exercises actual control over a subsidiary beyond that which is characteristic of a usual parent-subsidiary relationship.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Jurisdiction. Plaintiffs failed to establish prima facie showing of purposeful availment jurisdiction over foreign chocolate manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Chocolate Confectionary Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Alter ego jurisdiction does not attach merely because a parent corporation participates in its subsidiary's business.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Jurisdiction. Plaintiffs failed to establish prima facie showing of purposeful availment jurisdiction over foreign chocolate manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Western States Wholesale Natural Gas Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Nonprofit organizations failed to establish a prima facie case of personal jurisdiction based on subsidiaries being a parent corporation's alter ego. A subsidiary's contacts may be imputed to its parent for personal jurisdiction purposes upon a showing that the two companies shared such unity of interest and ownership that the companies' separateness no longer existed and failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice. The companies did not share offices and had only one overlapping officer or director. The parent did not make financial guarantees on the subsidiaries' behalf. The companies maintained separate books and records. Although the subsidiaries were permitted to use the parent trade name and service marks, they had to pay a royalty fee to do so.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Jurisdiction. Subsidiaries were not alter egos of parent corporation for personal jurisdiction purposes as the companies had separate books and only one overlapping...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Capital Technology Information Services, Inc. v. Arias & Arias Consultores
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Wholly-owned subsidiary was controlled by, was "fused" with, and thus, was alter ego of Maryland parent corporation, as required for exercise of jurisdiction over subsidiary corporation; corporations had same chief executive officer (CEO) and chairman, who believed and stated the entities were functionally the same for purposes of private placement offering, subsidiary's personnel performed corporation's contracts, corporation was maker of note to escrow agent but note was for subsidiary's benefit, and CEO caused subsidiary to make monthly payments on note.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Personal jurisdiction could be exercised over wholly-owned subsidiary fused with its parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: EBG Holdings LLC v. Vredezicht's Gravenhage 109 B.V.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to establish basis to apply alter ego theory and treat investment subsidiary, which was member of Delaware limited liability company (LLC), as alter ego of its foreign parent corporation, making parent subject to personal jurisdiction in LLC's breach of contract suit against investment subsidiary and parent, despite evidence that they shared offices, officers, and letterheads; fraud or other inequity was not present, investment subsidiary was investment vehicle with other assets besides LLC membership, and it observed corporate formalities like filing separate tax returns and maintaining separate books and records.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Evidence was insufficient to apply alter ego theory to investment subsidiary of foreign bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Sprint Nextel Corp. v. iPCS, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Delaware court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over nonresident affiliates of telecommunication company, which affiliates were subsidiary companies of Delaware parent company, under the agency theory.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Long-arm statute did not give personal jurisdiction over telecommunication affiliates.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Capital Finance & Commerce AG v. Sinopec Overseas Oil & Gas, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's implied finding of fact at hearing on special appearances that nonresident parent corporation of surviving corporation and nonresident holder representative of acquired corporation's shareholders did not have joint control over undistributed proceeds of merger transaction to the extent necessary to support brokerage company's imputed-contacts allegations, when court determined whether it had special jurisdiction over parent corporation and holder representative in action by company alleging that parent corporation and holder representative conspired to fraudulently deprive company of finder's fee owed for finding a purchaser for the acquired corporation; escrow agreement strictly limited nonresidents' access to the escrow account in which the undistributed proceeds were deposited to breaches of acquired corporation's warranties and claims by equity holders of the acquired corporation. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code §§ 17.041-17.045.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Court had no jurisdiction over nonresident entities in action by broker alleging conspiracy to deprive it of finder's fee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Capital Finance & Commerce AG v. Sinopec Overseas Oil & Gas, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support trial court's implied finding of fact at hearing on special appearance that nonresident parent corporation of surviving corporation was not the alter ego of surviving corporation and thus that the trial court did not have special jurisdiction over the nonresident parent corporation, in action by brokerage company alleging that parent corporation conspired with others to fraudulently deprive brokerage company of finder's fee owed by corporation acquired in merger for finding a purchaser for the acquired corporation; none of the witnesses who testified at the hearing testified that they had a relationship with, took directions from or reporting to nonresident parent corporation, and none of the terms of the merger documents demonstrated that parent corporation controlled surviving corporation. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code §§ 17.041-17.045.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Court had no jurisdiction over nonresident entities in action by broker alleging conspiracy to deprive it of finder's fee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Greenfield Energy, Inc. v. Duprey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Foreign parent corporation and its sole shareholder did not control the internal business operations and affairs of its subsidiaries and thus did not serve as the alter ego of the subsidiaries for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' jurisdictional contacts to parent or shareholder in energy companies' action regarding oil and gas drilling property, although parent corporation owned the property while subsidiaries pursued the development of the property; companies had independent management, boards of directors, and accounting practices, subsidiaries had different chief executive officer than parent, there was no overlap between the daily operations of the parent and the subsidiaries, entities filed separate tax returns, kept separate accounts, and had separate home offices, and subsidiaries were not operating on behalf of parent when negotiating regarding the property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiaries did not serve as parent corporations's agents for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' jurisdictional contacts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Greenfield Energy, Inc. v. Duprey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Foreign parent corporation's subsidiaries did not serve as parent's agents for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' jurisdictional contacts to parent corporation and its sole shareholder in energy companies' action arising out of drilling rights to foreign oil and gas property owned by parent corporation, where parent corporation did not exert control over the details of subsidiaries' work, there were no written or spoken words which indicated either actual or apparent authority, and parent corporation did not ratify subsidiaries' activities in pursuing development of the property but rather ultimately transferred the rights to the property to one of the subsidiaries.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiaries did not serve as parent corporations's agents for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' jurisdictional contacts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Dewey v. Volkswagen AG
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, service on a wholly owned subsidiary confers jurisdiction over the foreign parent only if the subsidiary is an alter ego or agent of the parent.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. United States subsidiary was an agent by law of manufacturer for purpose of service of process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Sehringer v. Big Lots, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, foreign parent corporation is not subject to jurisdiction of forum state merely because subsidiary is doing business there, unless subsidiary is merely agent through which parent company conducts business in particular jurisdiction or its separate corporate status is formal only and without any semblance of individual identity. West's F.S.A. § 48.193.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Exercise of specific personal jurisdiction over parent corporation did not violate due process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: PHC-Minden, L.P. v. Kimberly-Clark Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Louisiana hospital and its parent company did not operate as single business enterprise such that parent's contacts with Texas could be imputed to hospital, for purposes of establishing general jurisdiction over hospital on defendant tampon manufacturer's third-party medical malpractice claim against hospital, in context of action against manufacturer brought by representative of consumer's estate for products liability and other claims; parent and hospital maintained separate headquarters, hospital's board of governors approved budget and oversaw day-to-day operations of hospital, two entities did not share directors, and although some of hospital's officers and employees received paychecks and insurance benefits from parent, those salaries and benefits were paid from monies derived from hospital revenues. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Louisiana hospital and its parent company did not operate as single business enterprise such that parent's contacts with Texas could be imputed to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Crum & Forster Specialty Ins. Co. v. Extended Stay America, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Nonresident subsidiaries that owned chain hotels located in their respective states were not subject to general personal jurisdiction under the long-arm statute on basis of parent conducting business in the state as mere conduit of subsidiaries, where subsidiaries existed as separate corporate and legal entities, and each subsidiary maintained its own books, filed its own tax returns and kept separate financial statements. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2-209.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Jurisdiction. Nonresident subsidiaries of hotel chain were not subject to the general personal jurisdiction of an Illinois court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: City of Moundridge v. Exxon Mobil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: General jurisdiction may be exercised under District of Columbia's long-arm statute over corporation based on its subsidiaries' contacts where its subsidiaries are mere alter egos and have sufficient contacts with district to permit general jurisdiction over them.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Municipalities alleging that energy company violated antitrust laws were not entitled to conduct jurisdictional discovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Anchia v. DaimlerChrysler AG
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that German automobile manufacturer did not control subsidiary, who had the right to import, distribute and advertise manufacturer's vehicles, or the distribution system that brought the vehicles to state, for the purpose of establishing jurisdiction over manufacturer in owners' action against manufacturer that alleged the front bumpers of manufacturer's cars were defective; attorney for manufacturer stated in an affidavit that manufacturer sold the vehicles to subsidiary in Germany, that even though subsidiary was an indirect subsidiary of manufacturer both subsidiary and manufacturer were independent companies and strictly observed all corporate formalities, and manufacturer did not exercise any day to day control over subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Evidence that subsidiary was wholly owned by manufacturer was insufficient to establish manufacturer controlled subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Asshauer v. Glimcher Realty Trust
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Nonresident defendants, a corporation, a limited partnership and a limited liability company, were not a single business enterprise as might subject them to personal jurisdiction in Texas given that a subsidiary of the corporation owned commercial properties in Texas; there was no evidence showing undocumented transfers of funds, unclear allocation of profits and losses, or other lack of corporate distinctness between the defendants.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendants did not have sufficient minimum contacts with Texas so as to enable personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Davey v. Shaw
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory, personal jurisdiction may be established by imputing the jurisdictional contacts of a corporate entity to its owners or parent corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Alter ego theory could not be applied to confer personal jurisdiction over nonresident corporate and individual defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: First Horizon Merchant Services, Inc. v. Wellspring Capital Management, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. II.
Headnote: The objective of either the agency or alter ego theory, in a dispute concerning personal jurisdiction over a parent corporation, is to establish that the parent corporation has the minimum contacts with the forum necessary to support a finding of jurisdiction.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Letters, telephone call and presentation were sufficient contacts to subject bankrupt's CEO to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Klonis v. National Bank of Greece, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, domestic subsidiary is "department" of foreign parent corporation for jurisdictional purposes when activities of parent show disregard for separate corporate existence of subsidiary. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Jurisdiction. Greek bank was not doing business in New York for purposes of general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Klonis v. National Bank of Greece, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In assessing whether domestic subsidiary is "department" of foreign parent corporation for purposes of New York general jurisdictional statute, courts look to: (1) whether there is common ownership; (2) financial dependency of subsidiary on parent, (3) degree to which parent interferes in selection and assignment of subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formalities; and (4) degree of control over marketing and operational policies of subsidiary exercised by parent. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Jurisdiction. Greek bank was not doing business in New York for purposes of general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Cai v. DaimlerChrysler AG
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: To establish personal jurisdiction over parent corporation under alter ego theory based on subsidiary's contacts with forum, plaintiff must show that parent controls subsidiary to such degree as to render latter mere instrumentality of former.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. German employer was not subject to specific personal jurisdiction in Oregon in former employee's breach of contract suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gadea v. Star Cruises, Ltd.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Facts that cruise ship owner acquired subsidiary that did substantial business in Florida, installed subsidiary's top management, made public announcements that subsidiary was an extension of owner and a critical component of its global strategy, used subsidiary's Florida headquarters as booking agent, and advertised its cruises in subsidiary's brochures and listed subsidiary's reservation number as its contact number did not constitute substantial activity within Florida by owner so as to support the exercise of general jurisdiction over owner, where there was no evidence owner itself engaged in business activities in Florida, or that it acquired subsidiary in Florida. West's F.S.A. § 48.193(2).
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Business activity by cruise ship owner's subsidiary did not subject owner to general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gadea v. Star Cruises, Ltd.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Business activity in Florida by cruise ship owner's subsidiary could not form the basis for a finding of general jurisdiction over owner, even though owner and subsidiary shared some officers and directors and a common strategy, and subsidiary advertised owner's cruises in its brochures and took bookings and payment for owner's cruises, where subsidiary did not exist solely to serve owner, but rather had its own fleet of cruise ships that it operated. West's F.S.A. § 48.193(2).
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Business activity by cruise ship owner's subsidiary did not subject owner to general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gadea v. Star Cruises, Ltd.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Where a subsidiary manifests no separate interests of its own, but in effect functions only as an agent to achieve the purposes of the parent corporation, general jurisdiction over the foreign parent based on the activities of the subsidiary will be determined to exist. West's F.S.A. § 48.193(2).
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Business activity by cruise ship owner's subsidiary did not subject owner to general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Gadea v. Star Cruises, Ltd.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Fact that subsidiary of cruise ship owner contracted with Florida corporation did not expose owner to specific jurisdiction in Florida in an action arising out of such contract, where there was no evidence subsidiary functioned as owner's agent, either with respect to the contract or in general. West's F.S.A. § 48.193(1)(a).
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Business activity by cruise ship owner's subsidiary did not subject owner to general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Cappuccitti v. Gulf Indus. Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Evidence presented at special appearance hearing was sufficient to support trial court's finding that a mining chemicals distribution company over which the trial court had personal jurisdiction, and the company's owner and parent company, both nonresident defendants, were alter egos of each other such that piercing the corporate veil and exercising personal jurisdiction over the owner and parent company was justified; among other things, the evidence revealed that the owner had exercised complete control over both companies, owner had paid a debt of the distribution company with a personal check, and the owner and the two companies were used interchangeably to transfer assets from one to the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Texas court had personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant company owner and parent company under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: LinkAmerica Corp. v. Cox
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: The payment of subsidiary trucking company's legal fees by its parent company did not call into question the separateness of the two companies, and thus, trucking company's contacts with Indiana could not be attributed to parent company for purposes of exerting personal jurisdiction over parent company in truck driver's action; the payment of legal fees amounted to no more than an intercompany loan. Trial Procedure Rule 4.4(A).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Analysis of personal jurisdiction turned on whether exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with constitution.
