Title: LinkAmerica Corp. v. Cox
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Subsidiary trucking company that contracted with driver and company's parent were separate entities, and thus, trucking company's contacts with Indiana could not be attributed to parent company for purposes of exerting personal jurisdiction over parent company in truck driver's action, where each company maintained separate books, records, accounts, and corporate minutes, parent did not maintain an office or other place of business in Indiana, parent had no registered agent in Indiana, parent had no Indiana employees, parent did not pay taxes in Indiana, parent did not advertise in Indiana, parent had no real or personal property in Indiana, and parent never represented subsidiary as a department or division of parent. Trial Procedure Rule 4.4(A).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Analysis of personal jurisdiction turned on whether exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with constitution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Villagomez v. Rockwood Specialties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Though a nonresident corporation's subsidiaries' contacts in a forum state cannot be imputed to the parent corporation for jurisdictional purposes, i.e., the fact that the subsidiaries do business in the forum state does not mean that the parent does business in the forum state, the parent's ownership of the subsidiaries is a "forum contact" which, though it may not be enough for jurisdictional purposes, that can still be considered as a when determining whether parent corporation has sufficient contacts with the forum state such that assertion of general jurisdiction is proper. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Nonresident corporation's employment of Texas resident to oversee operations of Texas subsidiaries was a forum contact.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Resource Healthcare of America, Inc. v. McKinney
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Although the mere presence of a subsidiary in Florida, without more, does not subject a non-Florida corporate parent to long-arm jurisdiction, when a parent exercises sufficient control over a subsidiary, that control establishes an agency and supports jurisdiction. West's F.S.A. § 48.193.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Evidence did not establish long-arm jurisdiction over parent corporation of nursing home licensee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Lake v. Bayer Corp.
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut, Judicial District of Waterbury.
Headnote: Superior Court did not have personal jurisdiction over British subsidiary corporation in products liability action against German drug manufacturer and its British and American subsidiaries brought by United Kingdom citizen, alleging damages resulting from use of drug that was prescribed in the U.K., where there was no claim that British subsidiary transacted business in Connecticut, and there was no showing that the corporations failed to observe corporate formalities, or that British subsidiary had not existed as a separate entity from the other two entities. C.G.S.A. § 33-929(e, f).
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Venue. U.K. was not a more convenient forum for U.K. citizen's products liability claim, given obstacles posed by U.K. law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Carlson Mfg., Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: To "fuse" parent company and its subsidiary, for jurisdictional purposes, through application of alter ego doctrine in context of long-arm jurisdiction, plaintiffs must prove parent company controls internal business operations and affairs of subsidiary; degree of control parent exercises must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship, and evidence must show that two entities cease to be separate so that corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Long-arm jurisdiction could not be maintained over foreign corporation on theory of single business entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Carlson Mfg., Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Acts of deer stand seller in state could not be imputed to foreign corporation under alter ego theory to maintain long-arm jurisdiction over foreign corporation, in products liability action brought by deer hunter for injuries received in fall from tree-mounted deer stand; seller was not subsidiary of foreign corporation, there was no evidence foreign corporation controlled seller, and, while there was some evidence seller had parasitic existence on foreign corporation, there was no evidence that such arrangement was illegal or that companies failed to observe corporate formalities. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Long-arm jurisdiction could not be maintained over foreign corporation on theory of single business entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Alto Eldorado Partnership v. Amrep
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Liability under the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil and exercising personal jurisdiction over a nonresident corporation under an alter ego theory that attributes in-state contacts of the corporation's subsidiary to the corporation are different inquiries that focus on different principles and frequently on different bodies of law. (Per Kennedy, J., with one judge specially concurring.) West's NMSA § 38-1-16(A).
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise jurisdiction over foreign corporation in landowners' action against water utility subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Alto Eldorado Partnership v. Amrep
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Not all of the elements of alter ego need to be proven in order to hale a foreign corporate parent into court when a subsidiary of the parent is operating in New Mexico; instead a court can and will consider whatever elements a plaintiff shows in assessing minimum contacts. (Per Kennedy, J., with one judge specially concurring.) U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; West's NMSA § 38-1-16(A).
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise jurisdiction over foreign corporation in landowners' action against water utility subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: I & JC Corp. v. Helen of Troy L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that subsidiary company was the alter ego of parent company, thereby imputing its tortious conduct to parent company for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction in Texas; companies shared the same offices, address, telephone number, officers, directors, and shareholders, and financial operations of the companies were handled as one corporation. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.041 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Defendant companies were alter egos of the other, thereby imputing tortious conduct to the other for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Commonwealth ex rel. Pappert v. TAP Pharmaceuticals Products, Inc.
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Evidentiary facts asserted by Attorney General in response to nonresident pharmaceutical company's preliminary objections to personal jurisdiction were insufficient "minimum contacts" necessary for court to exercise personal jurisdiction under theory of veil piercing or alter ego, even though company owned 50% of subsidiary that operated in state marketing company's products; company could not exercise exclusive control over subsidiary. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; 42 Pa.C.S.A. § 5322.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. The state's complaint failed to adequately specify facts for each element of its claims against numerous drug companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Rains v. PPG Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Torts committed by subsidiary can result in parent's being subjected to personal jurisdiction under "commission of tortious act within this state" provision of Illinois long-arm statute only if there is basis for piercing corporate veil and thus attributing subsidiary's torts to parent. 735 ILCS 5/2-209(a)(2).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Doing business personal jurisdiction over foreign parent corporation required more than presence of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to establish general jurisdiction over nonresident corporations on the ground that they are mere alter egos of a resident subsidiary bears the burden of establishing a relationship between or among those entities that would justify doing so. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The mere existence of a parent-subsidiary relationship will not justify the disregard of the corporate fiction and exercise of jurisdiction over the nonresident parent; instead, to disregard the corporate separateness of parent and subsidiary for jurisdictional purposes, the plaintiff must prove the parent controls the internal business and affairs of the subsidiary. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: A court can impute a subsidiary's contacts to a nonresident parent and exercise general jurisdiction over the parent on alter ego grounds, where the parent corporation exerts such domination and control over its subsidiary that they do not in reality constitute separate and distinct corporate entities but are one and the same corporation for purposes of jurisdiction. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: One hundred percent stock ownership, commonality of officers and directors, and an exercise of control derived from stock ownership are not sufficient to establish an alter ego relationship and thus general jurisdiction over a nonresident parent. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Even proof of complete authority over general policy decisions of a subsidiary will not establish alter ego, for purposes of establishing general jurisdiction over a nonresident parent, unless the parent also controls the daily operations of the subsidiary. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Le Meridien Hotels & Resorts v. LaSalle Hotel Operating Partnership, I, L.P
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: General jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident parent corporations and affiliate of hotel lessee and operator based on alter-ego theory, in litigation between operator and hotel owner arising out of owner's exercise of option to purchase ownership interest in operator, though there were links between companies and examples of overlapping officers, employees and administrative services, as connections typical of a mere parent-subsidiary relationship could not justify the disregard of the corporate fiction, and record did not identify or evidence any fraud or injustice that would result from failure to join parent corporations and affiliate. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Specific jurisdiction could not be exercised over nonresident defendants in Meridien Hotel litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Seltzer v. I.C. Optics, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: New Jersey subsidiary of Italian parent company was not parent's alter ego, so as to permit imputation of subsidiary's New Jersey contacts to parent for personal jurisdiction purposes in former subsidiary employee's wrongful termination action, even though there were numerous contacts between parent and subsidiary's managers regarding subsidiary's operations and parent's executives exerted considerable influence and control over subsidiary; parent did not abuse relationship to perpetrate any criminal or tortious wrongdoing, and parent's activities did not deviate from normal control exercised by parent and did not amount to "dominance" since subsidiary maintained its own finances, offices and clients.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent's domestic subsidiary was not alter ego, thus parent was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Reers v. Deutsche Bahn AG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A corporate entity that is present in New York will be considered a mere department of a foreign parent, so as to expose the parent to personal jurisdiction in New York, only if the foreign parent's control is pervasive enough that the corporate separation is more formal than real. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Dismissal. Suit arising from train accident in France would be dismissed on forum non conveniens grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that Japanese tire manufacturer and its U.S. subsidiary had common personnel, as element of single business enterprise theory, thereby supporting the exercise of personal jurisdiction over manufacturer, in action against manufacturer and subsidiary alleging that defects in tire caused single-vehicle accident; evidence showed that corporations shared directors, ideas, and technology. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 13; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that Japanese tire manufacturer and its U.S. subsidiary shared common offices and facilities, as element of single business enterprise theory, which supported the exercise of personal jurisdiction over manufacturer, in action against manufacturer and subsidiary alleging that defects in tire caused single-vehicle accident; evidence showed that manufacturer had research and development operation based in Japan, and used proving grounds in forum state. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 13; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that Japanese tire manufacturer and its U.S. subsidiary had centralized accounting system and unclear allocation of profits and losses, thereby supporting the exercise of personal jurisdiction over manufacturer in Texas under single business enterprise theory, in action against manufacturer and subsidiary alleging that defects in tire caused single-vehicle accident; evidence showed that manufacturer amortized good will associated with subsidiary, provided for costs of recall of products sold in U.S., provided infusion of capital, provided relief for terrorist attacks in the U.S., and considered subsidiary's profits and losses as its own. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 13; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that Japanese tire manufacturer and its U.S. subsidiary supplied wages and services to one another, thereby supporting exercise of personal jurisdiction over manufacturer in Texas under single business enterprise theory, in action against manufacturer and subsidiary alleging that defects in tire caused single-vehicle accident; joint committee of both corporations oversaw rebuilding of U.S. brand, manufacturer assigned advisors to subsidiary, and it provided guidance on quality assurance. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 13; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence supported finding that Japanese tire manufacturer and its U.S. subsidiary shared common business name, thereby supporting exercise of personal jurisdiction in Texas under single business enterprise theory, in action against manufacturer and subsidiary alleging that defects in tire caused single-vehicle accident; subsidiary's name incorporated one word of manufacturer's name, annual financial report incorporated both names, and manufacturer's list of proving grounds on its website referred to those in the United States, under combined name. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 13; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Texas court's exercise of personal jurisdiction over Japanese tire manufacturer comported with fair play and substantial justice, as required under due process clause, although accident that gave rise to litigation occurred in Mexico; manufacturer and subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise, and manufacturer tested its tires at proving grounds in Texas. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; Vernon's Ann.Texas Const. Art. 1, § 13; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Zamarron v. Shinko Wire Company, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Foreign parent of corporations that did business in Texas was not the alter ego of subsidiaries, which did business in Texas, and was thus not subject to general jurisdiction in Texas, even though employees of parent occasionally visited Texas plant owned by subsidiaries, and even though parent approved sale of one subsidiary's assets; parent stated that it had no offices in common with subsidiaries and that daily operations of subsidiaries were kept separate from parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked general or specific jurisdiction over Japanese corporation in tort action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Hitachi Shin Din Cable, Ltd. v. Cain
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Nonresident manufacturer was not alter ego of its parent company, and thus court could not exercise general personal jurisdiction over manufacturer based on company's contacts with the state, in products-liability action, even though company retained copyright to manufacturer's web site, company referred to manufacturer in its annual financial report, and evidence indicated company directly or indirectly owned 50% of manufacturer's stock; there was no evidence that company's stock ownership gave it actual control over manufacturer's day-to-day operations and no showing of duplicate corporate officers, and Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filing did not list manufacturer as a subsidiary of company.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Nonresident defendant's web site did not support court's exercise of general personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Tsegaye v. Impol Aluminum Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary will be considered a "mere department" of foreign parent under New York statute permitting the general exercise of personal jurisdiction over a foreign corporation engaged in a continuous and systematic course of doing business in the state only if the foreign parent's control of the subsidiary is so pervasive that the corporate separation is more formal than real; four factors used in making this determination are 1) common ownership, which is essential, 2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent, 3) degree to which parent interferes in selection and assignment of subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formalities, and 4) degree of parent's control of subsidiary's marketing and operational policies. N.Y.McKinney's CPLR 301.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. New York did not have personal jurisdiction over foreign parent based on subsidiary's activities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Aviation Leasing Group v. Hyatt Corp.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Hotel developer failed to establish that hotel management corporation was "alter ego" of subsidiary of corporation's international arm, in order to demonstrate that subsidiary was doing business in state for purposes of jurisdiction, in developer's action claiming interference with contract and prospective economic advantage arising from subsidiary directly contracting with developer's agent to manage hotels abroad; there was no evidence that subsidiary had any presence in state, domestic corporation did not own stock in subsidiary, and there was no evidence of "manipulative conduct" by domestic corporation with regards to international corporation or its subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. An amended Doe" complaint did not relate back to the date of original filing."

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Johnson-Tanner v. First Cash Financial Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Unity of interest between parent corporation and subsidiary is established, for purposes of determining if subsidiary is alter ego of parent corporation, in analyzing existence of personal jurisdiction over parent corporation when it exists over subsidiary, if parent corporation had active and substantial control over subsidiary at the time of the alleged wrongful acts that form basis of lawsuit, but this control does not have to amount to actual day-to-day control or supervision. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. District Court had personal jurisdiction over parent corporation in employment discrimination action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Johnson-Tanner v. First Cash Financial Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Among the factors the district court is to consider in determining if subsidiary is alter ego of parent corporation, in analyzing existence of personal jurisdiction over parent corporation when it exists over subsidiary, are whether there was a failure to maintain separate corporate minutes or records, a failure to maintain corporate formalities, a commingling of funds or other assets, a diversion of one corporation's funds to the other's uses, the use of the same office or business location, and a joint accounting and payroll system, whether the subsidiary is operated as a mere division of the parent or exclusively in the interest of the parent, and whether there is a transfer of personnel back and forth between the parent corporation and its subsidiary. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. District Court had personal jurisdiction over parent corporation in employment discrimination action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Agency may confer general jurisdiction in the forum state over a foreign parent corporation due to its subsidiary, but only if the nature and extent of the control exercised is so pervasive and continual that the subsidiary may be considered nothing more than an agent of the parent, notwithstanding the separate corporate formalities; the nature of the parent's control over the subsidiary must be over and above that to be expected as an incident of the parent's ownership of the subsidiary, but must reflect the parent's purposeful disregard of the subsidiary's independent corporate existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: If a foreign parent corporation exercises such a degree of control over its subsidiary corporation that the subsidiary can legitimately be described as only a means through which the parent acts, or nothing more than an incorporated department of the parent, the subsidiary will be deemed to be the agent of the parent in the forum state and jurisdiction will extend to the parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Creditor's parent corporation, which was incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in Pennsylvania, was not subject to general jurisdiction in California in borrower's breach of contract action against creditor and parent corporation; there was no evidence that parent corporation was creditor's alter ego, there was no evidence that creditor performed a function compatible with and assisting parent corporation in parent corporation's business, parent corporation and creditor did not have agency relationship, and parent corporation did not do business in California.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: DVI, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Creditor's parent corporation, a Pennsylvania resident incorporated in Delaware, was not subject to specific jurisdiction in action by Oregon borrower for breach of loan agreement; there was no allegation that parent corporation was a party to the agreement, complaint mentioned no specific acts of wrongdoing by parent corporation, there was no evidence that parent corporation directed creditor to breach agreement, and creditor was not parent corporation's alter ego or agent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Foreign parent corporation of subsidiary was not subject to general jurisdiction in California.

Title: Hersey v. Lonrho, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Before a long arm statute can be utilized as a basis for the exercise of jurisdiction over the nonresident foreign corporation, the corporate veil must be pierced so that acts of the domestic subsidiary can be imputed to the absent parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil properly was not pierced for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Hersey v. Lonrho, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Corporate veil properly was not pierced, and as result, acts of subsidiary, which solicited business in Connecticut on behalf of hotel, properly were not imputed to its foreign parent corporation for purposes of asserting jurisdiction over nonresident parent with respect to slip and fall action brought by hotel guest; guest did not allege that parent exercised control over or dominated its subsidiary, parent did not provide any services to subsidiary, and although parent and its subsidiary had overlapping boards of directors, that alone was insufficient to establish parent's domination or control of subsidiary beyond that which was normal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil properly was not pierced for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BMC Software Belgium, N.V. v. Marchand
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Personal jurisdiction may exist over a nonresident defendant if the relationship between the foreign corporation and its parent corporation that does business in Texas is one in which the parent corporation exerts such domination and control over its subsidiary that they do not in reality constitute separate and distinct corporate entities but are one and the same corporation for purposes of jurisdiction, and the court can impute the parent corporation's doing business to the subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary of Houston based corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: BMC Software Belgium, N.V. v. Marchand
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Foreign subsidiary was not alter ego of Texas based parent corporation, for purposes of determining whether Texas courts had personal jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary, though parent corporation had a senior vice-president for worldwide marketing and corporations shared a letterhead, absent evidence that parent corporation considered subsidiary's revenue as its own, performed services for subsidiary that were not charged, offered subsidiary financial assistance, treated its subsidiary as a mere department or office, typically recruited, controlled or approved subsidiary's personnel, or typically compensated subsidiary's employees with stock options.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary of Houston based corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine applies, for purposes of determining whether a forum state has jurisdiction over a foreign parent corporation due to the activity of its subsidiary in the state, where the subsidiary is simply a conduit through which the parent conducts its business.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: In order for a forum state to exercise jurisdiction over a foreign parent corporation due to the activity of its subsidiary in the state, the degree of control exercised by the parent must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Operative question in jurisdictional analysis to determine whether corporate entities should be treated as one is whether subsidiary corporations are mere "divisions" or "branches" of larger whole, such that subsidiaries' contacts with Texas should be attributed to parent.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Evidence supported trial court's findings that Mexican parent corporations's Texas subsidiaries were mere "divisions" or "branches" of larger whole, such that subsidiaries' contacts with Texas could be attributed to parent; corporations worked together as interlocking whole with no formal barriers between management of entities and there was extensive overlapping of officers and directors.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Mexican parent corporation with subsidiaries doing business in Texas was subject to general jurisdiction of Texas courts based upon single business enterprise theory of jurisdiction where corporations shared common employees, utilized a central accounting system and provided services to each other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: "Alter ego" or agency relationship, as will allow imputing subsidiary's contacts with forum to non-resident parent for California personal jurisdiction purposes, is typified by parental control of subsidiary's internal affairs or daily operations. West's Ann.Cal.Civ.Code § 410.10.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Burmese plaintiffs did not show personal jurisdiction over French corporate defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Doe v. Unocal Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Agency test is satisfied, as will allow imputing subsidiaries' contacts with forum state to parent for purposes of establishing California jurisdiction, by showing that subsidiary functions as parent corporation's representative in that it performs services that are sufficiently important to foreign corporation that if it did not have representative to perform them, corporation's own officials would undertake to perform substantially similar services. West's Ann.Cal.Civ.Code § 410.10.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Burmese plaintiffs did not show personal jurisdiction over French corporate defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: In re Paques, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In addition to creating liability on part of corporate shareholder, piercing the corporate veil may also serve to provide personal jurisdiction over non-United States parent based upon activities of its United States subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise personal jurisdiction over debtor's foreign corporate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Nevada subsidiary corporation was not the alter ego of its Canadian parent corporation, as would allow corporate identity of subsidiary to be disregarded, and subsidiary's acts to be attributed to parent, in determining whether parent had sufficient minimum contacts with California to allow exercise of personal jurisdiction consistent with due process clause, where there was no evidence of any wrongdoing on part of either parent or subsidiary, or that any injustice flowed from recognition of separate corporate identity. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Cleary v. Philip Morris, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Mere fact that foreign-based tobacco company was a dominant shareholder in its American subsidiaries and that those subsidiaries were alleged to have acted in furtherance of a conspiracy within the United States was insufficient to establish personal jurisdiction over the company in Illinois, in the absence of a showing that the corporate veil between the company and its American subsidiaries should have been pierced. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2-209.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Illinois lacked personal jurisdiction over foreign-based tobacco company.

Title: De Castro v. Sanifill, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, to establish jurisdiction over the parent corporation based in action of subsidiary, a party must produce strong and robust evidence of control by the parent company over the subsidiary, rendering the latter a mere shell.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Piercing corporate veil not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: De Castro v. Sanifill, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Facts fell short of the strong and robust evidence required to pierce the corporate veil under Puerto Rico law, so as to establish personal jurisdiction over Delaware parent corporation with respect to accident in Puerto Rico involving waste hauling truck operated by joint venture formed by two Puerto Rico subsidiaries, though, besides executing the waste haulage agreement on behalf of the joint venture and registering the truck in the name of one of them, neither subsidiary was active, neither had assets, and there was substantial overlap among the officers and directors of parent and the subsidiaries, where no capital was shown to have been needed for subsidiaries to enter into the joint venture, which was their purpose, and there was no direct evidence of parent's control of day-to-day operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Piercing corporate veil not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Conservatorship of Prom v. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Japanese parent corporation which manufactured tires, and then distributed them to its wholly owned Japanese subsidiary, did not control subsidiary to extent that separate corporate identities could be disregarded, and subsidiary's contacts with State attributed to parent for purposes of determining whether parent transacted business in State, and thus was deemed to have appointed Secretary of State as its agent for service of process; only factors indicating control, which were that same persons were on boards of both corporations and parent was sole shareholder of subsidiary, were insufficient to establish requisite control.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Process. Japanese corporation did not transact business in Wisconsin, for purposes of process statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(3) Jurisdiction over shareholders, directors, or officers of foreign corporations >
Title: Cabot Safety Intermediate Corp. v. Arkon Safety Equipment, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Canadian parent corporation exercised pervasive control over its wholly-owned American subsidiary so as to satisfy Massachusetts test for piercing corporate veil in order to exercise personal jurisdiction over parent in patent infringement suit; there was an exact identity of officers in the two corporations, all of those officers resided in Canada and both corporations sold safety protection equipment.

Title: Garner v. Furmanite Australia Pty., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: To hold a foreign parent corporation subject to personal jurisdiction on the basis of the activity of one of its subsidiaries, there must be a showing of control by the parent which is greater than normal or that the parent acted as the "alter ego" of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Personal jurisdiction did not exist over Australian manufacturer of allegedly defective milling machine that injured employee of Texas corporation.

Title: C.R. Bard, Inc. v. Guidant Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to establish specific personal jurisdiction over parent corporation, under alter ego theory contained in Delaware long arm statute, party asserting jurisdiction must establish some fraud, injustice, or inequity in use of corporate form. 10 Del.C. § 3104(c)(1).

Title: IDS Life Ins. Co. v. SunAmerica Life Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Parents of wholly owned subsidiaries necessarily control, direct, and supervise subsidiaries to some extent, but unless there is basis for piercing corporate veil and thus attributing subsidiaries' torts to parent, parent is not liable for those torts and cannot be served under tort provision of Illinois long-arm statute. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2–209(a)(2).

Title: Lifeline Ambulance Services, Inc. v. Laidlaw, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil would not be preliminarily pierced to establish personal jurisdiction over parent corporation under Mississippi long arm statute based on claim that parent, through its Mississippi subsidiary, contracted for purchase of Georgia business; plaintiff failed to satisfy either the contract or the doing business prong of Mississippi's long arm statute. Miss.Code 1972, § 13–3–57.

Title: Environmental Waste Control, Inc. v. Browning-Ferris Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Delaware parent corporation with its principal place of business in Texas was subject to personal jurisdiction in Alabama in promissory fraud action against parent corporation and its Alabama subsidiary; initial negotiations regarding Alabama landfill project were conducted by parent corporation's vice president at parent corporation's divisional office, representatives of parent corporation attended second negotiating meeting in Alabama, parent corporation's name appeared on letter constituting proposal for landfill, and parent corporation filed report with Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) stating that parent corporation operated its solid waste business through regional offices.

Title: Small v. Lorillard Tobacco Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Jurisdiction over parent company under long-arm jurisdiction statute may exist under alter-ego theory, based upon acts of a subsidiary within state. McKinney's CPLR 302.

Title: Small v. Lorillard Tobacco Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Parent-subsidiary relationship alone cannot form predicate for exercise of long-arm jurisdiction over parent; there must be some proof that parent company dominates or controls daily activities of subsidiary. McKinney's CPLR 302.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Smokers' class action against cigarette manufacturers and trade associations survived jurisdictional, pre-emption and specificity of pleading challenges.

Title: State ex rel. Bell Atlantic-West Virginia, Inc. v. Ranson

Code, 31-1-15, 56-3-33(a).

Title: Satcorp Intern. Group v. China Nat. Import & Export Corp.

Headnote: Under New York law, Chinese parent corporation was subject to jurisdiction on theory that its wholly-owned New York subsidiary was its alter ego; ownership was common, parent had made loan to subsidiary on which no principal or interest had been paid, three of four members of subsidiary's board of directors were employees of parent, and parent exercised substantial operational control over subsidiary.

Title: Flight Intern. Aviation Training Center, Inc. v. Rivera

Headnote: Personal jurisdiction over resident parent corporation or resident corporate officer does not necessarily translate into personal jurisdiction over nonresident subsidiary or wholly owned corporation.

Title: Hobbs v. Don Mealey Chevrolet, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth District.
Headnote: Exception to rule that personal jurisdiction over resident parent corporation is not personal jurisdiction over nonresident subsidiary corporation arises where nonresident corporation is merely alter ego of resident parent.

Title: Mylan Laboratories, Inc. v. Akzo, N.V.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: District court did not have personal jurisdiction over foreign parent corporation under Maryland law, even though parent's third-tier subsidiary conducted business in Maryland, where there were no common officers or directors, corporate functions were rigidly separated, parent did not exert control over management or operating policies of subsidiary, and parent was not authorized to conduct any business in United States, though it indirectly owned 100% of subsidiary's stock and alleged criminal acts of subsidiary's employees were allegedly done for benefit of parent, where there was no evidence of intent to benefit parent or of parent's knowledge. Md.Code, Courts and Judicial Proceeding, § 6–103(b); Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 26(b)(1), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: American Home Assur. Co. v. Sport Maska, Inc.

Headnote: Court would not disregard separate corporate entities of Canadian corporations and Vermont corporation, to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over Canadian corporations based on activities of Vermont corporation, though Vermont corporation was wholly owned subsidiary of Canadian corporation, and corporations shared certain common officers, where no evidence was proffered that corporate dealings were fraudulent and had injurious consequences, or that corporate form was used merely to avoid liability for wrongdoing.

Title: Villar v. Crowley Maritime Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Neither nonresident defendant-corporations nor any of their subsidiary or parent corporations were alter egos of resident defendant-corporation so as to warrant exercise of jurisdiction over nonresident corporations on basis of defendant's residency under Texas long-arm statute, where resident defendant did not dominate nonresident defendant-corporations or their subsidiary or parent corporations, all codefendants maintained formalities of incorporation, and nonresident defendants did not function solely as conduit for Texas defendant. U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14; V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 17.042.

Title: In re Air Disaster Near Cove Neck, N.Y., on Jan. 25, 1990
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: American subsidiary and sales agent of Colombian airline could not be considered to be alter ego of airline so as to confer jurisdiction over airline under Warsaw Convention; Convention did not contemplate that corporation might be simultaneously domiciled in two separate countries. Warsaw Convention, Art. 28, 49 U.S.C.App.(1988 Ed.) § 1502 note.

Title: Dalton v. R & W Marine, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent was not the alter ego of its subsidiaries for purposes of determining long-arm jurisdiction, even though it owned 100% of its subsidiaries and remained responsible for general policy, offered benefit plans to its subsidiaries' employees, and had its subsidiaries funnel the revenues into centralized bank accounts and file a consolidated federal tax return, where it observed corporate formalities, made its subsidiaries responsible for daily operations, including personnel decisions, and allowed each subsidiary to keep its records and accounts in separate books and file its own state tax return.

Title: Copley Triangle Associates v. Apparel America, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Retail clothing corporation which did not have its own capital, funds or records was sham corporation for its nonresident, parent corporation and nonresident officers and directors of both corporations and, thus, acts of retail corporation were acts of nonresident defendants for purposes of acquiring personal jurisdiction over them. G.S. § 1-75.4; U.S.C.A. Const.Amend. 14.

Title: Sammons Enterprises, Inc. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Evidence adduced by discharged employee of hotel was insufficient to establish state court's general jurisdiction over hotel's nonresident corporate parent on alter ego theory; although parent's principals visited hotel during year and inquired about hotel management, and although parent owned outstanding shares of hotel's stock, there was no showing that hotel was undercapitalized, that corporate formalities were not maintained, or that hotel was held out as parent's agent.

Title: Reverse Vending Associates v. Tomra Systems US, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Statement by general partner of Pennsylvania business, that executive of Norwegian manufacturer and its United States subsidiary told partner that subsidiary had no power to make any decision not approved and ratified by manufacturer, unsupported by any independent evidence that manufacturer controlled activities of subsidiary and had usurped subsidiary's corporate identity, was insufficient to sustain partner's burden of proving that separate corporate form of either manufacturer or subsidiary was used by manufacturer as means to perpetrate fraud or promote injustice akin to fraud so as to mandate piercing the corporate veil and conferring upon Pennsylvania court personal jurisdiction over Norwegian manufacturer under Pennsylvania's long-arm statute. 42 Pa.C.S.A. §§ 5301, 5301 et seq., 5322, 5322(b); U.S.C.A. Const.Amends. 5, 14.

Title: 3-D Elec. Co., Inc. v. Barnett Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Generally, foreign parent corporation is not subject to jurisdiction of forum state merely because its subsidiary conducts business in that forum, and presence of one in forum may not be attributed to others; however, in some circumstances, close relationship between parent and subsidiary may justify finding that parent engages in business in jurisdiction through local activities of subsidiary.

Headnote: Parent corporation may be subject to jurisdiction of state if subsidiary located therein is deemed to be merely "alter ego" of parent, even though parent corporation is not located in or personally doing business in state.

Title: Grimandi v. Beech Aircraft Corp.

Title: Escude Cruz v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.

Headnote: Mere fact that a subsidiary company does business within state does not confer jurisdiction over its nonresident parent, even if parent is sole owner of subsidiary; there is presumption of corporate separateness that must be overcome by clear and convincing evidence that parent in fact controls activities of subsidiary.

Title: Rea v. An-Son Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: For purposes of determining personal jurisdiction of federal district court in Oklahoma over Venezuelan subsidiary of corporation, which had its principal place of business in Oklahoma and which, in turn, was subsidiary of corporation which also had its principal place of business in Oklahoma, record disclosed that both of the latter corporations had exercised sufficient control over Venezuelan corporation to enable federal court to disregard separate identities of each and to find that acts of the parent corporations might be imputed to Venezuelan corporation to give court jurisdiction under Oklahoma long-arm statute over that corporation, which could be said to be "doing business" in Oklahoma. 18 O.S.1971, § 1.204a; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 9(h), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: United Merchants & Mfrs., Inc. v. David & Dash, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: That foreign corporation's subsidiary maintained chain of retail stores in Maryland and its financial division owned security interest and personal property in Maryland and had made loans to customers outside Maryland secured by accounts receivable possibly relating to goods inside Maryland did not amount to "doing intrastate business" within Maryland statute precluding foreign corporation doing intrastate business without being qualified to do so from maintaining suit in state courts, where subsidiary was Maryland corporation, its activities of subsidiary could not be attributed to defendant by "piercing the veil," and transactions of financial division were interstate in nature. Md.Code, Corporations and Associations, §§ 7-103(7), 7-203.

Title: Titu-Serban Ionescu v. E. F. Hutton & Co.

Title: Wells Fargo & Co. v. Wells Fargo Exp. Co.

Title: In re Puerto Rico Air Disaster Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: While stock of defendant, which was a Puerto Rican corporation and which was owner and operator of aircraft in which decedents were passengers at time of fatal crash, was acquired by a New Jersey corporation, with its principal place of business in Verona, Pennsylvania, some nine months after accident, where defendant continued to carry on its corporate functions, operating and executive, as it did prior thereto, and where defendant's activities and records and those of its parent were kept separate and distinct at all times, with each maintaining integrity of its corporate existence separate and apart from other, parent corporation was not defendant's alter ego for purpose of determining whether defendant was "doing business" in Pennsylvania so as to come under personal jurisdiction of Pennsylvania in wrongful death and survival action commenced there. 12 P.S.Pa. §§ 1602-1604; 15 P.S.Pa. § 2011, subd. C.; 20 P.S.Pa. §§ 320.601-320.603.

Title: Penntube Plastics Co. v. Fluorotex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Greenville Division.
Headnote: In view of facts that South Carolina subsidiary corporation was formed for limited purpose of selling products of parent Delaware corporation, that all orders taken by subsidiary were submitted to parent for approval, that all sales brochures, samples, and price lists used by subsidiary were supplied by parent, and that all expenses of operating subsidiary's office were paid by parent, subsidiary, at time of commencement of patent infringement action against parent, was merely a resident sales agent for parent, and its office constituted a "regular and established place of business" of parent within District of South Carolina, and federal court for that District would pierce corporate shield for purposes of establishing venue as to parent under special statute covering venue in patent infringement cases. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1400(b).

Title: Henry v. Offshore Drilling (W. A.) Pty., Limited

Headnote: Where former employee of domestic parent corporation while employed by Australian subsidiary off coast of Australia received salary checks from account of parent, which included him as member of its retirement plan and employee retained at subsidiary the same identification number he had had with parent, parent and subsidiary did not maintain distinct and separate corporate entities and separate incorporation must be disregarded in determining jurisdiction of domestic federal court in employee's action against subsidiary.

Title: Karlin v. Avis
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.

CPLR N.Y. 301.

Bankr.Act, § 57, sub. a, 11 U.S.C.A. § 93(a).

Title: Hermetic Seal Corp. v. Savoy Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court S.D. Florida.
Headnote: In order to bring corporate parent within Florida "long arm" statute, plaintiff had burden of proving either that parent itself did business or was engaged in business venture in Florida, or that subsidiary, whose principal place of business was in Florida, was in reality its alter ego or instrumentality so that parent did business in Florida by means of and through subsidiary, or that officer of subsidiary was at time of attempted service sent into Florida by parent for purpose of promoting business of parent in Florida and encouraging the use of parent's products in Florida. F.S.A. § 48.081.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Statutes authorizing a court to exercise personal jurisdiction over person as to cause of action arising from person's transacting business in state do not abolish traditional recognition of separate entities of subsidiary and parent corporations.

Title: Textainer Equipment Management Limited v. United States
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: There was no evidence that lessor's wholly owned subsidiary was lessor's alter ego, thus precluding lessor's standing to seek just compensation for shipping containers owned by subsidiary on date of taking by Department of Army, since parents and subsidiaries were generally considered to be entirely separate entities, so lessor could not be presumed to own subsidiary's containers solely on basis of lessor's ownership of subsidiary's stock. U.S. Const. Amend. 5.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Eminent Domain. Department of Army's appropriation of lessors' shipping containers after expiration of lease constituted compensable taking.

Title: Tucker v. American Intern. Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Parent company of insurers sued by former employee seeking to collect judgment in her favor from unlawful discharge action was proper party to action, via piercing of corporate veil under Connecticut law; complaint averred that parent had control of business practices relating to employment practices liability (EPL) policy at issue, and that parent was entity that wrongfully closed employee's claim file and ultimately rejected her claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Debtor Protections. Employee's action was not outside scope of bankruptcy judge's ruling to lift automatic stay as to claims against employer.

Title: McCall v. Chesapeake Energy Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Corporate parent of operator of oil and gas wells was not a necessary party to declaratory judgment action brought against operator by working share owner seeking determination of parties' rights and responsibilities under joint operating agreement (JOA); owner made allegations simply that operator was subsidiary of corporate parent, but failed to produce evidence that the operator was the mere agent or instrumentality of the corporate parent.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Oil and Natural Gas. Owner of working shares in gas wells could not market share with operator under Oklahoma's Natural Gas Market Sharing Act.

Title: National Plan Administrators, Inc. v. National Health Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: For the purposes of legal proceedings, subsidiary corporations and parent corporations are separate and distinct "persons" as a matter of law, and the separate entity of corporations will be observed by the courts even where one company may dominate or control, or even treat another company as a mere department, instrumentality, or agency.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Third-party administrator and parent corporation were liable to health insurer for breach of fiduciary duty.

Title: USA Interactive v. Dow Lohnes & Albertson, P.L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Parent of subsidiary holding option to purchase shares of corporation could not bring malpractice action against attorneys who drafted option agreement, on grounds that subsidiary was mere instrumentality of parent.

Headnote: Notwithstanding fact that parent corporation owns entire capital stock of subsidiary corporation, two corporations are separate legal entities, and, whatever may have been motive leading to their separate existence, they can only be regarded as separate entities for purpose of legal proceedings.

Title: Gidwitz v. Stirco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation could be joined as counterdefendant in contract dispute, in view of evidence that parent and subsidiary commingled funds and assets, that subsidiary was undercapitalized, that parent owned 100% of stock in subsidiary, and that parent treated assets of subsidiary as its own; parent was "alter ego" and was actual financier of subsidiary's interest in transaction. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 20(a), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: La Chemise Lacoste v. General Mills, Inc.

Headnote: Wholly owned subsidiary corporations were not merely alter egos of parent corporation, so as to justify retention of parent as party to action against subsidiary, where, although parent had power to exercise control over subsidiaries, it appeared that it had not chosen to do so.
