Title: U.S. v. Kolon Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Service upon a subsidiary is generally insufficient to constitute process on the parent; however, exceptions exist for a situation in which the subsidiary constitutes the "managing or general agent" of the parent company, or where the subsidiary serves as the "alter ego" of the parent, such that the subsidiary serves as a mere conduit for the activities of its parent.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Summons. Mailing provision of rule governing service of a criminal summons was not a component of effective service.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: U.S. v. Kolon Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, wholly owned New Jersey subsidiary of Korean parent corporation was not alter ego of Korean corporation for purposes effectuating service of indictment and criminal summons; subsidiary was solvent, maintained records which were independently audited, negotiated with and paid parent for the products that it purchased from it, and there was no evidence regarding subsidiary's capitalization, and its officers reported to its own board of directors and not to parent's. Fed.Rules Cr.Proc.Rule 4(c)(3)(C), 18 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Summons. Mailing provision of rule governing service of a criminal summons was not a component of effective service.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: Tanfield Engineering Systems, Inc. v. Thornton
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: The general rule for parent and subsidiary corporations and service of process is that a subsidiary may be found to be a parent corporation's agent at law for service of process, or a parent may be held a subsidiary's agent at law for service of process, where the evidence shows that one is the agent or alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent's full ownership of and common officers with subsidiary did not establish that subsidiary was parent's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: Tanfield Engineering Systems, Inc. v. Thornton
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Facts that parent corporation owned 100% of the stock of subsidiary, and that the two entities shared a treasurer and chief executive officer, were insufficient to establish that subsidiary was the alter ego of parent, such that service of process on parent would suffice to constitute service on subsidiary; common officers had not had direct involvement in management of subsidiary for more than a year, parent and subsidiary observed corporate formalities and maintained separate accounting systems, and subsidiary exercised complete authority over its daily operations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent's full ownership of and common officers with subsidiary did not establish that subsidiary was parent's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: In re Subpoena To Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether foreign parent corporation has sufficient control over its domestic subsidiary to deem subsidiary its agent for purposes of service of process under Illinois law, court should consider whether: (1) subsidiary was established and wholly owned by parent; (2) parent paid salaries of subsidiary's directors; (3) parent guaranteed subsidiary's lease; (4) subsidiary's sole business was sale of parts for parent; (5) parent listed subsidiary's address in advertisements; (6) subsidiary existed primarily to promote sale and distribution of parent's products; (7) subsidiary was obligated to repair and sell parts for parent's products; (8) subsidiary was contractually required to apprise parent of all aspects of its business; (9) subsidiary was authorized to prosecute trademark infringement suits in parent's name; (10) parent controlled subsidiary's choice of dealers, designation of products and services, stock levels, and methods of ordering; (11) parent dominated subsidiary's board of directors; (12) subsidiary conducted its board meetings in parent's domicile; and (13) subsidiary was listed on consolidated financial sheet along with parent rather than publishing its own annual report. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2–204.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Process. Foreign parent corporation's American subsidiary was not its agent for purposes of service of process.

Title: In re Subpoena To Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, foreign parent corporation's American subsidiary was not its agent for purposes of service of process, even though subsidiary was wholly owned by corporation, parent used subsidiary's address in its marketing efforts, subsidiary's purpose was, at least in part, to promote sale and distribution of parent's products, and parent produced one annual report with income statement encompassing earnings of parent and its subsidiaries, where there was no evidence that parent controlled subsidiary's operation or undertook financial obligations on subsidiary's behalf. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2–204.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Process. Foreign parent corporation's American subsidiary was not its agent for purposes of service of process.

Title: Delta Constructors, Inc. v. Roediger Vacuum, GmbH
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Jackson Division.
Headnote: In action brought by purchaser of vacuum collection chambers against German vendor for breach of contract and breach of express and implied warranties after chambers allegedly cracked because they were not of sufficient thickness, vendor's American co-subsidiary was not vendor's domestic agent for purposes of service of process; German vendor did not disregard corporate formalities, vendor and co-subsidiary did not obtain any financial benefit from existence of the other, and purchaser did not present evidence that vendor had any ownership interest in co-subsidiary or that vendor controlled operations or board of directors of co-subsidiary, or vice-versa. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rules 4(e), (h)(2), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. German vendor's American co-subsidiary was not vendor's domestic agent for purposes of service of process.

Title: Cebcor Service Corp. v. Landscape Design and Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Service of process on a subsidiary constitutes service on an alter ego parent corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Plaintiffs' failure to serve amended petition on defendant provided no ground for setting aside default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: C3 Media & Marketing Group, LLC v. Firstgate Internet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Consulting company made prima facie showing that United States subsidiaries were mere departments of their foreign parent corporations and that service of process was therefore properly effected on parent corporations through subsidiaries, given company's allegations that parent corporations completely controlled subsidiaries by making them dependent upon parent corporations' hand-to-mouth advances of capital and dictating what work they performed, and that parent corporations ignored corporate formalities, in that their boards conducted simultaneous meetings and they held assets jointly.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Client's material breach of separation agreement did not warrant rescission.

Title: BPA Intern., Inc. v. Kingdom of Sweden
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Service on corporate subsidiary does not constitute service on the parent, under federal procedural rules, unless they are so intertwined that the subsidiary may be deemed parent's alter ego or agent. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(h)(1), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Direct action required for FSIA jurisdiction did not exist in action against Sweden and phone company.

Title: Bank of America Corp. v. Edwards
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: The parent-subsidiary corporate relationship alone is not ordinarily enough to establish agency for the purpose of service of process. Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 4(c)(6).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Process. Plaintiff never served bank, although subsidiary was served, and, thus, judgment against bank was void.

Title: Hickory Travel Systems, Inc. v. TUI AG
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: For service of process on a subsidiary to count as service upon its parent, plaintiff must demonstrate either that the subsidiary functions as the parent's agent or as its alter ego. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(h)(1), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Service on subsidiaries did not constitute service on parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: Hickory Travel Systems, Inc. v. TUI AG
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: For purposes of service of process, a subsidiary functions as the parent's alter ego if the subsidiary is so intertwined with the parent that it functions as part thereof, and if disregarding that unity of interest would result in fraud or injustice. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(h)(1), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Service on subsidiaries did not constitute service on parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: Hickory Travel Systems, Inc. v. TUI AG
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: If a parent is involved in directing the day-to-day management of a subsidiary, or if the management of the parent and subsidiary is so intertwined that separation is merely a fiction, a court may disregard the formalities of separation and consider service on the subsidiary to be service upon the parent. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(h)(1), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Service on subsidiaries did not constitute service on parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(5) Process >
Title: Hickory Travel Systems, Inc. v. TUI AG
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Plaintiff failed to show that service of process on foreign parent's subsidiaries constituted service on parent on theory that subsidiaries were alter egos of parent, based on evidence that parent wholly owned its subsidiaries, referred to them as divisions and not separate companies, reported their earnings in annual statements, boasted of corporate integration, and made decisions about restructuring the businesses of some of those subsidiaries; plaintiff did not show that management structures were interchangeable and made only speculative claims, without any evidentiary support, that parent was involved in the day-to-day management of its subsidiaries. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(h)(1), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Service on subsidiaries did not constitute service on parent.

Title: Chung v. Tarom, S.A.

Headnote: Under Illinois law, mere existence of parent-subsidiary relationship is insufficient to establish close ties necessary for subsidiary to be deemed agent of corporate parent for purposes of service of process. S.H.A. 735 ILCS 5/2-204.

Title: Bielicki v. Empire Stevedoring Co., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Federal district court would grant plaintiffs leave to serve wholly owned subsidiary of defendant whose corporate veil was subject to piercing for purposes of obtaining personal jurisdiction over defendant where plaintiffs originally attempted to serve subsidiary, which was localed in forum, and parent did not file timely motion to dismiss for insufficiency of service of process. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 12(b)(5), 28 U.S.C.A.; M.S.A. § 302A.901.

Title: Spann v. Colonial Village, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Service on corporation's wholly owned subsidiary effected service on corporation since subsidiary held itself out to public as a company of parent corporation, listed parent corporation on business cards, and advertised parent corporation's control of property.

Title: Mirrow v. Club Med, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: There was a degree of control by parent corporation over its wholly owned subsidiary such that service on the domestic subsidiary was reasonably calculated to give actual notice to the foreign parent, and thus was sufficient service on the parent, in light of interlocking officers and directors and in light of fact that the subsidiary effectively operated as the sales department of the parent in the United States, performing a function that the parent itself would otherwise have to perform.

Title: O'Berry v. McDermott, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Subsidiary was not alter ego of parent corporations, so that service of process on parent in tort case was not effective as to subsidiary, though parent and subsidiary had common or overlapping directors, engaged in same business, filed consolidated tax returns, and engaged in informal intercorporate loans or books transactions, where subsidiary was not undercapitalized or incapable of paying judgment if found liable.

Title: Akzona Inc. v. E.I. Du Pont De Nemours & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Service on a subsidiary does not confer jurisdiction over parent corporation where separate corporate identities are maintained, unless subsidiary is found to be either alter ego or agent of parent.

Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they did not in reality constitute separate and distinct corporate entities, but were one and same under alter ego analysis, and therefore service of process on a chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries, where parent corporation owned all of majority of capital stock of subsidiaries, several individuals were simultaneously officers of parent and subsidiaries, parent exercised significant financial control over subsidiaries, parent and subsidiaries attempted to project unified public image; and parent's exercise of control over personnel policies of all corporation subsidiaries was so substantial that to treat corporate entities separately would amount to injustice.

Title: Ex parte Volkswagenwerk Aktiengesellschaft
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Party seeking to prove proper service on parent corporation by means of service on subsidiary must show that parent corporation exercises such control and domination over subsidiary that subsidiary no longer has a will, mind or existence of its own, and operates merely as a department of the parent; alternatively, party seeking to have service on the subsidiary and the parent by means of service on the subsidiary may show that parent has complete control over subsidiary, conducting subsidiary's business and creating its policies, or that subsidiary is a mere adjunct and instrumentality of parent, or that subsidiary is merely a "dummy" by means of which parent does business in the state.

Title: Lasky v. Continental Products Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Service of complaint on wholly owned subsidiary of Japanese corporation did not constitute proper service on the Japanese corporation, where the subsidiary was a separate corporate entity with its own management policy and books and records, and where there was no showing that it was so dominated and controlled by the Japanese corporation as to warrant a finding that service on it constituted service on its parent. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(d)(3), 28 U.S.C.A.

Headnote: While relationship with parent and subsidiary alone would not suffice, where two corporations are not really separate entities service on parent will reach a foreign subsidiary.

Headnote: To sustain service on a subsidiary to a parent corporation, it must be demonstrated that parent corporation is acting as an agent for subsidiary within state or that two corporations are not really separate entities. Jones Act, 46 U.S.C.A. § 688; Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. Rule 4(d)(3), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: Betar v. De Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Service on subsidiary, which did nothing except sell foreign parent corporation's products, did not constitute service on parent corporation, which was sole stockholder of subsidiary, since plaintiff, by merely showing that such corporations had common officers and a parent-subsidiary relationship, failed to show that such corporations had failed to retain their separate identities, given fact that subsidiary performed a different function from parent, as was evidenced by case at bar in which plaintiff had conceded that parent had no responsibility for crash which was subject matter of litigation.

Title: Wells Fargo & Co. v. Wells Fargo Exp. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Alien corporation, as parent of allegedly "undercapitalized" Nevada corporation, might be subject to service under Nevada long-arm statute on theory that the cause of action which would "arise from" alien defendant's activity "in" Nevada would be one for loosing on the world an undercapitalized corporation unable to meet its obligations. Lanham Trade-Mark Act, §§ 1–45, 15 U.S.C.A. §§ 1051–1127; N.R.S. 14.065, subd. 2.

Title: Stanley Works v. Globemaster, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Service of process upon branch manager of local subsidiary was sufficient to constitute service upon foreign parent, where parent and subsidiary had disregarded all but formalities of separation and, by having a regular and established place of business in district, parent had a fortiori established minimum contacts in district to provide court with personal jurisdiction over it. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d)(3), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: Frito-Lay, Inc. v. Procter & Gamble Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Absent showing that nonresident corporate parent actually controlled the internal affairs of wholly owned subsidiary which conducted business within Texas, subsidiary was not the alter ego for parent and, therefore, service of process on subsidiary did not subject parent, which did not maintain either a regular place of business or a registered agent for service of process in Texas to in personam jurisdiction in Texas, in action for declaratory judgment of invalidity and unenforceability of patent issued to the parent. 28 U.S.C.A. §§ 2201, 2202; Vernon's Ann.Tex.Civ.St. arts. 2031b, 2031b, §§ 3, 4.

Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: New Jersey subsidiary corporations which were engaged in operation of nursing home in New Jersey and which existed prior to their acquisition by parent Delaware corporation which had other subsidiary corporations which operated other homes were not the alter ego of the parent corporation for purpose of service of process. Title: Comprehensive Sports Planning, Inc. v. Pleasant Valley Country Club
Court: Civil Court, City of New York, New York County, Trial Term, Part 48.
Headnote: For purpose of holding parent corporation liable in damages for the acts of subsidiary and thus exposing the assets of parent to lawsuit against subsidiary, a very strict set of standards is required before the corporate veil between the corporations can be pierced, but such strict standards are not required to pierce the corporate veil to determine whether parent may be served process solely for the purpose of acquiring jurisdiction over the subsidiary.

Title: Teledyne Ryan Aeronautical Co. v. Montgomery Ward & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Where, though wholly owned subsidiary corporation might act as agent for parent corporation in some isolated instances, that agency was very limited, and separate corporate identities of corporations had been maintained, and parent corporation was not alter ego of subsidiary corporation, service upon statutory agent for subsidiary corporation was not sufficient to acquire jurisdiction over either parent corporation or another wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(e), 28 U.S.C.A.; 28 U.S.C.A. §§ 1391(c), 1400(b); 1965 Perm.Supp. C.R.S. section 37–1–26.

Title: ACS Industries, Inc. v. Keller Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Notwithstanding fact that cause of action did not arise out of transaction between plaintiff and defendant's wholly owned subsidiary, and no aspects of disputed transaction occurred within jurisdictional forum, service in Connecticut on defendant's subsidiary was sufficient to confer jurisdiction over defendant, where plaintiff made threshold demonstration, by such proof as fact that subsidiary manufactured nothing and simply distributed products for other subsidiaries of defendant as well as certain unrelated companies, that defendant and its subsidiary failed to maintain sufficient formal separateness. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rules 12(b) (2), 56(b), 28 U.S.C.A.

Headnote: In determining whether service upon parent corporation's agent should constitute service upon nonresident subsidiary, court must pierce multiplicity of formalities and relationships to determine whether particular corporate form was shield behind which injustice was sought to be done by those who controlled corporation.

Title: Ludwig v. General Binding Corp.
Court: United States District Court E. D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Where subsidiary of Illinois corporation conducted sales activities in Wisconsin completely separate, and was a distinct organization from the Illinois corporation, maintained its own books, records and bank accounts, and held its own corporate meetings, filed its own tax returns and had its own board of directors, even though many of its officers and directors were also officers and directors of Illinois corporation, jurisdiction of federal District Court in Wisconsin could not be obtained over Illinois corporation by service of process on salesmen of subsidiary. W.S.A. 262.09(4); Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d)(3, 7), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: Ludwig v. General Binding Corp.
Court: United States District Court E. D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Maintenance of separate books, separate corporate records, separate directors and meetings were of paramount importance in determining that separate corporate existence and identity of Wisconsin subsidiary was successfully maintained and that parent Illinois corporation was not doing business in Wisconsin and that service of process on subsidiary did not constitute service on corporation. W.S.A. 262.09(4); Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d)(3, 7), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: Bergholt v. Hudson Motor Car Co.
Court: United States District Court D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: Where subsidiary corporation had independent headquarters in Minnesota for contracting with local dealers for delivery of automobiles and parts manufactured by parent, which was a Michigan corporation, and subsidiary had independent bank accounts, books of record, employees, income tax reports, and financial statements, there was not such a merger of corporate identities as to justify finding that parent was doing business in Minnesota, and therefore service on assistant zone manager of subsidiary in Minnesota was insufficient to constitute service on parent. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1694.

Title: Dam v. General Elec. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Washington, Northern Division.
Headnote: As a general rule, a foreign corporation, which owns or controls capital stock and dictates policies and directs affairs of subsidiary corporation, which is doing business within state, is not thereby subject to service of process through service upon an agent of the subsidiary in the state; but an exception is recognized where plaintiff seeks to hold parent corporation liable for act or omission of its subsidiary or where plaintiff seeks to enforce against subsidiary a liability of parent and primary concern is with enforcement of substantive rights; and an exception is also recognized where corporate subsidiary is used as an instrumentality or adjunct of the parent corporation for the accomplishment of some illegal or fraudulent or dishonest purpose. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d) (3, 7), 28 U.S.C.A.; RCW 428.080(9).

Title: Dam v. General Elec. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Washington, Northern Division.
Headnote: For service upon subsidiary to be regarded, in legal effect, as service upon parent corporation, there must be a showing of something more than complete control and direction of subsidiary by parent, and absolute domination, through capital stock ownership and its incidents, is not alone sufficient, even though subsidiary is instrumentality employed by parent for transaction of latter's business within forum state. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d) (3, 7), 28 U.S.C.A.; RCW 428.080(9).

Title: American Cities Power & Light Corp. v. Williams
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York, Special Term, Part III.
Headnote: Even where foreign corporation has not itself conducted any activities in the state, and has no officer in the state, service may be effected upon it by delivering summons to officer of a wholly owned subsidiary which is so controlled, and its affairs so conducted, that it is a mere instrumentality of the foreign corporation. Civil Practice Act, § 19, subd. 2.

Title: State v. Northwest Magnesite Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, en Banc.
Headnote: A foreign corporation which holds a controlling interest in a subsidiary corporation doing business within a state is not thereby subject to service of process through service upon an agent of the subsidiary doing business within such state.

Title: Darling Stores Corporation v. Young Realty Co.
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Iowa statute providing for service of process on foreign corporation doing business in Iowa on resident agent named by foreign corporation or on secretary of state, service of process on foreign corporation after withdrawal of corporation from Iowa, by serving resident agent named by corporation and attorney general, in action for breach of lease of premises in which foreign corporation did business, was sufficient, notwithstanding that lease had been assigned to subsidiary and not to foreign corporation. Code Iowa 1939, §§ 8420, 8421, subd. 6.

Headnote: Where books of parent corporation and those of wholly owned and controlled subsidiary were kept separate, and service of summons was made on the officer or agent of the subsidiary, return purporting to show service on parent corporation would be quashed, on parent corporation's motion. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d), 28 U.S.C.A.

Title: Sikousis Legacy Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Arbitration award-creditors failed to demonstrate that owner of the vessel that creditor chartered to arbitration award-debtor was involved in the alleged fraudulent transfer of debtor's assets to subsidiaries of debtor and owner's indirect parent company, as would support piercing owner's corporate veil to permit attachment of vessel as security to satisfy $7.5 million arbitration award for debtor's breach of charter agreement; there was no indication that valuable assets were concentrated in owner in connection with debtor, and creditors made no allegations that owner participated in the asset-stripping of debtor, but rather, merely asserted that owner's direct parent transferred its controlling interest over debtor for the price of $1, which demonstrated nothing about owner.

Title: Sikousis Legacy Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: California's single business enterprise doctrine did not apply to support arbitration award-creditors' attachment claims against the chairman of the board of shipping corporations and against corporations' subsidiaries, which included arbitration award-debtor, in action to attach vessel owned by one of the subsidiaries as security to satisfy $7.5 million arbitration award for debtor's breach of charter agreement, alleging owner and the various corporate entities were alter egos of each other; state law could only be used where it was not inconsistent with admiralty principles, but California law was inconsistent with admiralty law, as admiralty alter ego principles not only required both domination and control, but also that the subservient entity be used for a fraudulent purpose.

Title: Sikousis Legacy Inc. v. B-Gas Limited

Headnote: Arbitration award-creditors could not attach vessel charted to arbitration award-debtor to satisfy $7.5 million arbitration award for debtor's breach of charter agreement under the doctrine of reverse veil piercing, in action against chairman of the board of shipping corporations, whose subsidiaries included debtor and a subsidiary that owned the vessel, where chairman was not a shareholder debtor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Arbitration award-creditors failed to show that award-debtor was the alter ego of its parent company, as would support attachment of...

Title: Humphrey v. GlaxoSmithKline PLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In essence, nonsignatory voluntarily pierces its own veil to arbitrate claims against signatory that are derivative of its corporate-subsidiary's claims against same signatory.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Non-signatory to arbitration agreement could not be compelled to arbitrate its claims.

Title: Story v. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under New York law, in the context of a nonsignatory parent company estopping a signatory from avoiding arbitration with the nonsignatory, a nonsignatory voluntarily pierces its own veil to arbitrate claims against a signatory that are derivative of its corporate-subsidiary's claims against the same signatory.

Title: Cohen v. TNP 2008 Participating Notes Program, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 7, California.
Headnote: Parent company of subsidiary real estate investment company exercised sufficient control to cause subsidiary to become merely the agent or instrumentality of parent company, as required for parent company to be bound by arbitration agreement signed by investors and subsidiary in investor's action for breach of promissory notes and other causes of action, though parent company was non-signatory to arbitration provision; parent company made direct communications with investors that went beyond its role as guarantor and managing member of the subsidiary and demonstrated control of subsidiary's day-to-day operations, and record demonstrated that entities shared same address and phone number.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Parent company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary necessary to bind it as nonsignatory to subsidiary's arbitration agreement with investors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1078 Remedies and Procedure > 101k1078(6) Arbitration >
Title: Cohen v. TNP 2008 Participating Notes Program, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 7, California.
Headnote: An arbitration agreement signed by a subsidiary may bind the parent company only where the party seeking to compel arbitration can show the parent had sufficient control over the subsidiary's activities such that the subsidiary was a mere agent or instrumentality of the parent and the causes of action or claims against the parent arise out of this relationship.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Parent company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary necessary to bind it as nonsignatory to subsidiary's arbitration agreement with investors.

Title: Cohen v. TNP 2008 Participating Notes Program, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 7, California.
Headnote: Investor's claims against parent company of subsidiary real estate investment company for breach of promissory notes and other causes of action arose directly from parent company's agency relationship with subsidiary and fell within scope of arbitration provision in subscription agreement, providing for arbitration of any claim "arising under, out of or relating to this Agreement or any of the transactions contemplated hereby," as required for parent company to be bound by arbitration agreement despite fact that it was non-signatory to arbitration agreement; parent company's guaranty, like subscription agreement, was exhibit to private placement memorandum, thus making it a "transaction contemplated" by the arbitration agreement, and claims against parent company were based on same facts as those against subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Parent company exercised sufficient control over subsidiary necessary to bind it as nonsignatory to subsidiary's arbitration agreement with investors.

Title: USHealth Group, Inc. v. South
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, subsidiary was not alter ego of parent company, such that non-signatory parent was bound to arbitration provisions of agreement entered into by subsidiary; although the two entities had a corporate relationship, parent had not exercised such control over the subsidiary as to clearly show that the two entities had abandoned their separate corporate identities.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Compelling arbitration of non-signatory was not necessary to prevent factual and legal whipsaw.

Title: Variable Annuity Life Ins. Co. (VALIC) v. Dull
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: A registered representative of a broker failed to establish that insurer, broker's parent corporation, was alter ego of broker to justify piercing the corporate veil, and thus agreement to arbitrate between representative and broker did not bind insurer. Broker was wholly-owned subsidiary of insurer. Representative failed to make any allegation or present any evidence that insurer exercised dominance and control over broker.

Title: Zurich American Ins. Co. v. Watts Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the mere parent-subsidiary relationship does not create the relation of principal and agent or alter ego between two corporations, for the purpose of binding a non-signatory corporation to an arbitration agreement.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Arbitration and Appraisal. Insured could not be compelled to arbitrate dispute under agreement containing arbitration clause which it did not sign.

Title: Smoothline Ltd. v. North American Foreign Trading Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Domination requirement for veil-piercing under New York law was satisfied in American importer's action to compel parent to arbitrate importer's contract disputes with subsidiaries concerning importation and repair of wireless telephones; subsidiary that had contracted to produce phones had no manufacturing capability, no accounting books and records and only one employee, there was substantial overlap of directors and personnel among entities, entities' correspondence indicated blurring of boundaries between parent and subsidiaries, subsidiaries shared office space and parent had none, rent for office space was informally set, lines of credit were established that were guaranteed by parent and designed so that multiple subsidiaries could draw funds from them, with no established protocol for apportionment of lines of credit among subsidiaries, subsidiaries produced no standard accounting documents, implying that documents would indicate that subsidiaries were not independent but rather were divisions of parent, and numerous unexplained intercompany transfers among subsidiaries suggested lack of arms-length transactions.

Title: Smoothline Ltd. v. North American Foreign Trading Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Fraud requirement for veil-piercing under New York law was satisfied in American importer's action to compel parent to arbitrate importer's contract disputes with subsidiaries concerning importation and repair of wireless telephones; subsidiary that had contracted to produce phones had cost of sales that increased dramatically in two years preceding arbitration, and had engaged in numerous unexplained intercompany transfers with subcontracting subsidiaries, implying that funds were being shifted out of contracting subsidiary in form of inflated costs being paid to subcontracting subsidiaries in order to make contracting subsidiary judgment-proof, and parent had custody and control of evidence that would confirm or refute implication.

Title: TNS Holdings, Inc. v. MKI Securities Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation was not alter ego of its subsidiary corporation, and thus, corporate veil would not be pierced to enforce against parent an arbitration clause in a software licensing agreement for which subsidiary was signatory; parent's control over subsidiary did not result in fraud or inequity and licensor did not believe it was contracting with an entity other than the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not alter ego of subsidiary as to arbitration agreement.

Title: TNS Holdings, Inc. v. MKI Securities Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Interrelatedness between parent corporation and its subsidiary, standing alone, was not enough to pierce the corporate veil to enforce against parent an arbitration clause in a software licensing agreement for which subsidiary was signatory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not alter ego of subsidiary as to arbitration agreement.

Title: TNS Holdings, Inc. v. MKI Securities Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Subsidiary acted as alter ego of parent corporation when negotiating contract containing arbitration clause, and, thus, parent corporation was required to arbitrate contract dispute, despite fact that corporation had never agreed to arbitration, where negotiations regarding contract were conducted exclusively by representatives of corporation, there was no evidence that subsidiary exercised any corporate independence regarding project, product of contract was to be used for corporation's benefit and corporation guaranteed subsidiary's performance of its obligations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Parent corporation was required under alter ego theory to arbitrate dispute arising out contract involving subsidiary.

Title: Regency Island Dunes, Inc. v. Foley and Associates Const. Co., Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Corporation could not be compelled, based on alter ego theory, to arbitrate claims under agreement to which its subsidiary was party, absent evidence in record to support finding that parent was alter ego of subsidiary.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Corporation that was not party to arbitration agreement could not be compelled to arbitrate claims under agreement based on alter ego theory.

Title: Usina Costa Pinto S.A. Acucar E Alcool v. Louis Dreyfus Sugar Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Relationship exists and permits nonsignatory to act as alter ego and thereby compel arbitration, where parent corporation so dominates and controls affairs of its subsidiary that subsidiary cannot be said to have any independent existence of its own.

Title: Thomson-CSF, S.A. v. American Arbitration Ass'n
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate parent which recently purchased subsidiary did not exert requisite degree of control over subsidiary to justify piercing corporate veil and, thus, corporate parent could not be bound to arbitration agreement between subsidiary and subsidiary's supplier under corporate veil piercing theory, where there was no abandonment of separate corporate structures, there was no intermingling of corporate finances and directorship, and subsidiary continued to function as distinct entity closely incorporated into existing corporate structure of parent.

Title: Federated Dept. Stores, Inc. v. J.V.B. Industries, Inc.

Headnote: Contractor's parent corporation had right to compel arbitration of its business destruction claims against owner, even though parent was not party to construction contracts, where parent and contractor were alter egos, as one person controlled both corporations, and contractor was mere instrumentality of parent.

Title: Federated Title Insurers, Inc. v. Ward
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Employer was not an instrumentality of a corporate shareholder or parent corporation of shareholder's parent, and thus, shareholder and parent corporation of shareholder's parent could not be bound to arbitration provision of employment agreement under theory of mere instrumentality; there was no evidence that corporate shareholder or parent of parent controlled employer or that corporate shareholder and parent of parent acted wrongfully through employer.

Headnote: In light of thorough integration of franchisor's organization, composed of parent and subsidiary corporations, parent and subsidiary companies were all required to participate in arbitration with franchisee, notwithstanding that agreement between franchisee and one subsidiary was sole contract containing arbitration clause.

Title: Andrew Martin Marine Corp. v. Stork-Werkspoor Diesel B.V.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Where individual was the owner of 100% of stock of all but one of the corporations which actually existed, where he was the president of two of the corporations and also acted for his nonexistent corporations, where the parent corporation signed the agreement to refinance vessel engines for subsidiary, where formal legal requirements were not observed in connection with purchase and financing of the engines, corporate entities would be disregarded and corporation which was suing because of alleged defects in repair of the engines was bound by arbitration agreement contained in contract for repair of the engines, even though it had not signed the contract.

Title: Coastal States Trading, Inc. v. Zenith Nav. S. A.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to bind subsidiary corporation to arbitration agreement to which it was not signatory, but to which its parent was signatory, must first establish that subsidiary was controlled to such degree by parent that it had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; such control must go beyond mere stock ownership, or even identity of officers and directors, to point that controlling corporation dominates finances, policy, and business practices of controlled corporation.

Title: Fisser v. International Bank
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: If parent corporation is bound to its marionette's contract containing arbitration provision, then, like its marionette, the corporation is bound to submit to arbitration. 9 U.S.C.A. §§ 1–14, 2, 4.
